data.name: SDR-BP1_Category
data.value: Blocking Processes

data.name: SDR-BP1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aAIS62

data.name: SDR-BP1_Description
data.value: Blocking process

data.name: SDR-BP1_Finding
data.value: Process $(SPID) has been blocking $(BlockedNumberOfProcesses) other processes from running

data.name: SDR-BP1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Process $(SPID) has been blocking $(BlockedNumberOfProcesses) other processes from running. The process has been the lead blocker for $(BlockedWait) ms and is blocking object $(BlockedObject). The following details are relevant to the finding: $(ApplicationName?application $(ApplicationName): ) $(Database?in [$(Database)]: ) $(HostName?submitted from $(HostName): ) $(UserName?by $(UserName): )

data.name: SDR-BP1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the blocking chains be resolved to improve performance. This is typically resolved using the KILL command on the lead blocking process.

data.name: SDR-BP1_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) processes have been blocking other processes from running

data.name: SDR-BP1_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: These processes are lead blockers, preventing other processes from running.

data.name: SDR-D1_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9cFXjh

data.name: SDR-D1_Description
data.value: High average disk queue length: Drive holds swap files

data.name: SDR-D1_Finding
data.value: Drive $(DiskName) has a queue length average of $(AvgDiskQueueLength)

data.name: SDR-D1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: One or more swap files exist on drive $(DiskName) which also contains database files. The operating system is paging at an average rate of $(AvgPagesPerSecond) pages per second. Hosting page files on the same drive as database files can cause a performance bottleneck.

data.name: SDR-D1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended production servers have zero paging. Launch Task Manager and view the "Peak working Set" column to determine the largest users of memory and determine which can be removed to reduce the load. If at all possible, move your database files to a physical disk that does not host page files.

data.name: SDR-D1_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) drives have a high average queue length.

data.name: SDR-D1_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: One or more swap files exist on these drives. Hosting page files on the same drive as database files can cause a performance bottleneck.

data.name: SDR-D10_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D10_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aCOOyo

data.name: SDR-D10_Description
data.value: Tempdb is not pre-sized appropriately

data.name: SDR-D10_Finding
data.value: Tempdb is not pre-sized appropriately

data.name: SDR-D10_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The TempDB is being recreated each time SQL Server restarts at $(InitialSizeMB)MB but is currently $(CurrentSizeMB)MB which means that significant autogrow activity is occurring.

data.name: SDR-D10_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that autogrow be left on with instant file initialization left on. In addition, the database should be configured so that it never hits an autogrow event or very few autogrow events. Make sure the autogrow growth increment is appropriate.

data.name: SDR-D11_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D11_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9eQhQY

data.name: SDR-D11_Description
data.value: tempdb is experiencing metadata contention and waits

data.name: SDR-D11_Finding
data.value: Your tempdb is experiencing significant metadata contention and waits

data.name: SDR-D11_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Waits on tempdb can have a significant impact on overall SQL Server performance because all sorting, joining, group by, cursors and many other SQL Server operations rely on temporary objects which are implicitly created in this database. Contention on tempdb resources can result when there are many concurrent operations attempting to allocate/deallocate objects within a tempdb data file.

data.name: SDR-D11_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Numerous SQL Server operations require the creation of temporary objects in tempdb even when the running query does not explicitly use a temp table. $(li)When the temp object cache is depleted, object allocation/deallocation requires updates to the allocation pages of the data file where that object will be stored. These allocation pages can become a bottleneck when multiple concurrent object allocations are made within a single data file.

data.name: SDR-D11_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)When there are too many data files available, the allocation of very large objects within tempdb may see reduced performance due to the overhead generated by the allocation system.

data.name: SDR-D11_Recommendation
data.value: $(TraceStatus) is recommended that you create multiple data files for tempdb so that concurrent object allocations can be made in separate data files in order to avoid waiting for access to the allocation pages. The number of data files needed is based on the number of processor cores available to SQL Server for concurrent query processing. Generally a data file to processor core ratio between 1/4 and 1/2 will be optimal for most workloads, but in some cases the demands on tempdb may require even more data files in order to avoid allocation page contention and the waits associated with it. However, be aware that if your workload needs to store a small number of very large objects in tempdb, such as very large temp tables or sort operators spilling out of memory into tempdb, then writing out that data can be slowed significantly because of the overhead of the file weighting algorithm used by the allocation system. You should consider the data access patterns of your SQL Server workload when deciding whether new data files should be added to tempdb.

data.name: SDR-D12_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D12_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/dlroVZ

data.name: SDR-D12_Description
data.value: Tempdb could use additional data files

data.name: SDR-D12_Finding
data.value: Your TempDB performance could be improved by adding additional data files

data.name: SDR-D12_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Your system has $(ProcessorCount) logical processors but TempDB is only configured to have $(FileCount) data files.

data.name: SDR-D12_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that 1/2 to a maximum of 1 TempDB data file be created for each physical CPU core (not including hyperthreading) available to SQL Server (accounting for any affinity mask settings) up to a maximum of 8 data files to allow a thread on each processor to use a specific data file.

data.name: SDR-D13_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D13_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bCCaaA

data.name: SDR-D13_Description
data.value: tempdb has too many data files

data.name: SDR-D13_Finding
data.value: The number of tempdb data files exceeds half of the number of available processors

data.name: SDR-D13_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Tempdb is configured to have $(FileCount) data files but your system only has $(ProcessorCount) processor cores. This can degrade system performance for some workloads.

data.name: SDR-D13_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)If your workload needs to store a small number of very large objects in tempdb, such as very large temp tables or sort operators spilling out of memory into tempdb, then writing out that data can be slowed significantly because of the overhead of the file-weighting algorithm used by the allocation system.$(li)Having a large number of data files in tempdb can lead to seemingly random I/O when the lazy writer flushes dirty buffer pages from tempdb out to disk. This can potentially cause longer wait times if the I/O subsystem cannot handle the workload of writing out dirty pages to many different files.

data.name: SDR-D13_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)Workloads that create many small objects in tempdb will not see a significant performance loss, and may actually see performance improvement from having a large number of data files in tempdb due to reduced contention on the allocation maps.$(li)Some workloads will benefit from having a large number of data files in the tempdb. You can ignore this recommendation if your tempdb file structure is already optimized for the common workloads and data access patterns on this server.

data.name: SDR-D13_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you review the data access patterns caused by a typical workload on this server to determine if tempdb performance would be improved by reducing the number of data files. Generally a data file to processor core ratio between 1/4 and 1/2 will be optimal for most workloads. However, some workloads will benefit from adding tempdb data files beyond half the number of processor cores. When reviewing the typical workloads for this server, you may find that the current number of tempdb data files is required for optimal performance.

data.name: SDR-D14_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D14_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bE8bhm

data.name: SDR-D14_Description
data.value: Page compression is recommended

data.name: SDR-D14_Finding
data.value: Your server is experiencing significant I/O volume with no CPU usage problems. Page compression should be used

data.name: SDR-D14_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Page compression is not enabled on large and busy tables, which causes system performance degradation.

data.name: SDR-D14_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you turn on page compression on $(ObjectName) which should compress approximately $(CompressionPct)% and save you $(SavingsMB)MB.

data.name: SDR-D15_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D15_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/dmEhZg

data.name: SDR-D15_Description
data.value: Tempdb is not in simple recovery mode

data.name: SDR-D15_Finding
data.value: The TempDB database is not in Simple Recovery Mode

data.name: SDR-D15_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This causes SQL Server to slow dramatically.

data.name: SDR-D15_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the TempDB be set to Simple Recovery Mode as, by default, SQL Server only logs the before images of changes to data in the TempDB.

data.name: SDR-D17_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D17_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/buy2g4

data.name: SDR-D17_Description
data.value: Low fill factor for large tables

data.name: SDR-D17_Finding
data.value: [$(IndexName)] on table [$(SchemaName)].[$(TableName)] in database [$(DatabaseName)] has a fill factor of $(FillFactor) percent

data.name: SDR-D17_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A low fill factor on a large table causes an increase in the System I/Os as well as an additional memory footprint which slows SQL Server execution.

data.name: SDR-D17_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the index [$(IndexName)] on table [$(SchemaName)].[$(TableName)] in database [$(DatabaseName)] be examined to determine if it needs a low fill factor. If not, alter the table indexes to set a more appropriate fill factor.

data.name: SDR-D17_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) of the server's busiest databases have tables with low fill factors.

data.name: SDR-D17_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This causes an increase in the System I/Os as well as an additional memory footprint which slows SQL Server execution.

data.name: SDR-D17_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that these tables be examined to determine whether they need a low fill factor. If not, alter the table indexes to a more appropriate fill factor.

data.name: SDR-D19_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D19_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/allM0f

data.name: SDR-D19_Description
data.value: Auto-shrink enabled

data.name: SDR-D19_Finding
data.value: Database [$(DatabaseName)] has autoshrink enabled

data.name: SDR-D19_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Database [$(DatabaseName)] is configured to automatically shrink any data or log file once the file grows beyond the initial startup size defined for the file.

data.name: SDR-D19_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)A data file shrink will cause indexes to become fragmented. The fragmentation reduces the efficiency of range scans by requiring more I/O requests to read the same number of pages. $(li)There is an increase in the amount of I/O and CPU resource usage when performing the file shrink operations.$(li)The files can get into a cycle of frequently performing an autogrow followed by an autoshrink only to repeat this cycle over and over again. This repeated cycle will cause fragmentation of the files at the file system level that can cause I/O performance problems. Additionally this ends up continually wasting I/O and CPU resources by repeating these operations.

data.name: SDR-D19_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that autoshrink is turned off on the database.

data.name: SDR-D19_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) databases have auto-shrink enabled

data.name: SDR-D19_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: $(Count) databases are configured to automatically shrink any data or log file once the file grows beyond the initial startup size defined for the file.

data.name: SDR-D19_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that autoshrink is turned off on all of the databases.

data.name: SDR-D21_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D21_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/a74gF9

data.name: SDR-D21_Finding
data.value: The tables listed below have highly fragmented tables/Indexes: • Table – xxx, Index – xxx, fragmentation % - xxx, • Table – xxx, Index – xxx, fragmentation % - xxx

data.name: SDR-D21_Impact_Explanation
data.value: High levels of fragmentation causes excessive I/Os (by reducing the efficiency of ordered scans and pre-fetches) together with sub-optimal usage of the buffer pool and should be avoided.

data.name: SDR-D21_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that batch jobs should be created as part of a regularly scheduled maintenance plan to remove fragmentation. In cases where fragmentation builds up really rapidly, lower fill factors can be used to significantly slow the pace of fragmentation.

data.name: SDR-D21_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-D21_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-D21_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-D2_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D2_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cud2KS

data.name: SDR-D2_Description
data.value: High disk queue length

data.name: SDR-D2_Finding
data.value: Drive $(DiskName) has a queue length average of $(AvgDiskQueueLength)

data.name: SDR-D2_Impact_Explanation
data.value: One or more system page files exist on drive $(DiskName) which also contains database files. Hosting page files on the same drive as database files can cause a performance bottleneck.

data.name: SDR-D2_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you reduce the load on this drive by moving the system page file to another drive.

data.name: SDR-D2_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) drives have a high queue length

data.name: SDR-D2_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: One or more swap files exist on these drives. Hosting page files on the same drive as database files can cause a performance bottleneck.

data.name: SDR-D2_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you reduce the load on these drives by moving the system page file to another drive.

data.name: SDR-D20_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D20_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9KrdZ3

data.name: SDR-D20_Finding
data.value: The databases listed below have the Auto-Shrink option enabled: • xxx.dbo.xxx, • xxx.dbo.xxx

data.name: SDR-D20_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Auto-shrink is not advised due the following: 1. Causes significant I/O to be exerted on the production system at random intervals which will affect general system responsiveness, 2. Causes significant fragmentation on every table moved due to the Auto-Shrink process of moving blocks of data from the database file into available areas towards the near the beginning of the file.

data.name: SDR-D20_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that DBCC SHRINKDATABASE be scheduled during a batch processing window in order to have control over the impact of shrinking a database and this shrink should be closely followed by a defragmentation of all tables in the database as there is no way of knowing which tables will have fragmented.

data.name: SDR-D18_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D18_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/biMNsa

data.name: SDR-D18_Finding
data.value: On some of the server’s busiest databases, a significant amount of table/index fragmentation exists on the following tables: • Table – xxx, Index – xxx, fragmentation % - xxx, • Table – xxx, Index – xxx, fragmentation % - xxx

data.name: SDR-D18_Impact_Explanation
data.value: High levels of fragmentation causes excessive I/Os (by reducing the efficiency of ordered scans and pre-fetches) together with sub-optimal usage of the buffer pool and should be avoided.

data.name: SDR-D18_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that batch jobs should be created as part of a regularly scheduled maintenance plan to remove fragmentation. In cases where fragmentation builds up really rapidly, lower fill factors can be used to significantly slow the pace of fragmentation.

data.name: SDR-D18_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-D18_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-D18_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-D3_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D3_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/dv8TPR

data.name: SDR-D3_Description
data.value: I/O subsystem has been under stress

data.name: SDR-D3_Finding
data.value: The Wait statistics on your server indicate there have been periods where the I/O subsystem has been under considerable stress

data.name: SDR-D3_Impact_Explanation
data.value: An accurate analysis of your I/O subsystem cannot be determined unless the analysis occurs during a busy period.

data.name: SDR-D3_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that SQL doctor be scheduled to run during the next period of high I/O stress.

data.name: SDR-D16_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D16_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aEiiLe

data.name: SDR-D16_Finding
data.value: The statistics for the following tables are incorrect, which may cause the generation of suboptimal execution plans: • Table xxx.dbo.xxx, # of rows modified since statistics last updated – xxx, statistics last updated at xx/xx/xx xx:xx (xxhrs ago), • Table xxx.dbo.xxx, # of rows modified since statistics last updated – xxx, statistics last updated at xx/xx/xx xx:xx (xxhrs ago)

data.name: SDR-D16_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This may lead to greater amounts of I/Os being generated than necessary as well as excessive TempDB and processor usage in order to fulfill TSQL queries.

data.name: SDR-D16_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you ensure the following: • Auto create/update stats has been turned off at the database level, • Index has been created with STATISTICS_NORECOMPUTE = ON, • Statistics have been created with WITH(NORECOMPUTE)

data.name: SDR-D16_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-D16_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-D16_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-D4_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D4_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/c0R9H9

data.name: SDR-D4_Description
data.value: High average disk queue length and fragmentation: Drive holds transaction log and data files

data.name: SDR-D4_Finding
data.value: Drive $(DiskName) has a queue length average of $(AvgDiskQueueLength). This drive is also responsible for writing the transaction logs sequentially and performing the read/write of SQL Server pages which is typically random

data.name: SDR-D4_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This results in latency currently measured at $(AvgDiskSecPerTransfer)ms as the head moves between sequential transactional log writing and the random Reading/Writing of SQL Server pages. Significant fragmentation or a unit partition size which is not a multiple of 64kb has also been detected, which causes additional head movement and extra delay.

data.name: SDR-D4_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that for busy databases the Transaction logs reside on a different physical drive than the data files and that the database and disk should be defragmented.

data.name: SDR-D4_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) drives have a high average queue length. These drives are responsible for writing the transaction logs sequentially and performing the read/write of SQL Server pages, which is typically random.

data.name: SDR-D4_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This results in high latency as the head moves between sequential transactional log writing and the random Reading/Writing of SQL Server pages. Significant fragmentation or a unit partition size which is not a multiple of 64kb has also been detected, which causes additional head movement and extra delay.

data.name: SDR-D5_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D5_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9KEXbf

data.name: SDR-D5_Description
data.value: Incorrect unit allocation disc: Drive holds transaction log and data files

data.name: SDR-D5_Finding
data.value: Incorrect unit allocation size. Drive $(DiskName) has a queue length average of $(AvgDiskQueueLength). This drive is also responsible for writing the transaction logs sequentially and performing the read/write of SQL Server pages which is typically random

data.name: SDR-D5_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This results in latency currently measured at $(AvgDiskSecPerTransfer)ms as the head moves between sequential transactional log writing and the random Reading/Writing of SQL Server pages. The unit allocation size has been detected to be $(AllocationSize)KB. SQL Server works far more efficiently with unit allocation sizes of 64KB and larger.

data.name: SDR-D5_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that for busy databases the Transaction logs reside on a different physical drive than the data files and that a unit allocation size of 64KB or larger be used.

data.name: SDR-D5_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: Incorrect unit allocation size for $(Count) drives. These drives are responsible for writing the transaction logs sequentially and performing the read/write of SQL Server pages, which is typically random.

data.name: SDR-D5_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This results in high latency as the head moves between sequential transactional log writing and the random Reading/Writing of SQL Server pages. The unit allocation size is insufficient: SQL Server works far more efficiently with unit allocation sizes of 64KB and larger.

data.name: SDR-D6_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D6_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9shrxk

data.name: SDR-D6_Description
data.value: High average disk queue length: Drive holds transaction log and data files

data.name: SDR-D6_Finding
data.value: Drive $(DiskName) has a queue length average of $(AvgDiskQueueLength). This drive is also responsible for writing the transaction logs sequentially and performing the read/write of SQL Server pages which is typically random

data.name: SDR-D6_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This results in latency currently measured at $(AvgDiskSecPerTransfer)ms as the head moves between sequential transactional log writing and the random Reading/Writing of SQL Server pages.

data.name: SDR-D6_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that for busy databases the Transaction logs reside on a different physical drive than the data files.

data.name: SDR-D6_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) drives have a high average queue length. These drives are responsible for writing the transaction logs sequentially and performing the read/write of SQL Server pages, which is typically random.

data.name: SDR-D6_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This results in high latency as the head moves between sequential transactional log writing and the random Reading/Writing of SQL Server pages.

data.name: SDR-D7_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D7_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/afaa2P

data.name: SDR-D7_Description
data.value: High average disk queue length: Drive is SAN, SSD, or RAID array

data.name: SDR-D7_Finding
data.value: Your SAN, SSD or RAID array (reported as Drive $(DiskName)) has a queue length average of $(AvgDiskQueueLength)

data.name: SDR-D7_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The LUN allocated on the SAN, SSD, or RAID array is overloaded.

data.name: SDR-D7_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that for a Raid Array, switch to RAID 10 or add additional disks to support a higher rate of IO. For a SAN, ask the SAN administrator to increase the number of devices participating in this LUN.

data.name: SDR-D7_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) SANs, SSDs, or RAID arrays have a high queue length

data.name: SDR-D7_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The LUNs allocated on these SANs, SSDs, or RAID arrays are overloaded.

data.name: SDR-D7_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that for a Raid Array, switch to RAID 10 or add additional disks to support a higher rate of IO. For a SAN, ask the SAN administrator to increase the number of devices participating in the LUN.

data.name: SDR-D8_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D8_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/99Ah9a

data.name: SDR-D8_Description
data.value: Instant initialization is not enabled

data.name: SDR-D8_Finding
data.value: Your server has not been optimized to allow SQL Server to instantly expand databases (including TempDB) without first zeroing out space on the disk

data.name: SDR-D8_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Your server is not currently optimized to allow SQL Server to instantly expand a database (including TempDB) without first zeroing out the space on disk. If SQL Server needs to expand a database (or create a new one) the zeroing out of space on the disk can take a considerable amount of time.

data.name: SDR-D8_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the Service account of SQL Server $(SQLServerServiceAccount?({0}) include:include) the permission SE_MANAGE_VOLUME_NAME (granted to Windows Admin by default or via the Perform Volume Maintenance Tasks security policy) and that all the drives used by databases must be in an NTFS format to allow SQL Server to perform instant initialization.

data.name: SDR-D9_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D9_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/byil7H

data.name: SDR-D9_Description
data.value: tempdb data files are not all the same size

data.name: SDR-D9_Finding
data.value: tempdb data files are not all the same size

data.name: SDR-D9_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SQL Server will allocate pages for objects from the various tempdb data files in proportion to their relative sizes. The larger tempdb data files will experience more I/O stress than the smaller files, which will decrease overall performance. The largest file is $(LargestFileSizeText) and the smallest file is $(SmallestFileSizeText).

data.name: SDR-D9_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)When new objects are created in tempdb, the allocations will not be spread evenly between the data files, which removes one of the key benefits of using multiple data files for tempdb.$(li)SQL Server will favor the larger data files when allocating pages for objects in tempdb. This will cause increased contention for access to the allocation pages of those data files, resulting in reduced performance.

data.name: SDR-D9_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If you are not experiencing detrimental wait times when allocating pages for objects in tempdb, then the data file configuration is sufficient for your workload.

data.name: SDR-D9_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that all tempdb data files should be sized exactly the same, and if autogrowth is allowed, then the autogrowth increment should also be equalized across all data files. However, if autogrow is turned on for these data files, then they may still grow unevenly regardless of the autogrowth increment. This occurs when a new object allocation necessitates growing some but not all of the data files to find sufficient storage space.

data.name: SDR-D22_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D22_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/18xJQi2

data.name: SDR-D22_Description
data.value: Data files of tempdb do not have the same auto growth settings

data.name: SDR-D22_Finding
data.value: Data files of tempdb do not have the same auto growth settings

data.name: SDR-D22_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SQL Server will allocate pages for objects from the various tempdb data files in proportion to their relative sizes. The larger tempdb data files will experience more I/O stress than the smaller files, which will decrease overall performance.

data.name: SDR-D22_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)When new objects are created in tempdb, the allocations will not be spread evenly between the data files, which removes one of the key benefits of using multiple data files for tempdb.$(li)SQL Server will favor the larger data files when allocating pages for objects in tempdb. This will cause increased contention for access to the allocation pages of those data files, resulting in reduced performance.

data.name: SDR-D22_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)The current configuration is not having a performance impact on the server and is sufficient based on your current workload.

data.name: SDR-D22_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that all tempdb data files should be sized exactly the same, and the autogrowth increment should also be equalized across all data files. However, they may still grow unevenly regardless of the autogrowth increment. This occurs when a new object allocation necessitates growing some but not all of the data files to find sufficient storage space.

data.name: SDR-DC1_Category
data.value: Database Configuration

data.name: SDR-DC1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/av9nSh

data.name: SDR-DC1_Description
data.value: Non-default setting

data.name: SDR-DC1_Finding
data.value: $(Configuration) is set to value $(CurrentValue) for database $(Database)

data.name: SDR-DC1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The $(Configuration) setting has been changed from the default value of $(DefaultValue) to $(CurrentValue).

data.name: SDR-DC1_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)A non-default setting can have an adverse impact on performance.

data.name: SDR-DC1_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If the current setting has been verified to provide the greatest value.

data.name: SDR-DC1_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that the default value of $(DefaultValue) is used for the $(Configuration) database setting.
However, all changes to database configuration settings require thorough testing to verify there are no adverse effects.

data.name: SDR-DC1_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) non-default database settings

data.name: SDR-DC1_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The default database setting has been changed.

data.name: SDR-DC1_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that the default value is used for the database setting.
However, all changes to database configuration settings require thorough testing to verify there are no adverse effects.

data.name: SDR-DC2_Category
data.value: Database Configuration

data.name: SDR-DC2_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aAmJpH

data.name: SDR-DC2_Description
data.value: Page_Verify set to none on writeable database

data.name: SDR-DC2_Finding
data.value: The PAGE_VERIFY option for database $(Database) is set to None

data.name: SDR-DC2_Impact_Explanation
data.value: When PAGE_VERIFY is set to None on a writeable database it may prevent the early detection of I/O corruption issues.

data.name: SDR-DC2_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you set the PAGE_VERIFY option to TORN_PAGE_DETECTION (for best performance) or to CHECKSUM (for best integrity) on database $(Database).

data.name: SDR-DC2_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: The PAGE_VERIFY option is set to None for $(Count) databases

data.name: SDR-DC2_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you set the PAGE_VERIFY option to TORN_PAGE_DETECTION (for best performance) or to CHECKSUM (for best integrity) on all writable databases.

data.name: SDR-DC3_Category
data.value: Database Configuration

data.name: SDR-DC3_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cABc8c

data.name: SDR-DC3_Finding
data.value: The PAGE_VERIFY option for read-only database $(Database) is Not set to None

data.name: SDR-DC3_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The PAGE_VERIFY options of TORN_PAGE_DETECTION and CHECKSUM create unnecessary performance overhead on databases where data is not changing.

data.name: SDR-DC3_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you set the PAGE_VERIFY option to None on database $(Database).

data.name: SDR-DC3_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: The PAGE_VERIFY option is Not set to None for $(Count) read-only databases

data.name: SDR-DC3_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you set the PAGE_VERIFY option to None on all read-only databases.

data.name: SDR-DC4_Category
data.value: Database Configuration

data.name: SDR-DC4_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bx6UBe

data.name: SDR-DC4_Description
data.value: Database compatibility mode mismatch

data.name: SDR-DC4_Finding
data.value: The compatibility mode of database $(Database) ($(CurrentCompatibility)) is lower than the SQL Server version ($(TargetCompatibility))

data.name: SDR-DC4_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Running a database at a lower compatibility mode than the SQL Server version may cause certain features of SQL Server to be unavailable or to function unpredictably or to perform poorly.

data.name: SDR-DC4_Recommendation
data.value: If you are unsure of the reasons this database is running in a lower compatibility mode, it is recommended that you test the impact of setting the $(Database) compatibility mode to $(TargetCompatibility)

data.name: SDR-DC4_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: Database compatibility mode is lower than the target SQL Server version for $(Count) databases

data.name: SDR-DC4_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: If you are unsure of the reasons these databases are running in a lower compatibility mode, it is recommended that you test the impact of setting the compatibility mode to match the SQL Server version.

data.name: SDR-DC5_Category
data.value: Database Configuration

data.name: SDR-DC5_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aLRHoG

data.name: SDR-DC5_Description
data.value: Database collation mismatch

data.name: SDR-DC5_Finding
data.value: The collation of database $(Database), $(CurrentCollation), does not match that of the model database

data.name: SDR-DC5_Impact_Explanation
data.value: When database collations differ from the model database, it is possible to experience collation conflicts which may prevent code from executing. For example, when a table is joined to a temporary table, SQL Server may experience a collation conflict error if the user-defined database collation and the model database collation are different. This is because temporary tables are created in tempdb, which is created at server startup with the collation of the model database.

data.name: SDR-DC5_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you consider one of the following resolutions: $(li)Export the data from $(Database) and import it into new tables that have the same collation as model ($(ModelCollation)), $(li)Rebuild the system databases to use the same collation as $(Database) $(li)Modify any stored procedures and ad-hoc code that join user tables to tables in tempdb to prevent collation conflicts. To do this, add the "COLLATE database_default" clause to the column definitions of the temporary table.

data.name: SDR-DC5_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: The collations of $(Count) databases do not match that of the model database

data.name: SDR-DL1_Category
data.value: DeadLocks

data.name: SDR-DL1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bxz4WO

data.name: SDR-DL1_Description
data.value: A trace is not running to capture deadlock information

data.name: SDR-DL1_Finding
data.value: A trace is not running to capture deadlock information

data.name: SDR-DL1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Not running a trace capturing deadlock events prevents you from knowing whether or not deadlocks are occurring and the underlying cause.

data.name: SDR-DL1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you run a SQL Server trace in order to monitor for deadlocks.

data.name: SDR-DL2_Category
data.value: DeadLocks

data.name: SDR-DL2_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/b0pDL8

data.name: SDR-DL2_Description
data.value: Deadlock

data.name: SDR-DL2_Finding
data.value: A deadlock was detected $(ApplicationName? in application $(ApplicationName): ) $(Database?in [$(Database)]: ) $(HostName?submitted from $(HostName): ) $(UserName?by $(UserName): ) at $(StartTime)

data.name: SDR-DL2_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Deadlocks are caused by inconsistencies in the order in which an application updates data elements. Details of the deadlock are: Deadlock Victim Details: $(ApplicationName? in application $(ApplicationName): ) $(Database?in [$(Database)]: ) $(HostName?submitted from $(HostName): ) $(UserName?by $(UserName): )

data.name: SDR-DL2_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you investigate and remedy the deadlock.

data.name: SDR-DL2_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) deadlocks were detected

data.name: SDR-DL2_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Deadlocks are caused when inconsistencies in the order in which an application updates data elements.

data.name: SDR-DL2_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: We recommend you investigate and remedy these deadlocks.

data.name: SDR-I1_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aMxFSF

data.name: SDR-I1_Description
data.value: Out-of-date database statistics

data.name: SDR-I1_Finding
data.value: Database [$(Database)] may have out-of-date statistics

data.name: SDR-I1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Out-of-date statistics can result in poor query performance because the query optimizer might not choose the most efficient plan for retrieving or updating data.

data.name: SDR-I1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you set the AUTO_UPDATE_STATISTICS database option to ON by using the ALTER DATABASE statement. Alternatively, you can manually update statistics by using the UPDATE STATISTICS statement.

data.name: SDR-I1_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) databases may have out-of-date statistics

data.name: SDR-I10_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I10_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aMxFSF

data.name: SDR-I10_Description
data.value: Index is Experiencing Frequent Updates

data.name: SDR-I10_Finding
data.value: [$(IndexName)] on [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)] is experiencing frequent updates

data.name: SDR-I10_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Since this server was restarted $(DaysNotUsed) days ago, this index has experienced an average of $(WritesPerSecond) writes per second with $(WritesPerRead) writes occurring for each read.

data.name: SDR-I10_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)When modifying data in a table with nonclustered indexes, SQL Server incurs additional overhead in order to keep the indexes up-to-date. $(li)If write operations far outnumber read operations on your data set, then the cost of keeping the index up-to-date may outweigh the performance benefits to your queries.

data.name: SDR-I10_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)SQLdoctor’s analysis shows that this index is being used to improve the performance of some queries, and there is a trade-off between improved read performance and decreased write performance. If you are not experiencing any performance issues when updating the underlying table, then this recommendation can be ignored. $(li)Some indexes are designed and implemented to improve the performance of an infrequent but high priority cyclic business process, such as quarterly reporting. Altering such an index may have an undesired impact that is not obvious until a complete business cycle has elapsed. $(li)The index usage statistics (writes per second and writes per read) are based on usage since the last server restart. If an entire business/usage cycle has not elapsed since that time, then those statistics may be incomplete. Incomplete statistics may not accurately reflect usage patterns.

data.name: SDR-I10_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the definition of this index to determine whether it should be redesigned or removed to avoid the overhead cost during write operations. If the index is used for infrequent high priority operations, then consider disabling the index, re-enabling the index by rebuilding it shortly before it is needed, and then disabling the index again after the read operations have been completed.
However, altering or dropping any of the existing indexes could have negative consequences for queries which specifically reference those indexes in a query hint.

data.name: SDR-I10_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: Indexes are experiencing frequent updates

data.name: SDR-I10_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: These indexes experience high numbers of writes per second and high ratios of writes for each read.

data.name: SDR-I10_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the definition of these indexes to determine whether they should be redesigned or removed to avoid the overhead cost during write operations. If these indexes are used for infrequent high priority operations, then consider recreating the indexes shortly before they are needed and removing them after the read operations have been completed.
However, altering or dropping any of the existing indexes could have negative consequences for queries which specifically reference those indexes in a query hint.

data.name: SDR-I12_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I12_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cjyed9

data.name: SDR-I12_Finding
data.value: The function "$(FunctionName)" may be causing a table scan on [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)]

data.name: SDR-I12_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The function or expression "$(FunctionName)" on a column can cause index suppression resulting in poor performance due to a scan being performed instead of a seek.

data.name: SDR-I12_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you consider redesigning this WHERE clause to prevent index suppression and performance degradation.

data.name: SDR-I12_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) functions may be causing table scans

data.name: SDR-I12_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: These functions or expressions can cause index suppression, resulting in poor performance due to a scan being performed instead of a seek.

data.name: SDR-I12_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you consider redesigning these WHERE clauses to prevent index suppression and performance degradation.

data.name: SDR-I11_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I11_Finding
data.value: Primary key $(PrimaryKeyName) on table $(TableName) is experiencing frequent updates

data.name: SDR-I11_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Typically a clustered index is maintained for a table's primary key. SQL Server incurs performance overhead when maintaining this index. If the index requires frequent updates, the cost of maintaining the index may outweigh the benefit of the index.

data.name: SDR-I11_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you consider altering table $(TableName) to use a different primary key.

data.name: SDR-I11_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-I11_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-I11_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-I11_Impact_Factor
data.value: Impact: Dont show if number of updates < 2/sec average over the sample period or longer; Low - updates per sec >=2 <=25/sec ave; Med - updates per sec > 25; There is no high impact for this recomendation as no existing index (no matter how bad) can single-handedly drag down a server

data.name: SDR-I11_Confidence_Factor
data.value: 5% confidence if its a clustered index as no DBA can easily change this.30% confidence if not a clustered index as we dont know if removing this index is going to destroy the run times of queries or stop a query which names the index from running completly

data.name: SDR-I14_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I14_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/dpLnka

data.name: SDR-I14_Finding
data.value: An implicit conversion on column [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)].[$(Column)] to data type "$(DataType)" may be causing index suppression

data.name: SDR-I14_Impact_Explanation
data.value: An implicit conversion in a WHERE clause of a query can cause index suppression if an indexed column is of a different type resulting in a scan rather than a seek.

data.name: SDR-I14_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you consider redesigning this WHERE clause to prevent index suppression and performance degradation.

data.name: SDR-I14_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) implicit conversions may be causing index suppression

data.name: SDR-I14_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you consider redesigning these WHERE clauses to prevent index suppression and performance degradation.

data.name: SDR-I13_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I13_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9gImFn

data.name: SDR-I13_Finding
data.value: The referenced column in Index $(IndexName) begins with a date type

data.name: SDR-I13_Impact_Explanation
data.value: If the key columns of a multi-column index begins with a date type, queries using the index can experience poor performance due to sub-optimal range scans.

data.name: SDR-I13_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you consider redesigning index $(IndexName) so that the key columns do not begin with a date type.

data.name: SDR-I13_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation

data.name: SDR-I16_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I16_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/caOD8r

data.name: SDR-I16_Description
data.value: Unused Index

data.name: SDR-I16_Finding
data.value: Index [$(IndexName)] on [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)] has not been used in $(DaysSinceUsed) days

data.name: SDR-I16_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Since this server was restarted $(DaysNotUsed) days ago, this index has experienced an average of $(WritesPerSecond) writes per second. However, this index has not been used by any reads during that time.

data.name: SDR-I16_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)When modifying data in a table with nonclustered indexes, SQL Server incurs additional overhead in order to keep the indexes up-to-date. $(li)If write operations far outnumber read operations on your data set, then the cost of keeping the index up-to-date may outweigh the performance benefits to your queries.

data.name: SDR-I16_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)Some indexes are designed and implemented to improve the performance of an infrequent but high priority cyclic business process, such as quarterly reporting. Altering such an index may have an undesired impact that is not obvious until a complete business cycle has elapsed. $(li)The index usage statistics (writes per second and writes per read) are based on usage since the last server restart. If an entire business/usage cycle has not elapsed since that time, then those statistics may be incomplete. Incomplete statistics may not accurately reflect usage patterns.

data.name: SDR-I16_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the definition of this index to determine whether it should be redesigned or removed to avoid the overhead cost during write operations. If the index is used for infrequent high priority operations, then consider disabling the index, re-enabling the index by rebuilding it shortly before it is needed to re-enable it, and then disabling the index again after the read operations have been completed.
However, altering or dropping any of the existing indexes could have negative consequences for queries which specifically reference those indexes in a query hint.

data.name: SDR-I16_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) indexes have not been used recently

data.name: SDR-I16_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: These indexes experience high numbers of writes per second and high ratios of writes for each read.

data.name: SDR-I16_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the definitions of these indexes to determine whether they should be redesigned or removed to avoid the overhead cost during write operations. If these indexes are used for infrequent high priority operations, then consider recreating the indexes shortly before they are needed and removing them after the read operations have been completed.
However, altering or dropping any of the existing indexes could have negative consequences for queries which specifically reference those indexes in a query hint.

data.name: SDR-I15_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I15_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bUhP9B

data.name: SDR-I15_Finding
data.value: An index covering columns $(ColumnNames) can improve query performance on table $(TableName)

data.name: SDR-I15_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A large number of queries are accessing table $(TableName) referencing columns $(ColumnNames) that are not covered by an index. The performance of these queries would benefit from a covered index.

data.name: SDR-I15_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you add an index to $(TableName) including columns $(ColumnNames).

data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-I15_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-I15_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-I17_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I17_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aOIDK7

data.name: SDR-I17_Description
data.value: Index experiencing page latch contention

data.name: SDR-I17_Finding
data.value: $(IndexName?Index [$(IndexName)] on table:Table) [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)] is experiencing high levels of page latch contention

data.name: SDR-I17_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The $(IndexName?index:table) is experiencing an average wait time of $(FormattedAvgWait) per wait with $(WaitCount) waits due to latch contention. This can significantly degrade the performance of queries using the $(IndexName?index:table).

data.name: SDR-I17_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you review your applications usage of $(IndexName?index [$(IndexName)]:table [$(TableName)]) to determine if optimizations can be introduced to reduce contention.

data.name: SDR-I17_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) objects are experiencing excessive page latch contention

data.name: SDR-I17_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: These objects are experiencing a high average wait time per wait due to latch contention. This can significantly degrade the performance of queries using these objects.

data.name: SDR-I17_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you review your application's use of these objects to determine if optimizations can be introduced to reduce contention.

data.name: SDR-I19_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I19_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9bRLae

data.name: SDR-I19_Description
data.value: Out-of-date column statistics

data.name: SDR-I19_Finding
data.value: Column [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)].[$(Column)] has missing or out of date statistics

data.name: SDR-I19_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The statistics used in creating an execution plan based on a column is currently out of date. The execution plan generated is still correct, but it may not be optimal.

data.name: SDR-I19_Recommendation

data.name: SDR-I19_Plural_Form_Recommendation

data.name: SDR-I18_Finding
data.value: The SQL Server memory limit has been exceeded while generating an execution plan

data.name: SDR-I18_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The creation of an execution plan caused the SQL Server memory limit to be exceeded. The execution plan generated is still correct, but it may not be optimal.

data.name: SDR-I18_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you try one of the following methods to increase available memory: 1) Reduce the load on the server 2) Increase memory available to SQL Server 3) Check the max server memory option that is set with sp_configure and increase the value if it is too low
