data.name: SDR-I2_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I2_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/b3Qv1m

data.name: SDR-I2_Description
data.value: Index fragmentation

data.name: SDR-I2_Finding
data.value: Index [$(Name)] on [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)] with a partition size of $(PartitionSize) is $(FragmentationPercentage)% fragmented

data.name: SDR-I2_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Queries that rely on index [$(Name)] may be adversely impacted by fragmentation.

data.name: SDR-I2_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Highly fragmented indexes can cause inefficiencies with range scans because the SQL Server read-ahead logic is unable to read large page ranges into memory with single I/O requests. Instead, a greater number of smaller IO requests may be performed which can slow down query performance.

data.name: SDR-I2_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)The index is very small.$(li)The index is never used by queries that perform range scans.

data.name: SDR-I2_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you rebuild or reorganize the index.

data.name: SDR-I2_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) indexes are fragmented

data.name: SDR-I2_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Queries that rely on indexes may be adversely impacted by fragmentation.

data.name: SDR-I2_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you rebuild or reorganize the indexes.

data.name: SDR-I20_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I20_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cnuSux

data.name: SDR-I20_Description
data.value: Missing Index (DMV)

data.name: SDR-I20_Finding
data.value: Missing index on [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)]

data.name: SDR-I20_Impact_Explanation
data.value: An average of $(AvgUserScansSeeksPerDay) user seeks/scans per day on table [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)] could see performance improvements from adding a new index. The performance improvement is estimated to be $(AvgUserCostImpact) ms for each query execution.

data.name: SDR-I20_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Without proper indexes, the SQL Server query optimizer may not have an efficient path to choose for retrieval of row data to satisfy the query. This may result in a full scan of the underlying table data.

data.name: SDR-I20_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If write operations far outnumber read operations on your data set, then the cost of keeping the index up-to-date may outweigh the performance benefits to your queries. $(li)If the increase in performance from adding a new index does not justify the additional storage space on disk, additional time and space spent on backups, or additional maintenance required by the new index.

data.name: SDR-I20_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the data access patterns for this table to determine if the suggested index would improve your query performance significantly and to ensure the extra overhead of maintaining the index is justified. If the overhead of maintaining the index is justified, the suggested index should be created. Alternatively, review the existing indexes to determine if there is an index which can be modified to incorporate the missing index data, for example, by recreating the index with one or more additional non-key columns using the INCLUDE option.
However, be aware that creating indexes will increase the size of the underlying table, and that SQL Server will have the additional overhead of keeping indexes up-to-date when the table data changes.

data.name: SDR-I20_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(count) missing index opportunities were found

data.name: SDR-I20_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Several queries could see performance improvements from adding additional indexes. Without proper indexes, the SQL Server query optimizer may not have an efficient path to choose for retrieval of row data to satisfy the query. This may result in a full scan of the underlying table data.

data.name: SDR-I20_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review data access patterns for these tables to determine if the suggested indexes would improve your query performance significantly and to ensure the extra overhead of maintaining these indexes is justified. If the overhead of maintaining these indexes is justified, the suggested indexes should be created. Alternatively, review the existing indexes to determine if there are any indexes which can be modified to incorporate the missing index data.
However, be aware that creating indexes will increase the size of the underlying tables, and that SQL Server will have the additional overhead of keeping indexes up-to-date when the table data changes.

data.name: SDR-I21_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I21_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cnuSux

data.name: SDR-I21_Description
data.value: Overlapping Indexes

data.name: SDR-I21_Finding
data.value: Indexes on [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)] overlap

data.name: SDR-I21_Impact_Explanation
data.value:
Index [$(OverlappingIndexName)] and index [$(IndexName)] on table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] of database [$(Database)] contain the same data in some key columns and included columns.
These indexes are not identical, but they do share data. Index [$(IndexName)] consists of all the data contained in index [$(OverlappingIndexName)], plus additional columns. Index [$(OverlappingIndexName)] is being updated $(UpdatesPerDay) times per day.

data.name: SDR-I21_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)When modifying data in a table with a nonclustered index, SQL Server incurs additional overhead in order to keep the indexes up-to-date. $(li)Using multiple indexes for the same function requires additional storage space on disk and in memory. $(li)If this overlap is not intentional, then one of these indexes may not be used by any queries.

data.name: SDR-I21_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)These indexes may already be optimized to yield maximum performance for particular queries or access patterns (for example, seeking versus scanning). $(li)These indexes may be relatively small, which would invalidate concerns about their storage or memory footprint. $(li)The time SQL Server spends updating these indexes may be very small, which would invalidate concerns about a performance overhead for write operations.$(li)Some indexes are designed and implemented to improve the performance of an infrequent but high priority cyclic business process, such as quarterly reporting. Altering such an index may have an undesired impact that is not obvious until a complete business cycle has elapsed.

data.name: SDR-I21_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the definitions of these indexes and the queries that use them to determine whether index [$(IndexName)] can replace index [$(OverlappingIndexName)] without negatively impacting the performance of queries that currently use index [$(OverlappingIndexName)]. If this index is used for infrequent high priority operations, then consider disabling the index, re-enabling the index by rebuilding it shortly before it is needed, and then disabling the index again after the read operations have been completed.
However, be aware that index [$(IndexName)] occupies more space on disk and in memory; therefore queries which currently use [$(OverlappingIndexName)] may not receive the same performance benefit when using [$(IndexName)]. Also, altering or dropping either of the existing indexes could have negative consequences for queries which specifically reference those indexes in a query hint.

data.name: SDR-I21_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) overlapping indexes found

data.name: SDR-I21_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value:
Multiple indexes contain the same data in some key columns and included columns.
These indexes are not identical, but several indexes consist of all the data contained in the smaller indexes, plus additional columns. Maintaining these separate indexes incurs a performance overhead for data modifications on this database.

data.name: SDR-I21_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the definitions of these indexes and the queries that use them to determine whether the overlapping indexes can be deleted without negatively impacting the performance of the queries that currently use these indexes.
However, be aware that the larger indexes occupy more space on disk and in memory; therefore queries which currently use small overlapped indexes may not receive the same performance benefit when using the larger indexes. Also, altering or dropping either of the existing indexes could have negative consequences for queries which specifically reference those indexes in a query hint.

data.name: SDR-I22_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I22_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cUCyf1

data.name: SDR-I22_Description
data.value: A Non-Clustered Index Key Matches the Clustered Index Key

data.name: SDR-I22_Finding
data.value: A non-clustered index key matches the clustered index key on table [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)]

data.name: SDR-I22_Impact_Explanation
data.value:
Non-clustered index [$(NonClusteredIndexName)] contains the same key columns as the clustered index [$(ClusteredIndexName)] on table [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)].
These indexes are not identical, but the non-clustered index [$(NonClusteredIndexName)] contains a subset of the data in [$(ClusteredIndexName)] while using the same organizational structure. [$(NonClusteredIndexName)] may not provide a performance benefit over [$(ClusteredIndexName)], so it may not see regular use. Index [$(NonClusteredIndexName)] is being updated an average of $(UpdatesPerDay) times per day, but it has not been used to improve the read performance of any queries.

data.name: SDR-I22_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)When modifying data in a table with a nonclustered index, SQL Server incurs additional overhead in order to keep the indexes up-to-date. $(li)Using multiple indexes for the same function requires additional storage space on disk and in memory. $(li)If this overlap is not intentional, then one of these indexes may not be used by any queries.

data.name: SDR-I22_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)The time SQL Server spends updating these indexes may be very small, which would invalidate concerns about a performance overhead for write operations. $(li)These indexes may be relatively small, which would invalidate concerns about their storage or memory footprint. $(li)The SQL Server query optimizer will favor the non-clustered index for some data access patterns such as queries that aggregate the data in the key columns. In such cases the non-clustered index presents a performance improvement rather than a problem.$(li)Some indexes are designed and implemented to improve the performance of an infrequent but high priority cyclic business process, such as quarterly reporting. Altering such an index may have an undesired impact that is not obvious until a complete business cycle has elapsed. $(li)The index usage statistics (including updates per day) are based on usage since the last server restart. If an entire business/usage cycle has not elapsed since that time, then those statistics may be incomplete. Incomplete statistics may not accurately reflect usage patterns.

data.name: SDR-I22_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the definitions of these indexes to determine whether the non-clustered index is needed and to ensure the extra overhead of maintaining the non-clustered index is justified. If the overhead of maintaining the non-clustered index is not justified, the non-clustered index should be dropped. If this index is used for infrequent high priority operations, then consider disabling the index, re-enabling the index by rebuilding it shortly before it is needed, and then disabling the index again after the read operations have been completed.
However, be aware that dropping the non-clustered index may have negative performance impacts on those queries which are currently using it. The clustered index may be larger and may be less optimized to suit your data access patterns. Also, altering or dropping either of the existing indexes could have negative consequences for queries which specifically reference those indexes in a query hint.

data.name: SDR-I22_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: Non-clustered index keys matches the clustered index key

data.name: SDR-I22_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value:
Non-clustered indexes contain the same key columns as the clustered index on one or more tables.
These indexes are not identical, but the non-clustered indexes contain a subset of the data in the clustered indexes while using the same organizational structure. The non-clustered indexes will rarely provide a performance benefit over the clustered indexes, so they will rarely be used to improve query performance.

data.name: SDR-I22_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the definitions of these indexes to determine if the non-clustered indexes are needed and to ensure the extra overhead of maintaining the non-clustered indexes is justified. If the overhead of maintaining the non-clustered indexes is not justified, those indexes should be dropped.
However, be aware that dropping the non-clustered indexes may have negative performance impacts on those queries which are currently using them. The clustered indexes may be larger and may be less optimized to suit your data access patterns. Also, altering or dropping any of the existing indexes could have negative consequences for queries which specifically reference those indexes in a query hint.

data.name: SDR-I3_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I3_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bITWMu

data.name: SDR-I3_Description
data.value: Out-of-date statistics object

data.name: SDR-I3_Finding
data.value: Statistics object [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)].[$(Name)] was last updated on $(StatsDate) and would benefit from updated statistics

data.name: SDR-I3_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The optimizer may not be able to create optimal execution plans when statistics are out of date. This can lead to greater amounts of I/Os being generated than necessary as well as excessive TempDB and processor usage in order to fulfill T-SQL queries.

data.name: SDR-I3_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you schedule a process to update statistics explicitly for object [$(Name)]. Possible causes are: “Auto create/update stats” has been turned off at the database level; the index has been created with “STATISTICS_NORECOMPUTE = ON”; the statistics themselves have been created “WITH (NORECOMPUTE)”

data.name: SDR-I3_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) statistics objects would benefit from updated statistics

data.name: SDR-I3_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you schedule a process to update statistics explicitly for these objects. Possible causes are: “Auto create/update stats” has been turned off at the database level; the index has been created with “STATISTICS_NORECOMPUTE = ON”; the statistics themselves have been created “WITH (NORECOMPUTE)”

data.name: SDR-I4_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I4_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/ceXqCZ

data.name: SDR-I4_Description
data.value: Missing index

data.name: SDR-I4_Finding
data.value: Missing index on [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)]

data.name: SDR-I4_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Missing $(RecommendedIndexes.Count>1?indexes:index) on [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)] which is experiencing $(TableUpdatesPerMinute) table updates per minute.

data.name: SDR-I4_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Without proper indexes, the SQL Server query optimizer may not have an efficient path to choose for retrieval of row data to satisfy the query. This may result in a full scan of the underlying table data.

data.name: SDR-I4_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If write operations far outnumber read operations on your data set, then the cost of keeping the index up-to-date may outweigh the performance benefits to your queries. $(li)If the increase in performance from adding a new index does not justify the additional storage space on disk, additional time and space spent on backups, or additional maintenance required by the new index.

data.name: SDR-I4_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the data access patterns for this table to determine if the suggested index would improve your query performance significantly and to ensure the extra overhead of maintaining the index is justified. If the overhead of maintaining the index is justified, then the suggested index should be created. Additionally, review the existing indexes for consolidation opportunities and determine if there is an index that can be modified to incorporate the missing index data. For example, it might be possible to consolidate indexes by recreating one of them with one or more additional non-key columns using the INCLUDE option.
The ‘Affected Batches’ can be reviewed to see which batches are impacted by the addition of the new index. Each batch is labeled with the estimated percentage of cost improvement for the corresponding batch based on the addition of the new index.
However, be aware that creating indexes will increase the used allocation space of the database, and that SQL Server will have the additional overhead of keeping indexes up-to-date when the table data changes.

data.name: SDR-I4_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) tables are missing indexes

data.name: SDR-I4_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Adding the recommended indexes will improve SQL Server performance by optimizing the access paths for their respective workloads.

data.name: SDR-I4_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you review the data access patterns for the tables to determine if the suggested indexes would improve the performance of the queries significantly and to ensure the extra overhead of maintaining any new index is justified.

data.name: SDR-I5_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I5_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bPcpqr

data.name: SDR-I5_Description
data.value: Disabled index

data.name: SDR-I5_Finding
data.value: Index [$(Name)] on [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)] is disabled

data.name: SDR-I5_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A disabled index [$(Name)] has been found on table [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)]

data.name: SDR-I5_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)The query optimizer does not consider the index when creating query execution plans.$(li)For nonclustered indexes, disabling the index will delete the index data but leave the metadata for the index definition. However, for clustered indexes, all nonclustered indexes for the table will be disabled and the clustered index will continue to consume storage space.$(li)If the index is a clustered index, this will prevent user access to the table data.

data.name: SDR-I5_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)The index has been disabled to reduce the time taken for data extraction, transformation, and loading.$(li)The index is used rarely (once a week/month/quarter/year/etc.) and the cost of constantly keeping the index maintained is significant enough to justify rebuilding the index prior to using it and then disabling it again.$(li)A large nonclustered index has been disabled prior to rebuilding the index. Normally, rebuilding a nonclustered index requires enough temporary disk space to store both the old and new index. By disabling and rebuilding the nonclustered index in separate transactions, the space made available by disabling the index can be reused by the subsequent rebuild.

data.name: SDR-I5_Recommendation
data.value:
You should consider dropping the disabled index if it is no longer needed.
However, before dropping the index, verify that:$(li)The index is not temporarily disabled for data loads.$(li)The index is not rebuilt shortly before infrequent high priority operations and disabled after the read operations have completed.

data.name: SDR-I5_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) indexes are disabled

data.name: SDR-I5_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: $(Count) disabled indexes have been found.

data.name: SDR-I5_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
You should consider dropping the disabled indexes if they are no longer needed.
However, before dropping any disabled index, verify that:$(li)The index is not temporarily disabled for data loads.$(li)The index is not rebuilt shortly before infrequent high priority operations and disabled after the read operations have completed.

data.name: SDR-I6_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I6_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cUCyf1

data.name: SDR-I6_Description
data.value: Duplicate index

data.name: SDR-I6_Finding
data.value: Duplicate index found on [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)]

data.name: SDR-I6_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Duplicate indexes [$(IndexName)] and [$(DuplicateIndexName)] were found on table [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)].

data.name: SDR-I6_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)When modifying data in a table, SQL Server incurs additional overhead in order to keep the indexes up-to-date.$(li)Using multiple indexes for the same function requires additional storage space on disk and in memory.

data.name: SDR-I6_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)The time SQL Server spends updating these indexes may be negligible, which would invalidate concerns about a performance overhead for write operations.$(li)These indexes may be relatively small, which would invalidate concerns about their storage or memory footprint.

data.name: SDR-I6_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the definition of these indexes to determine whether they should be redesigned or removed to avoid the overhead cost during write operations.
However, altering or dropping any of the existing indexes could have negative consequences for queries which specifically reference those indexes in a query hint.

data.name: SDR-I6_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) duplicate indexes found

data.name: SDR-I6_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Duplicate indexes require additional overhead in order to keep the indexes up-to-date along with additional storage space on disk and in memory.

data.name: SDR-I6_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the definition of these indexes to determine whether they should be redesigned or removed to avoid the overhead cost during write operations.
However, altering or dropping any of the existing indexes could have negative consequences for queries which specifically reference those indexes in a query hint.

data.name: SDR-I7_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I7_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9PeSLH

data.name: SDR-I7_Description
data.value: Hypothetical index

data.name: SDR-I7_Finding
data.value: Hypothetical index found on [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)]

data.name: SDR-I7_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Hypothetical index [$(IndexName)] was found on [$(TableName)] of database [$(Database)]. This index was used by Microsoft Index Tuning Wizard, Database Tuning Advisor or SQL doctor during index performance analysis and could not be dropped due to a lock on the table.

data.name: SDR-I7_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you drop the index.

data.name: SDR-I7_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) hypothetical indexes found

data.name: SDR-I7_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The hypothetical indexes were used by Microsoft Index Tuning Wizard, Database Tuning Advisor or SQL doctor during index performance analysis and could not be dropped due to a lock on the table.

data.name: SDR-I7_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you drop the indexes.

data.name: SDR-I8_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I8_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/d0sGg2

data.name: SDR-I8_Description
data.value: Index Consolidation

data.name: SDR-I8_Finding
data.value: Indexes on [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)] could be consolidated

data.name: SDR-I8_Impact_Explanation
data.value:
Index [$(RedundantIndexName)] and index [$(IndexName)] on table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] of database [$(Database)] may be candidates for index consolidation.
Although these indexes do share key columns, they are not identical because there were differences found in either the key columns or INCLUDE columns.

data.name: SDR-I8_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)When modifying data in a table with a nonclustered index, SQL Server incurs additional overhead in order to keep the indexes up-to-date.$(li)Using multiple indexes for the same function requires additional storage space on disk and in memory.$(li)If this overlap is not intentional, then one of these indexes may not be used by any queries.

data.name: SDR-I8_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)The time SQL Server spends updating these indexes may be very small, which would invalidate concerns about a performance overhead for write operations. $(li)These indexes may be relatively small, which would invalidate concerns about their storage or memory footprint. $(li)These indexes may already be optimized to yield maximum performance for particular queries or access patterns (for example, seeking versus scanning).

data.name: SDR-I8_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the definitions of these indexes to determine whether a single index should be created to address the full set of queries currently being covered by [$(RedundantIndexName)] and [$(IndexName)]. If one of these indexes is used for infrequent high priority operations, then consider disabling the index, re-enabling the index by rebuilding it shortly before it is needed, and then disabling the index again after the read operations have been completed.
However, be aware that consolidating these indexes may have undesirable performance impacts. The consolidated index may be larger and may be less optimized to suit your data access patterns. Also, altering or dropping either of the existing indexes could have negative consequences for queries which specifically reference those indexes in a query hint.

data.name: SDR-I8_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) index consolidation opportunities found

data.name: SDR-I8_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Multiple indexes may be candidates for index consolidation. These indexes are not identical, but they do share key columns. This overlap consists of a subset of columns in the same order as those included in another index.

data.name: SDR-I8_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the definitions of these indexes to determine whether a single index should be created to address the full set of queries currently being covered by these multiple separate indexes.
However, be aware that consolidating these indexes may have undesirable performance impacts. The consolidated index may be larger and may be less optimized to suit your data access patterns. Also, altering or dropping either of the existing indexes could have negative consequences for queries which specifically reference those indexes in a query hint.

data.name: SDR-I9_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I9_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bH9cVw

data.name: SDR-I9_Description
data.value: Index experiencing lock contention

data.name: SDR-I9_Finding
data.value: $(IndexName?Index [$(IndexName)] on table:Table) [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)] is experiencing excessive $(ContentionType) lock contention

data.name: SDR-I9_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The $(IndexName?index:table) is experiencing an average wait time of $(FormattedAvgWait) per wait due to lock contention with $(FormattedLockPercent) of the locks experiencing a wait. This can significantly degrade the performance of queries using the $(IndexName?index:table).

data.name: SDR-I9_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you review your applications usage of $(IndexName?index [$(IndexName)]:table [$(TableName)]) to determine if optimizations can be introduced to reduce contention. Note that other SQL doctor recommendations may be available to help remedy this problem.

data.name: SDR-I9_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) objects are experiencing excessive lock contention

data.name: SDR-I9_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: These objects are experiencing a high average wait time per wait due to lock contention. This can significantly degrade the performance of queries using these objects.

data.name: SDR-I9_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you review your application's use of these objects to determine if optimizations can be introduced to reduce contention. Note that other SQL doctor recommendations may be available to help remedy this problem.

data.name: SDR-LR1_Category
data.value: Long Running Jobs

data.name: SDR-LR1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/axXNZZ

data.name: SDR-LR1_Description
data.value: Long running SQL Agent job

data.name: SDR-LR1_Finding
data.value: Job '$(JobName)' ran substantially longer than usual

data.name: SDR-LR1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The last run of job '$(JobName)' ran substantially longer than the prior successful runs. It ran for a total of $(LastRunDurationMinutes) minutes and it normally runs for $(AvgRunDurationMinutes) minutes.

data.name: SDR-LR1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the job be examined for possible problems.

data.name: SDR-LR1_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) jobs ran substantially longer than usual

data.name: SDR-LR1_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The last run of the jobs ran substantially longer than the prior successful runs.

data.name: SDR-LR1_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the job be examined for possible problems.

data.name: SDR-M28_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M28_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9LptAQ

data.name: SDR-M28_Finding
data.value: SQL Server memory is experiencing stress while no CPU problems are detected

data.name: SDR-M28_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A performance bottleneck is being experienced due to page compression settings.

data.name: SDR-M28_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that page compression be turned on for the following large tables which are in your most used databases in terms of I/O usage: Table xxx (xx% and xxMB reduction will be achieved compressing this table), Table xxx (xx% and xxMB reduction will be achieved compressing this table)

data.name: SDR-M28_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-M28_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-M28_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-M1_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bXIagg

data.name: SDR-M1_Description
data.value: The SQL Server User Right “Lock Pages in Memory” is Not Being Used

data.name: SDR-M1_Finding
data.value: The SQL Server user right “Lock Pages in Memory” is not being used

data.name: SDR-M1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Granting the “Lock Pages in Memory” user right to the SQL Server service on a 64-bit system allows SQL Server to manage its memory allocations to ensure that critical data remains in physical memory.

data.name: SDR-M1_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)The right “Lock Pages in Memory” is necessary in order to enable AWE on 32-bit SQL Servers prior to SQL 2012 (SQL 2012 does not support AWE). AWE has no impact on 64-bit systems, but the user right prevents the Windows OS from removing the SQL Server buffer pool from physical memory in order to make room for other applications.$(li)Without this user right granted, the Windows OS can move large portions of the SQL Server buffer pool to disk when other applications request physical memory. $(li)SQL Server performance is degraded significantly when critical data is paged out of physical memory.

data.name: SDR-M1_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)When multiple applications are running on a single server, giving SQL Server the right to “Lock Pages in Memory” without also configuring the maximum server memory setting can result in other applications or the operating system becoming unable to allocate sufficient memory. If it is not possible to configure the maximum server memory for SQL Server, then the “Lock Pages in Memory” right should not be granted. $(li)When multiple applications are running on a single server and have the “Lock Pages in Memory” right, each application should be configured with an upper bound for memory consumption. Essentially, the total system memory should be divided up and portioned to each application including the operating system in order to ensure that none of your essential applications become memory starved. If any of the applications running on the server do not support this configuration, then the “Lock Pages in Memory” right should not be granted.

data.name: SDR-M1_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you review the memory usage of all applications running on the server to determine if it is appropriate to grant the user right “Lock Pages in Memory” to the SQL Server. You should NOT try to set the AWE switch on 64-bit systems as it has no effect.
However, be aware that with “Lock Pages in Memory” granted, the Windows OS will not page SQL Server’s buffer pool out of physical memory in order to reclaim space, which can lead to memory starvation in other applications running on the server. To avoid this situation, you should ensure that the SQL Server configuration option “Max Server Memory” is also configured to set an upper bound which will leave sufficient memory available for the operating system and other applications.
Note: Standard Editions of SQL Server will also require trace flag 845 to be added as a startup parameter so that “Lock Pages in Memory” can be used. Enterprise editions do not need this trace flag.

data.name: SDR-M26_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M26_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bcgT1p

data.name: SDR-M26_Finding
data.value: The Screen Saver is enabled

data.name: SDR-M26_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The screen saver can unnecessarily use resources that should be kept available for SQL Server.

data.name: SDR-M26_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the Screen Saver be set to (none) or blank on a production server to improve performance.

data.name: SDR-M26_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-M26_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-M26_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-M25_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M25_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9WiWK0

data.name: SDR-M25_Finding
data.value: Visual Effects are not adjusted for best performance

data.name: SDR-M25_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Visual Effects consume CPU cycles, extra memory and network bandwidth as most production servers are accessed using Remote Desktop.

data.name: SDR-M25_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that Visual Effects on the Control Panel be set for best performance on production servers.

data.name: SDR-M10_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M10_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/ch3Blq

data.name: SDR-M10_Description
data.value: Non-Essential Applications Detected

data.name: SDR-M10_Finding
data.value: Non-essential applications have been detected running on the server

data.name: SDR-M10_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Non-essential applications compete for resources and degrade performance on your server.

data.name: SDR-M10_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Non-essential applications compete for resources and degrade performance on your server.

data.name: SDR-M10_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)These applications may be configured to have a very low footprint or to yield resources to SQL Server as necessary. $(li)Your business requirements may consider some of these applications essential.

data.name: SDR-M10_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you review these applications to determine if they can be moved to a different server: $(RunningProcesses).

data.name: SDR-M11_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M11_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/8Z0OAR

data.name: SDR-M11_Description
data.value: Server is domain controller

data.name: SDR-M11_Finding
data.value: The server is being used as a domain or a backup controller

data.name: SDR-M11_Impact_Explanation
data.value: During periods of high user validation on the domain, SQL Server performance will degrade.

data.name: SDR-M11_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that production servers should not be used as domain controllers (or backup domain controllers).

data.name: SDR-M22_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M22_bitly

data.name: SDR-M22_Finding
data.value: The Operating System is set to give best performance to the System Cache

data.name: SDR-M22_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SQL Server performance will increase if the setting is changed to Allow best performance of background services.

data.name: SDR-M22_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that a production SQL Server should have the setting set to Allow best performance of background programs. To make sure that memory is not taken away from SQL Server in order to enlarge Operating System cache which will not help SQL Server.

data.name: SDR-M12_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M12_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bomYRC

data.name: SDR-M12_Description
data.value: Maximize data throughput for file sharing setting is enabled

data.name: SDR-M12_Finding
data.value: The ‘Maximize data throughput for file sharing’ setting is enabled

data.name: SDR-M12_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This setting optimizes the Windows server for file and printer sharing resources.

data.name: SDR-M12_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)This setting reduces the amount of memory available for SQL Server by providing additional memory to the file system cache.

data.name: SDR-M12_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)The SQL Server instance is located on a server which is used for file sharing. This setting is useful for servers that typically run the file sharing service.$(li)Additional memory is available for the larger file system cache that is not needed by the SQL Server instance.

data.name: SDR-M12_Recommendation
data.value: You should consider changing this setting to "Maximize data throughput for network applications" if the SQL Server is not located on a file sharing server. This can be changed through Network Local Connection Properties on Windows 2003 production servers.

data.name: SDR-M20_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SQL Server performance will increase if the setting is changed to Allow best performance of background services.

data.name: SDR-M20_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that on high availability SQL Server should have the setting set to Allow best performance of background services.

data.name: SDR-M13_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M13_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/c4DZhD

data.name: SDR-M13_Description
data.value: Low Default Fill Factor

data.name: SDR-M13_Finding
data.value: The server default fill factor is $(FillFactor) which may be contributing to memory pressure

data.name: SDR-M13_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The SQL Server is currently experiencing memory pressure which may be related to the number of partially-filled index pages loaded into memory.

data.name: SDR-M13_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)The server-wide fill factor affects all indexes on the server whenever they are created or rebuilt. Every page of the index will be left partially empty in order to avoid future page splits as the underlying table data is updated. This increases the total size of the index by leaving “air pockets” for future growth. $(li)Because the indexes are larger, they take up more storage in the buffer cache whenever they are being used. This in turn forces other data pages to be moved out of the buffer cache in order to make room for “air pockets.”

data.name: SDR-M13_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)When index page density is high, this indicates that the space left empty due to the fill factor setting has since been filled in due to modifications to the table data, which means that the index pages in the buffer cache are not left partially empty. The next time this index is rebuilt, the data will be redistributed in order to again enforce the fill factor setting. $(li)Increasing the index fill factor will compact the data and save space in memory, but it will also lead to more page splits as the underlying table data is modified. The cost of page splits in your environment may justify the memory contention created by using a low fill factor.

data.name: SDR-M13_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that the server-wide fill factor be increased and the indexes of larger tables be rebuilt in order to reduce memory stress as more data will reside on each 8K page. Additionally, it is possible to control the fill factor for individual indexes when the index is created or rebuilt. This provides more granular control over how much empty space is left in each index so that these settings can be adjusted according to the data access patterns for each table.
However, be aware that increasing the fill factor of an index can lead to more frequent page splits as the data changes. Such page splits always impact SQL Server performance and generate additional transaction log data.

data.name: SDR-M14_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M14_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9yumDA

data.name: SDR-M14_Finding
data.value: The server default fill factor is $(FillFactor) and the number of page splits is small

data.name: SDR-M14_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The number of page splits is small and the fill factor is low.

data.name: SDR-M14_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the fill factor be increased and the indexes of larger tables be re-indexed to reduce I/O usage and to maximize available memory as more data will reside on each 8K page.

data.name: SDR-M15_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M15_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/ayvaZa

data.name: SDR-M15_Description
data.value: High page split count

data.name: SDR-M15_Finding
data.value: SQL Server is experiencing relatively high levels of page splits and its memory is not under stress

data.name: SDR-M15_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Page splits are currently accounting for $(PageSplitAllocationPercentage)% of all new page allocations.

data.name: SDR-M15_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the fill factor be lowered on indexes that are experiencing a high number of page splits. This will result in better insert and update performance.

data.name: SDR-M16_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M16_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9x9nNT

data.name: SDR-M16_Description
data.value: Physical RAM has decreased

data.name: SDR-M16_Finding
data.value: The total amount of physical RAM available on this server has decreased by $(DecreasedBy)

data.name: SDR-M16_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A decrease in physical RAM has a corresponding decrease in system performance.

data.name: SDR-M16_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the cause of the decrease in physical RAM on this server be determined and fixed to improve performance. There are several possible causes: $(li)One of your memory modules has failed or become unseated. $(li)Changes either to the BIOS version or on the BIOS have allocated some of the shared memory to another resource (such as video RAM).$(li)If this is a virtual machine then changes to the VM have excluded memory to this VM.$(li)If this server is part of a cluster then a failover may have occurred onto a machine with less physical RAM

data.name: SDR-M17_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M17_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9uzhuu

data.name: SDR-M17_Description
data.value: Max Server Memory Setting has been Reduced

data.name: SDR-M17_Finding
data.value: The max server memory setting has been reduced since the last analysis

data.name: SDR-M17_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The SQL Server is experiencing memory pressure, and the most recent analysis shows that the max server memory setting has been reduced from previous values.

data.name: SDR-M17_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)SQL Server is experiencing memory pressure, which may be directly linked to having less memory available.

data.name: SDR-M17_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)It may be necessary to lower the max server memory setting to prevent SQL Server from consuming all available resources and starving other applications or even the operating system.

data.name: SDR-M17_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you review recent changes to the SQL Server max server memory setting to determine if those changes may be causing the current memory pressure.

data.name: SDR-M18_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M18_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cSsoJ3

data.name: SDR-M18_Description
data.value: Non-default "Max concurrent user connections"

data.name: SDR-M18_Finding
data.value: The Max Concurrent User Connections setting is not set to the default of “0”

data.name: SDR-M18_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The default setting dynamically allocates memory for connection as needed. Each connection requires ~100KB Ram, which means that your setting of $(UserConnections) is reserving $(MemoryEstimate) of memory to be continuously allocated to connections.

data.name: SDR-M18_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you set the Max Concurrent User Connections setting to the default of “0” to allow SQL Server to use free memory to store additional data/index pages or additional query plans.

data.name: SDR-M19_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M19_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aPn5sR

data.name: SDR-M19_Description
data.value: Non-default "Index creation memory"

data.name: SDR-M19_Finding
data.value: The Index Creation Memory option is not set to the default of “0”

data.name: SDR-M19_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The Index Creation Memory option is currently set to $(MemoryInKB) KB. This setting dynamically allocates the memory index creation as it is needed.

data.name: SDR-M19_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the Index Creation Memory option be set to the default of “0” unless very large tables are being indexed as this memory is permanently allocated and cannot be shared by either the buffer pool or procedure cache.

data.name: SDR-M2_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M2_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bNRKeQ

data.name: SDR-M2_Description
data.value: Memory Configuration Not Optimized: 16GB+ RAM

data.name: SDR-M2_Finding
data.value: Memory configuration settings are not set for the best performance of a 32-bit SQL Server with 16GB or more of RAM

data.name: SDR-M2_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Memory options for ‘Physical Address Extension,’ ‘3GB,’ ‘USERVA,’ ‘Address Windowing Extensions,’ and ‘Lock Pages in Memory’ are not configured correctly for optimal performance of a 32-bit SQL Server with 16GB or more of RAM.

data.name: SDR-M2_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Physical Address Extension (PAE) is a feature of the processor that allows access to more than 4GB of physical memory. Without this enabled, the additional physical memory cannot be accessed on a 32-bit system. $(li)The /3GB switch will allot 3GB of virtual address space to user mode processes and 1GB of virtual address space to the operating system. When you limit the operating system to only 1GB, you limit the amount of physical memory that can be managed by the operating system to only 16GB. Because this server has 16GB or more of memory, do not set the /3GB switch to limit the operating system to only 1GB.$(li)Address Windowing Extensions (AWE) on a 32-bit SQL Server will allow for SQL Server to access physical memory greater than 4GB. Because this server has 16GB or more of memory, AWE will allow the 32-bit SQL Server process to access to the additional memory. $(li)The ‘Lock Pages in Memory’ user right must be assigned to the user account that the SQL Server process is executed under. This right is assigned by default to the ‘Local System’ account. Without the ‘Lock Pages in Memory’ user right, AWE cannot be used by the SQL Server process.

data.name: SDR-M2_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)There may be a specific requirement for the server to have one or more of these configuration options set. This could be the requirement of third-party applications or the result of extensive performance tuning relating specifically to memory allocation and management. $(li)In an environment where multiple SQL Server instances are on the same server, or in a clustered environment when multiple SQL Server instances can be active on the same clustered node, consideration should be given to the memory usage of each instance.

data.name: SDR-M2_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended you implement all of the following recommendations on 32-bit SQL Servers that have 16GB or more of RAM: $(li)Enable Physical Address Extensions (/PAE) in the startup configuration $(li)Disable /3GB in the startup configuration $(li)Enable Address Windowing Extensions (AWE) in the SQL Server configuration $(li)Enable the SQL Server advanced user right lock pages in memory
However, extra steps should be taken to verify the current configuration is not required. The recommended configuration is very specific to a 32-bit SQL Server with 16GB or more of physical memory. If the amount of physical memory has been changed on the system, these settings must be verified again to ensure optimum performance of both the operating system and applications.

data.name: SDR-M21_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M21_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/91AWUg

data.name: SDR-M21_Description
data.value: OS optimized for foreground applications

data.name: SDR-M21_Finding
data.value: The Operating System is set to give best performance to foreground applications

data.name: SDR-M21_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SQL Server performance will increase if the setting is changed to 'Allow best performance of background services'.

data.name: SDR-M21_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that your Operating System should have the setting set to 'Allow best performance of background services' to improve SQL Server performance.

data.name: SDR-M23_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M23_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9UAeS2

data.name: SDR-M23_Finding
data.value: The Operating System is set to give best performance to the System Cache

data.name: SDR-M23_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This setting enlarges the system cache at the expense of giving SQL Server extra memory for data or index pages as well as procedure plans.

data.name: SDR-M23_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the Operating System should have the Memory Usage adjusted for 'best performance of programs' to increase performance.

data.name: SDR-M9_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M9_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bwtmh8

data.name: SDR-M9_Finding
data.value: The production server has more than one SQL Server instance running

data.name: SDR-M9_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SQL Server instances compete for resources (CPU, Memory and I/O) potentially degrading performance.

data.name: SDR-M9_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that on high availability production servers, only one instance of SQL Server should be running.

data.name: SDR-M9_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-M9_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-M9_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-M24_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M24_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aO7KPX

data.name: SDR-M24_Description
data.value: Need to optimize for ad-hoc workloads

data.name: SDR-M24_Finding
data.value: Single use Ad-hoc plans are using $(AdhocCacheSizeFormatted) of procedure cache

data.name: SDR-M24_Impact_Explanation
data.value: These plans consume storage that can be better utilized by other plans or data pages.

data.name: SDR-M24_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the 'Optimize For Ad-Hoc Workloads' setting should be used.

data.name: SDR-M27_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M27_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/b0FKxx

data.name: SDR-M27_Description
data.value: Paging detected

data.name: SDR-M27_Finding
data.value: Your Server is currently paging at $(PagesPerSec) pages per second

data.name: SDR-M27_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This is putting a strain on both the processor and I/O subsystems and significantly slowing response times.

data.name: SDR-M27_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that physical page faults be kept to a minimum. The list below contains the 10 processes which are currently consuming the greatest amount of total memory on your Server: $(Processes).

data.name: SDR-M29_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M29_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aD6kth

data.name: SDR-M29_Description
data.value: SQL Server memory limit reached

data.name: SDR-M29_Finding
data.value: The SQL Server memory limit has been exceeded while generating an execution plan

data.name: SDR-M29_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The creation of an execution plan caused the SQL Server memory limit to be exceeded. The execution plan generated is still correct, but it may not be optimal.

data.name: SDR-M29_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you try one of the following methods to increase available memory: $(br)1. Reduce the load on the server $(br)2. Increase memory available to SQL Server $(br)3. Check the max server memory option that is set with sp_configure and increase the value if it is too low

data.name: SDR-M3_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M3_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/a9WU82

data.name: SDR-M3_Description
data.value: Memory Configuration Not Optimized: 4-16GB RAM

data.name: SDR-M3_Finding
data.value: Memory configuration settings are not set for best performance of a 32-bit SQL Server with greater than 4GB and less than 16GB of RAM

data.name: SDR-M3_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Memory options for ‘Physical Address Extension,’ ‘3GB,’ ‘USERVA,’ and ‘Address Windowing Extensions’ are not configured correctly for optimal performance of a 32-bit SQL Server with greater than 4GB and less than 16GB of RAM.

data.name: SDR-M3_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Physical Address Extension (PAE) is a feature of the processor that allows access to more than 4GB of physical memory. Without this enabled, the additional physical memory cannot be accessed on a 32-bit system. $(li)The /3GB switch will allot 3GB of virtual address space to user mode processes and 1GB of virtual address space to the operating system. When you limit the operating system to only 1GB, you limit the amount of physical memory that can be managed by the operating system to only 16GB. Because this server has between 4GB and 16GB of physical memory, the /3GB switch should be set to limit the operating system to only 1GB.$(li)Address Windowing Extensions (AWE) on a 32-bit SQL Server will allow for SQL Server to access physical memory greater than 4GB. Because this server has more than 4GB of memory, AWE will allow the 32-bit SQL Server process to access to this memory. $(li)The ‘Lock Pages in Memory’ user right must be assigned to the user account that the SQL Server process is executed under. This right is assigned by default to the ‘Local System’ account. Without the ‘Lock Pages in Memory’ user right, AWE cannot be used by the SQL Server process.

data.name: SDR-M3_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)There may be a specific requirement for the server to have one or more of these configuration options set. This could be the requirement of third-party applications or the result of extensive performance tuning relating specifically to memory allocation and management.

data.name: SDR-M3_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended you implement all of the following recommendations on 32-bit SQL Servers that have greater than 4GB and less than 16GB of RAM: $(li)Enable Physical Address Extensions (/PAE) in the startup configuration $(li)Enable /3GB in the startup configuration $(li)Enable Address Windowing Extensions (AWE) in the SQL Server configuration $(li)Enable the SQL Server advanced user right lock pages in memory
However, extra steps should be taken to verify the current configuration is not required. The recommended configuration is very specific to a 32-bit SQL Server with greater than 4GB and less than 16GB of physical memory. If the amount of physical memory has been changed on the system, these settings must be verified again to ensure optimum performance of both the operating system and applications.

data.name: SDR-M4_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M4_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9igrOB

data.name: SDR-M4_Description
data.value: Memory Configuration Not Optimized: 4GB RAM

data.name: SDR-M4_Finding
data.value: Memory configuration settings are not set for best performance for a 32-bit SQL Server with 4GB of RAM

data.name: SDR-M4_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Memory options for ‘Physical Address Extension,’ ‘3GB,’ ‘USERVA,’ and ‘Address Windowing Extensions’ are not configured correctly for optimal performance of a 32-bit SQL Server with 4GB of RAM.

data.name: SDR-M4_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Physical Address Extension (PAE) is a feature of the processor that allows access to more than 4GB of physical memory. This feature will not help the performance of SQL Server when the system has 4GB or less of physical memory. $(li)The /3GB switch will allot 3GB of virtual address space to user mode processes and 1GB of virtual address space to the operating system. When you limit the operating system to only 1GB, you limit the amount of physical memory that can be managed by the operating system to only 16GB. Because this server has 4GB of physical memory, the /3GB switch should be set to limit the operating system to only 1GB and allow 3GB for user mode processes.$(li)Address Windowing Extensions (AWE) on a 32-bit SQL Server will allow for SQL Server to access physical memory greater than 4GB. Because this server has 4GB of memory, AWE is not needed.

data.name: SDR-M4_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)There may be a specific requirement for the server to have one or more of these configuration options set. This could be the requirement of third-party applications or the result of extensive performance tuning relating specifically to memory allocation and management.

data.name: SDR-M4_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended you implement all of the following recommendations on 32-bit SQL Servers that have 4GB of RAM: $(li)Disable Physical Address Extensions (/PAE) in the startup configuration $(li)Enable /3GB in the startup configuration $(li)Disable Address Windowing Extensions (AWE) in the SQL Server configuration
However, extra steps should be taken to verify the current configuration is not required. The recommended configuration is very specific to a 32-bit SQL Server with 4GB of physical memory. If the amount of physical memory has been changed on the system, these settings must be verified again to ensure optimum performance of both the operating system and applications.

data.name: SDR-M5_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M5_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aOT72F

data.name: SDR-M5_Description
data.value: Memory Configuration Not Optimized: 3-4GB RAM

data.name: SDR-M5_Finding
data.value: Memory configuration settings are not set for best performance of a 32-bit SQL Server with greater than 3GB and less than 4GB of RAM

data.name: SDR-M5_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Memory options for ‘Physical Address Extension,’ ‘3GB,’ and ‘Address Windowing Extensions’ are not configured correctly for optimal performance of a 32-bit SQL Server with greater than 3GB and less than 4GB of RAM.

data.name: SDR-M5_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Physical Address Extension (PAE) is a feature of the processor that allows access to more than 4GB of physical memory. This feature will not help the performance of SQL Server when the system has less than 4GB of physical memory. $(li)The /3GB switch will allot 3GB of virtual address space to user mode processes and 1GB of virtual address space to the operating system. When you limit the operating system to only 1GB, you limit the amount of physical memory that can be managed by the operating system to only 16GB. Because this server has enough physical memory, the /3GB switch should be set to limit the operating system to only 1GB and allow 3GB for user mode processes. $(li)The /USERVA switch will allow for a more precise tuning of user and kernel virtual memory space. This switch in combination with the /3GB switch will allow for fine tuning the user mode space to a value between 2GB and 3GB. Because this server has between 3GB and 4GB of physical memory, precise tuning of the space available to user mode processes should be considered.$(li)Address Windowing Extensions (AWE) on a 32-bit SQL Server will allow for SQL Server to access physical memory greater than 4GB. Because this server has less than 4GB of memory, AWE is not needed.

data.name: SDR-M5_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)There may be a specific requirement for the server to have one or more of these configuration options set. This could be the requirement of third-party applications or the result of extensive performance tuning relating specifically to memory allocation and management.

data.name: SDR-M5_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended you implement all of the following recommendations on 32-bit SQL Servers that have greater than 3GB and less than 4GB of RAM: $(li)Disable Physical Address Extensions (/PAE) in the startup configuration $(li)Enable /3GB in the startup configuration $(li)Disable Address Windowing Extensions (AWE) in the SQL Server configuration
However, extra steps should be taken to verify the current configuration is not required. The recommended configuration is very specific to a 32-bit SQL Server with greater than 3GB and less than 4GB of physical memory. If the amount of physical memory has been changed on the system, these settings must be verified again to ensure optimum performance of both the operating system and applications.
