data.value: Memory Configuration Not Optimized: <3GB RAM

data.name: SDR-M6_Finding
data.value: Memory configuration settings are not set for best performance of a 32-bit SQL Server with 3GB or less RAM

data.name: SDR-M6_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Memory options for ‘Physical Address Extension,’ ‘3GB,’ ‘USERVA,’ and ‘Address Windowing Extensions’ are not configured correctly for optimal performance of a 32-bit SQL Server with 3GB or less of RAM.

data.name: SDR-M6_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Physical Address Extension (PAE) is a feature of the processor that allows access to more than 4GB of physical memory. This feature will not help the performance of SQL Server when the system has 3GB or less of physical memory. $(li)The /3GB switch will allot 3GB of virtual address space to user mode processes and 1GB of virtual address space to the operating system. Because there is not enough physical memory available to account for larger user mode and allotted operating system address space, the SQL Server process performance could be hindered by excessive memory paging to when supporting the additional memory requirements. $(li)The /USERVA switch will allow for a more precise tuning of user and kernel virtual memory space. This switch in combination with the /3GB switch will allow for fine tuning the user mode space to a value between 2GB and 3GB. Because there is not enough physical memory available to account for larger user mode and allotted operating system address space, the SQL Server process performance could be hindered by excessive memory paging to when supporting the additional memory requirements.$(li)Address Windowing Extensions (AWE) on a 32-bit SQL Server will allow for SQL Server to access physical memory greater than 4GB. Because this server has 3GB or less of memory, AWE is not needed.

data.name: SDR-M6_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)There may be a specific requirement for the server to have one or more of these configuration options set. This could be the requirement of third-party applications or the result of extensive performance tuning relating specifically to memory allocation and management.

data.name: SDR-M6_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that the following settings be used on 32-bit SQL Servers with 3GB or less RAM: $(li)Disable Physical Address Extensions (/PAE), /3GB, and /USERVA in the startup configuration $(li)Disable Address Windowing Extensions (AWE) in the SQL Server configuration
However, extra steps should be taken to verify the current configuration is not required. There are configurations which make use of SQLCLR, Extended Stored Procedures, OLE Automation, linked servers, or other heavy MemToLeave users where it may be necessary to use the /3GB switch in conjunction with the –g startup parameter to the SQL Server process.
This recommendation is very specific to a 32-bit SQL Server with 3GB or less of physical memory. If the amount of physical memory has been changed on the system, these settings must be verified again to ensure optimum performance of both the operating system and applications.

data.name: SDR-M7_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M7_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9qGa6O

data.name: SDR-M7_Description
data.value: Memory contention

data.name: SDR-M7_Finding
data.value: The SQL Server instance is experiencing memory stress

data.name: SDR-M7_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The SQL Server instance is experiencing at least some memory stress that could be relieved due to one or more of the following conditions: $(li)1. Page Life Expectancy of less than 5 minutes. $(li)2. Buffer Cache Hit Ratio of less than 95% $(li)3. Memory Grants Pending has remained about 10 on average over a 5 minute period.

data.name: SDR-M7_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the Max Server Memory option in SQL Server which is currently set to $(MaxServerMemory) be set to $(SuggestedMaxServerMemory) or set back to the default of 2147483647 to allow SQL Server to dynamically adjust this value as needed.

data.name: SDR-M30_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M30_Description
data.value: Available memory not used

data.name: SDR-M30_Finding
data.value: This version of SQL Server will not use all of the availble memory

data.name: SDR-M30_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The system has $(ServerMemory)gigs of memory availble which cannot be accessed by the 32-bit version of SQL Server. To access more than 4gigs of RAM, 32-bit Address Windowing Extensions (AWE) must be used which is no longer supported in SQL Server.

data.name: SDR-M30_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that a 64-bit Operating System and hardware be used to allow access to more memory.

data.name: SDR-M8_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M8_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9rZPq1

data.name: SDR-M8_Description
data.value: System paging

data.name: SDR-M8_Finding
data.value: The system is paging excessively

data.name: SDR-M8_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Your system is paging at a rate of $(PagesPerSec) pages per second and the SQL Server instance is configured with a high ‘Min Server Memory’ setting.

data.name: SDR-M8_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)SQL Server will not release memory if it will be less than the ‘Min Server Memory’ setting. This can cause additional memory pressure on the server and require the operating system to page out SQL Server memory.$(li)If ‘Lock pages in memory’ is used by SQL Server, a high ‘Min Server Memory’ setting can starve the operating system of physical memory by preventing the operating system from paging out the memory allocated to SQL Server.

data.name: SDR-M8_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If the performance implications of the ‘Min Server Memory’ setting are understood and acceptable for the SQL Server instance.

data.name: SDR-M8_Recommendation
data.value: You should consider setting the ‘Min Server Memory’ configuration value to zero. This will provide SQL Server with the needed flexibility to properly manage the memory requirements of the SQL Server instance.

data.name: SDR-N1_Category
data.value: Network

data.name: SDR-N1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/8ZLb0k

data.name: SDR-N1_Description
data.value: Failed network card

data.name: SDR-N1_Finding
data.value: One or more network cards have stopped working

data.name: SDR-N1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: In a previous analysis $(PreviousCards) network cards were detected with a total bandwidth of $(PreviousBandwidthMB) MB/s. In the current analysis $(Cards) network cards with a total bandwidth of $(BandwidthMB) MB/s were found (representing a $(BandwidthLost)% reduction in capacity).

data.name: SDR-N1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the Network cards be examined to determine which are having problems. Either a network card has stopped working or been unplugged either on the card or network switch or the network cable/fiber is faulty or another server is being used or a failover has occurred on a cluster to a server with lesser network capability.

data.name: SDR-N2_Category
data.value: Network

data.name: SDR-N2_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9zFqUa

data.name: SDR-N2_Description
data.value: Reduced network bandwidth

data.name: SDR-N2_Finding
data.value: The server has lost network bandwidth

data.name: SDR-N2_Impact_Explanation
data.value: In a previous analysis, the total active bandwidth was $(PreviousBandwidthMB) MB/s and it is now $(BandwidthMB) MB/s representing a $(BandwidthLost)% reduction.

data.name: SDR-N2_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you check the following: $(br)1. Have you exchanged your network card recently with a lower bandwidth card? $(br)2. Has a network driver BIOS change been made? $(br)3. Has the "teaming" between network cards changed? $(br)4. Are there hardware/cable/fiber errors preventing a card from operating at full potential? $(br)5. Has a failover occurred on a cluster to a server with a less capable card?

data.name: SDR-N6_Category
data.value: Network

data.name: SDR-N6_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9Eleuj

data.name: SDR-N6_Finding
data.value: Network encryption has been turned on by default

data.name: SDR-N6_Impact_Explanation
data.value: There are high security environments where network encryption is required. It is important to note that encryption and decryption of network transmission streams places additional CPU load on the server as well as double the number of network transmissions during each connection made.

data.name: SDR-N6_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that, if the network transmission encryption is not necessary, network encryption be disabled.

data.name: SDR-N3_Category
data.value: Network

data.name: SDR-N3_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/90sWu3

data.name: SDR-N3_Description
data.value: Non-SQL Server network load

data.name: SDR-N3_Finding
data.value: Significant non-SQL Server network load

data.name: SDR-N3_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SQL Server is generating only $(SqlNetworkLoad)% of the network load on your production server while $(NonSqlNetworkLoad)% is being generated by non-SQL Server processes and your network is under stress.

data.name: SDR-N3_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that non-essential applications be stopped on production servers.

data.name: SDR-N4_Category
data.value: Network

data.name: SDR-N4_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cP2PpO

data.name: SDR-N4_Description
data.value: TCP segments being retransmitted

data.name: SDR-N4_Finding
data.value: High number of TCP segments are being retransmitted

data.name: SDR-N4_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The number of TCP segments being retransmitted is $(SegmentsRetransmittedPerSec). This represents $(SegmentsRetransmittedPercent)% of the total. TCP segments are typically retransmitted either due to the lack of timely acknowledgement or when segments are being acknowledged out of sequence. A high level of retransmissions will significantly slow SQL Server.

data.name: SDR-N4_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you check the following for the following problems: 1. Either the network card in the server or the network switch is highly congested. 2. There is a cabling problem between the network card and switch. 3. There are intermittent hardware faults in the NIC or switch. 4. There is a firmware problem. 5. There is an issue with the firewall.

data.name: SDR-N5_Category
data.value: Network

data.name: SDR-N5_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cmY6ba

data.name: SDR-N5_Description
data.value: Network errors

data.name: SDR-N5_Finding
data.value: The network redirector is experiencing $(Errors) errors

data.name: SDR-N5_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Such network redirect errors generally indicate that the redirector and one or more servers are having serious communication difficulties. For example, a Server Message Block protocol error generates a network error.

data.name: SDR-N5_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the errors which are written to the system event log should be closely scrutinized as the log entries will give further details.

data.name: SDR-N7_Category
data.value: Network

data.name: SDR-N7_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cyNu82

data.name: SDR-N7_Description
data.value: SET NOCOUNT ON Not Being Used

data.name: SDR-N7_Finding
data.value: The SET NOCOUNT ON connection option is not being used

data.name: SDR-N7_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The default ‘nocount on’ option is not being used and a sample of the text of the T-SQL being executed by SQL Server shows that in most cases the SET NOCOUNT ON statement is not being included.

data.name: SDR-N7_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)This causes additional network traffic as packets containing the number of rows affected are being transmitted back to the clients for many of the T-SQL statements being executed.

data.name: SDR-N7_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)Some third-party applications require the rows affected message and will experience unexpected results or errors when these messages are not returned.

data.name: SDR-N7_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you change SET NOCOUNT to ON for the default network setting on your SQL Server instance. Alternatively, you can modify T-SQL batches, stored procedures, etc. to include the option SET NOCOUNT ON which will only affect that one batch. This will reduce network traffic for connections executing that batch without affecting all connections coming into the SQL Server.
However, some ActiveX Data Objects (ADO) functions rely on row count information and may return unexpected results or errors when SET NOCOUNT is ON. If applications in your environment use ADO to communicate with SQL Server, they may be negatively impacted by this setting.

data.name: SDR-N8_Category
data.value: Network

data.name: SDR-N8_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bZzOem

data.name: SDR-N8_Description
data.value: Multiple network cards recommended

data.name: SDR-N8_Finding
data.value: Multiple active cards are not being used in either a teamed or un-teamed mode

data.name: SDR-N8_Impact_Explanation
data.value: It is a suggested best practice that for mission critical servers either 2 redundant network cards are used on the server or 2 network cards are “teamed” to provide both network redundancy and increased performance (via load balancing).

data.name: SDR-N8_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that one or more additional network cards should be added for both redundancy and performance.

data.name: SDR-N9_Category
data.value: Network

data.name: SDR-N9_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/asUP0Z

data.name: SDR-N9_Description
data.value: Network card errors

data.name: SDR-N9_Finding
data.value: Network errors detected

data.name: SDR-N9_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The network card $(Name) has given $(Errors) errors within the analysis period.

data.name: SDR-N9_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you check the following: $(br)1. The network card in the server or the network switch/hub is highly congested. $(br)2. The cabling between the network card and the switch/hub is faulty/sub-standard. $(br)3. The network card or switch/hub is giving intermittent hardware faults. $(br)4. The firmware installed on either the network card and/or the switch/hub has bugs. $(br)5. A problem or bug in the firewall hardware or software.

data.name: SDR-OT1_Category
data.value: Open Transactions

data.name: SDR-OT1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/dzmSXJ

data.name: SDR-OT1_Description
data.value: Long running open transaction

data.name: SDR-OT1_Finding
data.value: Process $(SPID) has an open transaction for $(DurationMinutes) minutes

data.name: SDR-OT1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Long running transactions prevent transaction logs from being offloaded or truncated and can result in uncontrolled growth of the transaction log file as only the committed portion of the transaction log can be offloaded/truncated. Details are: $(ApplicationName?on $(ApplicationName): ) $(Database?in [$(Database)]: ) $(HostName?submitted from $(HostName): ) $(UserName?by $(UserName): )

data.name: SDR-OT1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you examine the T-SQL running via the open transaction to determine if its runtime could be reduced.

data.name: SDR-OT1_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) Processes have long-running open transactions

data.name: SDR-OT1_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Long running transactions prevent transaction logs from being offloaded or truncated and can result in uncontrolled growth of the transaction log file as only the committed portion of the transaction log can be offloaded/truncated.

data.name: SDR-P1_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cjQauo

data.name: SDR-P1_Description
data.value: Affinity mask set

data.name: SDR-P1_Finding
data.value: The affinity mask setting is limiting the available CPU cores

data.name: SDR-P1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Only $(AllowedToUseCpuCount) out of $(TotalCpuCount) CPU cores can be used by the SQL Server instance.

data.name: SDR-P1_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Limiting the number of CPU cores available to SQL Server will limit the number of ONLINE Schedulers that are available to process requests. This will limit the number of requests that can be concurrently processed and therefore increases the amount of work for each of the CPU cores available to SQL Server.

data.name: SDR-P1_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)The CPU cores are intentionally limited to allow other SQL Server instances or applications to utilize the CPU cores not available to this SQL Server instance.

data.name: SDR-P1_Recommendation
data.value:
The affinity mask setting should be reviewed to ensure the correct number of CPU cores is available for this SQL Server instance. Because the CPU was under stress, you should consider increasing the number of CPU cores for this SQL Server instance to improve overall performance.
However, before making any changes you should understand the exact reason why the affinity mask was set for this SQL Server instance. This is an advanced configuration setting that should be changed only when all application requirements and hardware configurations for this server have been taken into account.

data.name: SDR-P10_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P10_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9P2pta

data.name: SDR-P10_Description
data.value: Multiple SQL Server instances

data.name: SDR-P10_Finding
data.value: More than one SQL Server instance has been detected on your production server

data.name: SDR-P10_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A production server consuming significant CPU resources should not share its CPU and memory resources with other SQL Server instances. This practice leads to highly variable response times. There are currently $(Count) SQL Server instances running on your server.

data.name: SDR-P10_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that production servers consuming significant CPU resources should not share CPU and memory resources with any other SQL Server instances. This practice leads to highly variable response times. $(br)If you do need to run a number of other instances on a production server, then either CPU affinity should be used to guarantee CPU exclusivity for production instances or the priority of those other instances should be set to “below-normal” (or at least below the priority of the production SQL Server instance) in order to make sure that they have as little impact on the production instance as possible. In addition, it is recommended that in cases where secondary SQL Server instances must be used that you configure the Max Memory for the secondary instances to prevent them from consuming more memory than necessary.

data.name: SDR-P9_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P9_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cvcIqD

data.name: SDR-P9_Finding
data.value: Xxx of your tables have the primary key encrypted

data.name: SDR-P9_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This is an inefficient method of encryption when secondary indexes exist on those same tables. Secondary indexes point to the primary key (if present) on a table and therefore encrypting the primary key makes these indexes (and the primary key itself) far less efficient during joins and other operations.

data.name: SDR-P9_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the primary key on tables with secondary indexes not be encrypted. If data has been properly normalized the key is typically not something secret enough to have to be encrypted. Only the columns that contain vital information should be encrypted.

data.name: SDR-P9_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-P9_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-P9_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-P22_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P22_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9w2K6G

data.name: SDR-P22_Finding
data.value: The Screen Saver is enabled

data.name: SDR-P22_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The screen saver can unnecessarily use resources that should be kept available for SQL Server.

data.name: SDR-P22_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the Screen Saver be set to (none) or blank on a production server to improve performance.

data.name: SDR-P22_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-P22_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-P22_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-P11_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P11_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9qoqcb

data.name: SDR-P11_Finding
data.value: The system is experiencing $(ContextSwitches) context switches per second

data.name: SDR-P11_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The system is in privileged mode $(PrivilegedTime)% of the time and cannot execute user threads. SQL Server uses these user threads to respond to T-SQL requests. SQL Server is currently running $(ThreadCount) threads which in turn causes many context switches to occur.

data.name: SDR-P11_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that SQL Server instances that operate with a large number of threads be switched to use lightweight fiber mode scheduling which eliminates context switches and reduces the time the system spends in privileged mode. It is important to note that certain components like SQLMXL, SQLMail, SQLCLR and even SQL doctor may not work or may work erratically.

data.name: SDR-P12_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P12_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/8Z5Mu1

data.name: SDR-P12_Finding
data.value: Network encryption is being used for $(EncryptedConnections) $(EncryptedConnections>1?connections:connection)

data.name: SDR-P12_Impact_Explanation
data.value: There are high security environments where network encryption is required. It is important to note that encryption and decryption of network transmission streams places additional CPU load on the server as well as double the number of network transmissions during each connection made.

data.name: SDR-P12_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that, if the network transmission encryption is not necessary, it should be disabled.

data.name: SDR-P13_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P13_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9HMtXI

data.name: SDR-P13_Description
data.value: Network card causing processor interrupts

data.name: SDR-P13_Finding
data.value: Your network card appears to be causing a high rate of processor interrupts

data.name: SDR-P13_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The number of processor interrupts should not be higher than a ratio of 1:4 when compared to the total activity exhibited by the network subsystem, I/O subsystem as well as other device activity (after subtracting the hardware interrupts generated by the system clock). Your server has a ratio of $(DeviceReqPerInterrupt) device requests for each interrupt which is causing your processor(s) to spend $(PercentInterruptTime)% of its time handling interrupts. Modern disk and network controllers give a ratio of 1:4-5 device requests per interrupt using a combination of interrupt modulation and interrupt avoidance.

data.name: SDR-P13_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you upgrade the drivers (and possibly the firmware) of your network cards, disk I/O subsystem and even the server’s mouse (if one is physically attached). If you have recently upgraded drivers and firmware, review the technical bulletins regularly issued by manufactures for possible errors and associated fixes. In certain cases the physical device or PCI card or cabling may be intermittently malfunctioning at the hardware level. This may be reported in the System event log which you should examine. $(Cards.Count>0?:There is a queue forming behind network device $(Cards), which indicates that the device would be the first place to start checking.

data.name: SDR-P14_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P14_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/abo05p

data.name: SDR-P14_Description
data.value: Disk I/O causing processor interrupts

data.name: SDR-P14_Finding
data.value: Your disk I/O subsystem appears to be causing a high rate of processor interrupts

data.name: SDR-P14_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The number of processor interrupts should not be higher than a ratio of 1:4 when compared to the total activity exhibited by the network subsystem, I/O subsystem as well as other device activity (after subtracting the hardware interrupts generated by the system clock). Your server has a ratio of $(DeviceReqPerInterrupt) device requests for each interrupt which is causing your processor(s) to spend $(PercentInterruptTime)% of its time handling interrupts. Modern disk and network controllers give a ratio of 1:4-5 device requests per interrupt using a combination of interrupt modulation and interrupt avoidance.

data.name: SDR-P14_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you upgrade the drivers (and possibly the firmware) of your network cards, disk I/O subsystem and even the server’s mouse (if one is physically attached). If you have recently upgraded drivers and firmware, review the technical bulletins regularly issued by manufactures for possible errors and associated fixes. In certain cases the physical device or PCI card or cabling may be intermittently malfunctioning at the hardware level. This may be reported in the System event log which you should examine. In addition, a queue has been detected forming behind disk device $(Disks). This device could be the cause of the interrupts and should be checked first.

data.name: SDR-P15_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P15_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9VsomP

data.name: SDR-P15_Description
data.value: Server experiencing processor interrupts

data.name: SDR-P15_Finding
data.value: Your server is currently experiencing a high rate of processor interrupts per second

data.name: SDR-P15_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The number of processor interrupts should not be higher than a ratio of 1:4 when compared to the total activity exhibited by the network subsystem, I/O subsystem as well as other device activity (after subtracting the hardware interrupts generated by the system clock). Your server has a ratio of $(DeviceReqPerInterrupt) device requests for each interrupt which is causing your processor(s) to spend $(PercentInterruptTime)% of its time handling interrupts. Modern disk and network controllers give a ratio of 1:4-5 device requests per interrupt using a combination of interrupt modulation and interrupt avoidance.

data.name: SDR-P15_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you upgrade the drivers (and possibly the firmware) of your network cards, disk I/O subsystem and even the server’s mouse (if one is physically attached). If you have recently upgraded drivers and firmware, review the technical bulletins regularly issued by manufactures for possible errors and associated fixes. In certain cases the physical device or PCI card or cabling may be intermittently malfunctioning at the hardware level. This may be reported in the System event log which you should examine. In addition, a queue has not been detected forming behind any specific device. All devices should be examined (network, I/O, and mouse).

data.name: SDR-P16_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P16_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/dkubSO

data.name: SDR-P16_Description
data.value: Bitlocker drive encryption detected

data.name: SDR-P16_Finding
data.value: Bitlocker drive encryption has been detected on $(DriveLetter)

data.name: SDR-P16_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Drive $(DriveLetter) is used for SQL Server data files, log files, or the system page file.

data.name: SDR-P16_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Volume encryption will require additional CPU processing to perform the encryption. This could have a significant impact on performance when used for heavily accessed drives, such as the drives hosting SQL Server data files, log files, or the server’s page file.

data.name: SDR-P16_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If the additional resource usage overhead required by the encryption algorithm is acceptable.$(li)If volume level encryption is required for the volumes hosting the SQL Server data files, log files, or the system page file.

data.name: SDR-P16_Recommendation
data.value:
You should consider the performance implications of enabling Bitlocker drive encryption on volumes hosting the SQL Server data files, log files, or the system page file.
As an alternative, Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) could be used to encrypt all files and filegroups for specific databases. This will generally provide better performance than using Bitlocker drive encryption.

data.name: SDR-P16_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: Bitlocker drive encryption has been detected on $(Count) drives

data.name: SDR-P16_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The drives are used for SQL Server data files, log files, or the system page file.

data.name: SDR-P16_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
You should consider the performance implications of enabling Bitlocker drive encryption on volumes hosting the SQL Server data files, log files, or the system page file.
As an alternative, Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) could be used to encrypt all files and filegroups for specific databases. This will generally provide better performance than using Bitlocker drive encryption.

data.name: SDR-P17_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P17_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9JY969

data.name: SDR-P17_Finding
data.value: C2 auditing is enabled on your production server

data.name: SDR-P17_Impact_Explanation
data.value: C2 auditing on a production server will degrade performance by increasing the workload of processors and the I/O subsystem significantly when writing all successful and failed logging events.

data.name: SDR-P17_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that C2 auditing be disabled and that correct user access permissions be applied to SQL Server and its associated objects. A restart is required for this change to take effect.

data.name: SDR-P18_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P18_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/co89QH

data.name: SDR-P18_Finding
data.value: Your production server is operating within a virtual machine

data.name: SDR-P18_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Having a SQL Server instance reside within a Virtual Machine can limit performance.

data.name: SDR-P18_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that to guarantee consistent performance and steady transaction response times, your production server should not reside within a virtual machine. $(br)If your production server must reside within a virtual machine: $(li)Pair critical production servers with far quieter VMs on the same physical hardware. $(li)Properly designate sufficient resources to the VM that your critical production server resides on and limit the resources of the other VMs that reside on the same physical hardware to prevent VMs of lesser importance from using too many resources to the detriment of your critical server.

data.name: SDR-P2_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P2_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9vtin8

data.name: SDR-P2_Description
data.value: Number of processors reduced

data.name: SDR-P2_Finding
data.value: Your SQL Server is only allowed to use $(AllowedToUseCpuCount) of $(TotalCpuCount) CPU cores

data.name: SDR-P2_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The last analysis indicated that SQL Server was allowed to use $(PreviousAllowedToUseCpuCount) cores which has now been reduced to $(AllowedToUseCpuCount) cores.

data.name: SDR-P2_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that SQL Server be allowed to use all CPU cores via CPU affinity settings to increase performance when SQL Server requires more CPU power.

data.name: SDR-P21_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P21_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cwsz5E

data.name: SDR-P21_Description
data.value: Visual effects not optimized

data.name: SDR-P21_Finding
data.value: Visual Effects are not adjusted for best performance

data.name: SDR-P21_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Visual Effects consume CPU cycles, extra memory and network bandwidth as most production servers are accessed using Remote Desktop.

data.name: SDR-P21_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that, as most production servers are accessed via Remote Desktop Connect, Visual Effects be adjusted for best Performance. $(br) Visual Effects consume CPU cycles, extra memory, and network bandwidth. Visual Effects settings are located in the Performance section of the Advanced System Properties dialog. $(br)In addition, It is recommended that you stop the Themes service and that it be changed to a manually started service.

data.name: SDR-P3_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P3_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/brk9tf

data.name: SDR-P3_Description
data.value: Processing ability reduced

data.name: SDR-P3_Finding
data.value: Your server has lost some processing ability since it was last checked

data.name: SDR-P3_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Previously this server had $(PreviousCpuCount) processors running at a total processing “horsepower” of $(PreviousSpeed) GHz. It currently has $(CurrentCpuCount) processors running at a total processing speed of $(CurrentSpeed) GHz which represents a loss of $(LostPercent).

data.name: SDR-P3_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that, if this is not a known issue, check to see if: $(br)1. A CPU has been lost (or disabled via BIOS). $(br)2. A failover has occurred on a cluster machine. $(br)3. Your power settings have changed.

data.name: SDR-P4_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P4_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9nEt2y

data.name: SDR-P4_Description
data.value: Power or BIOS settings incorrect

data.name: SDR-P4_Finding
data.value: Your BIOS settings or Control Panel Power Settings are not allowing the server's CPUs to run at full frequency

data.name: SDR-P4_Impact_Explanation
data.value: During the system analysis the CPUs averaged $(AvgFrequencyPercentString)% of maximum frequency and have never reached 100% of their rated frequency. This causes significant performance impact.

data.name: SDR-P4_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you adjust Control Panel Power settings (or BIOS settings) to allow the server to run at full frequency.

data.name: SDR-P5_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P5_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aQsFIr

data.name: SDR-P5_Description
data.value: Power or BIOS settings not set to "high performance"

data.name: SDR-P5_Finding
data.value: Your BIOS settings or Control Panel Power settings are not set to High Performance

data.name: SDR-P5_Impact_Explanation
data.value: This may affect performance as it takes a finite amount of time to increase the processors frequency when it is needed by increasing voltage to the core. During this state transition the core clock and the phase-locked loop are both stopped and restarted which prevents the core from performing any work during that period.

data.name: SDR-P5_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that your Power or BIOS settings be set to High Performance to increase server performance.

data.name: SDR-P6_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P6_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cyJsRK

data.name: SDR-P6_Description
data.value: Excessive Max Degree of Parallelism

data.name: SDR-P6_Finding
data.value: The Max Degree of Parallelism parameter setting allows a single query to use more than half the number of available processor cores

data.name: SDR-P6_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The Max Degree of Parallelism option is set to $(MaxDOP) with $(Cores) processor cores available for the SQL Server process to use.

data.name: SDR-P6_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)A single, large query could monopolize the server to the detriment of other OLTP transactions, causing a significant backlog. $(li)True OLTP transactions generally will not parallelize unless they are not tuned correctly, i.e., missing/incomplete WHERE clause, missing index, out-of-data statistics, or it is not a true OLTP transaction.

data.name: SDR-P6_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)The server is not a true OLTP server but is a hybrid-OLTP server used for data warehousing or reporting. $(li)The current setting has been tuned specifically for the data access patterns, IO subsystem, CPU cores, and acceptable user response time for the specific SQL Server instance.

data.name: SDR-P6_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that on an OLTP production server, the Max Degree of Parallelism parameter should be set to a value greater than zero and not exceeding half the number of available processor cores up to a maximum setting of 8. For servers that have NUMA configured, the Max Degree of Parallelism parameter should be set to the number of CPUs that are assigned to each NUMA node up to a maximum setting of 8.
However, you should verify that the specific database usage model for the server is ‘online transaction processing’ (OLTP) and the usage pattern will benefit from the setting change. Note the following guidelines when making this setting change for an OLTP server: $(li)The ‘max degree of parallelism’ server option should never be set to a value greater than the number of physical cores available. $(li)The ‘affinity mask’ and ‘affinity64 mask’ server configuration option should be considered to determine the total number of physical cores available. $(li)Consider the impact that Hyper-Threading may have on performance. If Hyper-Threading is not disabled in your environment, verify that Hyper-Threading is enhancing the performance of the SQL Server instance and not comprising performance. $(li)Never exceed the number of CPUs assigned to each NUMA node for servers configured to use NUMA.$(li)For true OLTP environments, some experts recommend setting ‘max degree of parallelism’ to 1 to prevent query parallelization. There are situations where this is justified but only after an in-depth analysis of wait statistics, data access patterns, the IO subsystem, processor core usage, and other important factors. $(li)Parallelism can be controlled on specific queries by the MAXDOP query hint. $(li)The ‘cost threshold for parallelism’ server configuration option can allow for preventing parallelism on queries that don’t exceed the estimated query cost.

data.name: SDR-P7_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P7_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/agslkv

data.name: SDR-P7_Finding
data.value: Databases with high usage are being encrypted

data.name: SDR-P7_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Encrypting entire high usage databases as was detected on $(EncryptedDatabases.Count>1?databases:database) $(EncryptedDatabases) (representing $(EncryptedIOPercentString)% of all IO traffic performed by this SQL Server. This places an additional CPU processing burden on your server.

data.name: SDR-P7_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that only the columns that contain vital data be encrypted. It is seldom necessary to encrypt every single column of every table in a database. Typically, only a few select columns actually hold vital data which must be kept secret at all costs and it is only those columns which should be encrypted.

data.name: SDR-P7_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Note: 256-bit AES may be required by certain IT departments, but be aware that it requires additional processing overhead and 128-bit AES has never been cracked.

data.name: SDR-P8_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P8_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cZs5Ia

data.name: SDR-P8_Finding
data.value: Inefficient encryption has been detected on database $(Database)

data.name: SDR-P8_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Encryption methods other than 128-bit AES place an unnecessary additional CPU processing burden on your Server. $(br)Note: 256-bit AES may be required by certain IT departments, but be aware that it requires additional processing overhead and 128-bit AES has never been cracked. $(br)Note: DES, RC2 and SQL Server’s implementation of RC4 and RC4_128 are no longer considered secure and can typically be cracked in a few hours or days.

data.name: SDR-P8_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that 128-bit AES encryption be used for the database. 128-bit AES represents a 15-25% computational efficiency over other encryption methods (3DES, asymmetric encryption, RC2, etc).

data.name: SDR-P8_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: Inefficient encryption has been detected on $(Count) databases

data.name: SDR-P8_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Encryption methods other than 128-bit AES place an unnecessary additional CPU processing burden on your Server. Note: 256-bit AES may be required by certain IT departments, but be aware that it requires additional processing overhead and 128-bit AES has never been cracked. Note: DES, RC2 and SQL Server’s implementation of RC4 and RC4_128 are no longer considered secure and can typically be cracked in a few hours or days.

data.name: SDR-P8_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that 128-bit AES encryption be used for these databases. 128-bit AES represents a 15-25% computational efficiency over other encryption methods (3DES, asymmetric encryption, RC2, etc).

data.name: SDR-P19_Recommendation

data.name: SDR-P23_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P23_Description
data.value: High CXPACKET waits on OLTP Server

data.name: SDR-P23_Finding
data.value: Your OLTP Server is experiencing high CPU usage along with a high number of CXPACKET waits

data.name: SDR-P23_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A high number of CXPACKET waits indicate parallel queries are running on your server. This is an indication that one or more threads of the parallelized queries are waiting for another thread to complete before the parallel operation can be completed.

data.name: SDR-P23_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Indexes may be missing which are causing queries to be less efficient.$(li)Statistics could be out-of-date or missing which will cause the optimizer to not properly estimate the cost of the query.$(li)Fragmentation could be causing additional I/O requests for one or more of the parallel threads.$(li)Query filter predicates may be incomplete or missing causing queries to be less efficient.$(li)Query filter predicates may contain functions on column values forcing a scan to be used instead of a seek.$(li)Query filter predicates may be causing an implicit conversion of a column value because of mismatched data types.$(li)Queries are not true online transaction processing (OLTP) transactions.

data.name: SDR-P23_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)When CXPACKET waits are not excessive and parallelism is desired for the workload.$(li)This is not a true online transaction processing (OLTP) server or it is a hybrid server.

data.name: SDR-P23_Recommendation
data.value: You should consider the following which can have a significant impact on CPU usage and CXPACKET wait times:$(li)Updating statistics to ensure the query optimizer is estimating the cost of queries correctly.$(li)Rebuild highly fragmented indexes which are experiencing range scans.$(li)Research the addition of new indexes to improve workload performance.$(li)Review queries to ensure they are optimized for OLTP transactions.$(li)Revise filter criteria to prevent implicit conversions which could be causing index/table scans.$(li)Revise filter criteria to prevent functions from being used on columns which could be causing index/table scans.

data.name: SDR-P23_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-P23_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-P23_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q1_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9GblQc

data.name: SDR-Q1_Description
data.value: Unclosed cursor

data.name: SDR-Q1_Finding
data.value: Cursor $(CursorName) is not properly closed or cleared

data.name: SDR-Q1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Cursors that have not been cleared can consume memory resources and hold locks that affect data availability.

data.name: SDR-Q1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that cursor $(CursorName) should be explicitly closed and cleared after use.

data.name: SDR-Q1_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) cursors are not properly closed or cleared

data.name: SDR-Q1_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that these cursors be explicitly closed and cleared after use.

data.name: SDR-Q10_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q10_Finding
data.value: A filter predicate contains mismatched data types

data.name: SDR-Q10_Impact_Explanation
data.value: One side of the query predicate has a data type of $(FoundType) while the other side has a data type of $(DesiredType). This condition will cause implicit conversions for data type matching and likely prevent the query optimizer from using indexes to access the data more efficiently.

data.name: SDR-Q10_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you re-write the predicate to explicitly CAST the data type $(FoundType) to match data type $(DesiredType) to avoid implicit conversions.

data.name: SDR-Q10_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q10_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q10_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q11_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q11_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/d9FNEi

data.name: SDR-Q11_Description
data.value: Unfiltered delete statement

data.name: SDR-Q11_Finding
data.value: An unfiltered delete on [$(TableName)] in [$(Database)]

data.name: SDR-Q11_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The query deletes all data from table [$(TableName)].

data.name: SDR-Q11_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)A significant amount of system resources and transaction log space could be used due to the DELETE operation logging each row deleted.$(li)The duration of the delete operation could be significant depending on the number of rows deleted.$(li)When the DELETE is executed using a row lock, each row is locked for deletion which may require a significant amount of locking.$(li)The table can still contain empty pages which may account for a large amount of excess space allocated to the table.

data.name: SDR-Q11_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If a trigger must be fired for each individual row deletion.$(li)If an identity column exists and the identity counter value must be retained.$(li)If another table references this table in a FOREIGN KEY constraint.$(li)If the table is used by an indexed view.$(li)If the delete operation will be published by using transactional replication or merge replication.$(li)If the table is small enough that the overhead of the DELETE is negligible.

data.name: SDR-Q11_Recommendation
data.value:
You should consider rewriting the query to use a TRUNCATE instead of a DELETE. The TRUNCATE operation is much faster and uses far less system and transaction log resources than a DELETE.
However, you should be aware that the TRUNCATE should not be performed in the following situations:$(li)A trigger exists and should be fired for each row deletion.$(li)An identity column exists and the identity counter should be retained.$(li)This table is referenced by another table in a FOREIGN KEY constraint.$(li)The table is used in an indexed view.$(li)Transactional replication or merge replication is in use.

data.name: SDR-Q11_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) unfiltered delete statements have been detected

data.name: SDR-Q11_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: These queries delete all data from the tables they reference

data.name: SDR-Q12_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q12_Finding
data.value: SELECT DISTINCT abuse has been detected

data.name: SDR-Q12_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The query's SELECT clause contains a potentially redundant DISTINCT operator. The select list of this query contains $(ColumnNames.Count>1?columns:column) from table [$(TableName)] that $(ColumnNames.Count>1?are:is) unique. Analysis of this query indicates that the result rows will be unique without using DISTINCT, use of which results in performance overhead since SQL Server must sort or group the result set to remove duplicate rows.

data.name: SDR-Q12_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you re-write the SELECT clause of this query to remove the use of DISTINCT.

data.name: SDR-Q12_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q12_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q12_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q16_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q16_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/deZV4X

data.name: SDR-Q16_Description
data.value: Function used in query predicate

data.name: SDR-Q16_Finding
data.value: A function is being used in a query predicate

data.name: SDR-Q16_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The use of a function on a column value within a search predicate prevents the query optimizer from performing an index seek and requires all column values to be scanned and processed by the function.

data.name: SDR-Q16_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you rewrite the query to remove the use of the function within the search predicate. One option to remove the use of the LEFT function would be to replace it with LIKE and the % wild card. Using LIKE instead of the LEFT function will allow the query optimizer to consider index seeks for satisfying the query.

data.name: SDR-Q16_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: A function is being used in a query predicate for $(Count) queries

data.name: SDR-Q16_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you rewrite the query to remove the use of the function within the search predicate. One option to remove the use of the LEFT function would be to replace it with LIKE and the % wild card. Using LIKE instead of the LEFT function will allow the query optimizer to consider index seeks for satisfying the query.

data.name: SDR-Q2_Finding

data.name: SDR-Q2_Impact_Explanation
data.value: If cursor $(CursorName) is only used to read sequentially from the first to the last row, using the FAST_FORWARD option will allow performance optimizations to be enabled.

data.name: SDR-Q2_Recommendation

data.name: SDR-Q20_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q20_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bUCNVt

data.name: SDR-Q20_Description
data.value: Table/index scan due to NOT IN

data.name: SDR-Q20_Finding
data.value: The NOT IN predicate is causing a table or index scan

data.name: SDR-Q20_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The query execution plan indicates that a table or index scan is being performed for each column value filterd by the NOT IN predicate. This could be caused by column $(ColumnName) allowing NULL values.

data.name: SDR-Q20_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that the NOT IN portion of the query be reviewed to determine if an alternate method could be used for filtering. If the NOT IN must be used, consider modifying the NOT IN subquery to filter out null values (WHERE $(ColumnName) IS NOT NULL).
All query modifications must be thoroughly tested before implemented into production. A simple change to a query could have a significant impact on the results of executing that query.

data.name: SDR-Q20_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) queries found where the NOT IN predicate is causing a table or index scan

data.name: SDR-Q20_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that the NOT IN portion of the query be reviewed to determine if an alternate method could be used for filtering. If the NOT IN must be used, consider modifying the NOT IN subquery to filter out null values (WHERE [ColumnName] IS NOT NULL).
All query modifications must be thoroughly tested before implemented into production. A simple change to a query could have a significant impact on the results of executing that query.

data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q22_Description
data.value: Select * found

data.name: SDR-Q22_Finding
data.value: The use of SELECT * has been found

data.name: SDR-Q22_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The use of SELECT * will return all of the columns found in the tables and/or views of the FROM clause. This can lead to a number of unused columns being returned.

data.name: SDR-Q22_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you change the SELECT * to explicitly include only the columns needed and remove the *.

data.name: SDR-Q22_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: The use of SELECT * has been found $(Count) times

data.name: SDR-Q22_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you change all of the SELECT * queries to explicitly include only the columns needed and remove the *.

data.name: SDR-Q23_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q23_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aHoji9

data.name: SDR-Q23_Finding
data.value: Obsolete recommendation

data.name: SDR-Q23_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Please perform a new analysis for updated recommendations.

data.name: SDR-Q24_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q24_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9dhQyO

data.name: SDR-Q24_Description
data.value: Search predicate contains a column expression in a function

data.name: SDR-Q24_Finding
data.value: A Search predicate contains a column expression in a function

data.name: SDR-Q24_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The query optimizer will not be able to perform an index seek on search predicates that include the column in a function, resulting in a less optimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-Q24_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you modify the search predicate to no longer filter based on the result of a function on a column value. This will allow the query optimizer to consider index seeks to satisfy the search predicate and not require a scan of all column values.
All query modifications must be thoroughly tested before implemented into production. A simple change to a query could have a significant impact on the results of executing that query.

data.name: SDR-Q24_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) search predicates contain a column expression in a function

data.name: SDR-Q25_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q25_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/a1wbPY

data.name: SDR-Q25_Finding
data.value: Function $(FunctionName) called for a row set

data.name: SDR-Q25_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SQL is a set based programming language, not a procedural language. Using functions to encapsulate procedural code can result in significant performance overhead when called on a row set because the function is executed for each row of the set.

data.name: SDR-Q25_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that this query be re-written to include the function logic as in-line code, allowing the query optimizer to produce a more optimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-Q25_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q25_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q25_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q26_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q26_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/c83yoX

data.name: SDR-Q26_Description
data.value: Union operator found

data.name: SDR-Q26_Finding
data.value: The UNION operator has been found on a query

data.name: SDR-Q26_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The UNION operator combines the results of two or more queries into a single result set and removes duplicate rows. The overhead required to remove the duplicate rows from the result set can be significant for a large result set.

data.name: SDR-Q26_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that the use of UNION ALL be considered if the result set is large and will not contain duplicate rows.
Additionally, if duplicate rows do exist in the result set, consider the option of filtering out the duplicate rows by the querying application. It is common for the consuming application to perform the duplicate filtering regardless of the result set already being filtered by SQL Server. In this situation, the additional performance hit on SQL Server may not be justified in the reduced result set transfered back to the client application.
All query modifications must be thoroughly tested before implemented into production. A simple change to a query could have a significant impact on the results of executing that query.

data.name: SDR-Q26_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: The UNION operator has been found on a $(Count) queries

data.name: SDR-Q27_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q27_Finding
data.value: Subquery used instead of JOIN

data.name: SDR-Q27_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A subquery is used in the WHERE clause of the query. The query optimizer will typically generate a less optimal execution plan than if an explicit JOIN were used.

data.name: SDR-Q27_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the WHERE clause of this query be re-written to use a JOIN rather than a subquery.

data.name: SDR-Q27_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q27_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q27_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q28_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q28_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cabWQq

data.name: SDR-Q28_Description
data.value: SET ROWCOUNT used instead of TOP

data.name: SDR-Q28_Finding
data.value: SET ROWCOUNT used instead of TOP

data.name: SDR-Q28_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The query is using SET ROWCOUNT to limit the size of the result set instead of the TOP clause. Since SET ROWCOUNT is used outside the statement that executes the query, its value cannot be used to produce an optimal execution plan. The query optimizer can use the value of the expression in the TOP clause to generate a more optimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-Q28_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the query be rewritten to use the TOP clause instead of SET ROWCOUNT.

data.name: SDR-Q28_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SET ROWCOUNT used instead of TOP $(Count) times

data.name: SDR-Q28_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: These queries are using SET ROWCOUNT to limit the size of their result sets instead of the TOP clause. Since SET ROWCOUNT is used outside the statement that executes the query, its value cannot be used to produce an optimal execution plan. The query optimizer can use the value of the expression in the TOP clause to generate a more optimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-Q28_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that these queries be rewritten to use the TOP clause instead of SET ROWCOUNT.

data.name: SDR-Q29_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q29_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bMsKmB

data.name: SDR-Q29_Description
data.value: Search predicate used instead of TOP

data.name: SDR-Q29_Finding
data.value: Search predicate is being used to limit result set instead of TOP

data.name: SDR-Q29_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The WHERE clause of the query limited the result set instead of the applicable TOP clause. Using TOP will result in a more optimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-Q29_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the query be rewritten replacing the search predicate with equivalent TOP clause.

data.name: SDR-Q29_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) instances of search predicate being used to limit result sets instead of TOP

data.name: SDR-Q29_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The WHERE clause of these queries limited their result sets instead of using the applicable TOP clause. Using TOP will result in a more optimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-Q29_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that these queries be rewritten, replacing the search predicate with equivalent TOP clause.

data.name: SDR-Q3_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q3_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/acMX06

data.name: SDR-Q3_Description
data.value: Inefficient SQL Module settings

data.name: SDR-Q3_Finding
data.value: SQL Module settings may prevent query optimization

data.name: SDR-Q3_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SQL Module $(DatabaseName).$(SchemaName).$(ObjectName) was found with ANSI_NULLS and/or QUOTED_IDENTIFIER set to OFF. These settings can prevent the query optimizer from using an index seek for certain queries.

data.name: SDR-Q3_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that ANSI_NULLS is always set to ON. In a future version of SQL Server, setting ANSI_NULLS to OFF will generate an error.
Additionally, if QUOTED_IDENTIFIER is set to OFF, change the setting to ON unless the object requires the setting to be OFF.
All query modifications must be thoroughly tested before implemented into production. A simple change to a query could have a significant impact on the results of executing that query.

data.name: SDR-Q3_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) SQL Modules have settings that may prevent query optimization

data.name: SDR-Q3_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: SQL Modules found with ANSI_NULLS and/or QUOTED_IDENTIFIER set to OFF. These settings can prevent the query optimizer from using an index seek for certain queries.

data.name: SDR-Q30_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q30_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/d93X4k

data.name: SDR-Q30_Finding
data.value: Invariant operation found inside a loop

data.name: SDR-Q30_Impact_Explanation
data.value: An invariant operation inside of a loop will result in unnecessary performance overhead.

data.name: SDR-Q30_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the query be rewritten to move the invariant operation outside of the loop.

data.value: http://bit.ly/d7zlzw

data.name: SDR-Q31_Finding
data.value: Columns $(ColumnNames) referenced in a different order than their covered index $(IndexName)

data.name: SDR-Q31_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Referencing columns in a different order than that of their covered index will result in a less optimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-Q31_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the WHERE clause of this query be rewritten to reference the columns in the same order as the covering index.
