data.name: SDR-Q32_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q32_bitly
data.value: http://http://bit.ly/aE07TU 2

data.name: SDR-Q32_Finding
data.value: Use of NOT NULL condition on column $(ColumnName) is suppressing an index range scan

data.name: SDR-Q32_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Column $(ColumnName) in table [$(TableName)] is covered by an index but not producing an index range scan for the query due to the use of the NOT NULL condition, resulting in a suboptimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-Q32_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the search predicate of the query be rewritten using an upper and lower limit that will allow for an index range scan, resulting in a more optimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-Q32_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) usages of NOT NULL conditions are suppressing index range scans

data.name: SDR-Q32_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The use of the NOT NULL expression is preventing index range scans on indexed columns, resulting in suboptimal execution plans.

data.name: SDR-Q33_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q33_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cM8VRo

data.name: SDR-Q33_Finding
data.value: Use of not-equal operator on column $(ColumnName) is suppressing an index range scan

data.name: SDR-Q33_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Column $(ColumnName) in table [$(TableName)] is covered by an index but not producing an index range scan for the query due to the use of the not-equal operator, resulting in a suboptimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-Q33_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the query be rewritten, if the not-equal operator covers most rows, replacing the not-equal operator with the IN clause, allowing for an index range scan and more optimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-Q33_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) usages of not-equal operators suppressing an index range scan

data.name: SDR-Q33_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The use of the not-equal operator is preventing index range scans on indexed columns, resulting in suboptimal execution plans.

data.name: SDR-Q33_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: SKIPPED

data.name: SDR-Q34_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q34_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bbUDWs

data.name: SDR-Q34_Description
data.value: Insert statement without column list

data.name: SDR-Q34_Finding
data.value: Insert statement without column list

data.name: SDR-Q34_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Although this will not affect performance it is a best practice to specify a column list on insert statements.

data.name: SDR-Q34_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you specify a column list on insert statements.

data.name: SDR-Q34_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) insert statements without column lists

data.name: SDR-Q5_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q5_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/a5riMX

data.name: SDR-Q5_Finding
data.value: Row count logging is turned on

data.name: SDR-Q5_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The SET NOCOUNT option isn't explicitly configured in the batch. By default, SET NOCOUNT is set to OFF resulting in additional information about the affected row count of each query being sent back to the client application. While some applications require this information, many do not and the information is discarded. Sending this information back to the client application results in network overhead for each execution.

data.name: SDR-Q5_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you evaluate the necessity of row count information for the client application. If this information is not required, re-write stored procedures used by the client application to include SET NOCOUNT ON at the beginning for the procedure definition.

data.name: SDR-Q5_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) instances where row count logging is turned on

data.name: SDR-Q35_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q35_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9cZpwC

data.name: SDR-Q35_Description
data.value: Function causing table scan

data.name: SDR-Q35_Finding
data.value: The function "$(FunctionName)" on column [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)].[$(Column)] may be causing a table scan

data.name: SDR-Q35_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The function or expression "$(FunctionName)" in a query $(ObjectName?in $(ObjectName) :)$(ApplicationName?from $(ApplicationName) :)$(Database?in [$(Database)] :)$(HostName?submitted from $(HostName) :)$(UserName?by $(UserName) :)can cause index suppression resulting in poor performance due to a scan being performed instead of a seek.

data.name: SDR-Q35_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you consider redesigning this WHERE clause to prevent index suppression and performance degradation. $(br)Note: This recommendation can be caused from T-SQL that is nested in a function, view or stored procedure.

data.name: SDR-Q35_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) functions may be causing table scans

data.name: SDR-Q35_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A function or expression can cause index suppression resulting in poor performance due to a scan being performed instead of a seek.

data.name: SDR-Q35_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you consider redesigning the WHERE clause for the affected queries to prevent index suppression and performance degradation.

data.name: SDR-Q36_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q36_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aTCOcL

data.name: SDR-Q36_Description
data.value: Implicit conversion may be causing index suppression

data.name: SDR-Q36_Finding
data.value: An implicit conversion on column [$(Database)].[$(Schema)].[$(Table)].[$(Column)] to data type "$(DataType)" may be causing index suppression

data.name: SDR-Q36_Impact_Explanation
data.value: An implicit conversion in a WHERE clause of a query $(ObjectName?in $(ObjectName) :)$(ApplicationName?on $(ApplicationName) :)$(Database?in [$(Database)] :)$(HostName?submitted from $(HostName) :)$(UserName?by $(UserName) :)can cause index suppression if an indexed column is of a different type resulting in a scan rather than a seek.

data.name: SDR-Q36_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you consider redesigning this WHERE clause to prevent index suppression and performance degradation.

data.name: SDR-Q36_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: Implicit conversions may be causing index suppression for $(Count) columns

data.name: SDR-Q36_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: An implicit conversion in a WHERE clause of a query can cause index suppression if an indexed column is of a different type resulting in a scan rather than a seek.

data.name: SDR-Q36_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you consider redesigning the WHERE clause for the affected queries to prevent index suppression and performance degradation.

data.name: SDR-Q4_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q4_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cMjC0j

data.name: SDR-Q4_Finding
data.value: DML parameters are being explicitly manipulated

data.name: SDR-Q4_Impact_Explanation
data.value: One or more parameters used in a DML statement are being explicitly manipulated prior to execution of the statement. This may prevent the query optimizer from generating optimal execution plans because the actual parameter value is not known at optimization and compile time.

data.name: SDR-Q4_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you re-write the procedure to execute the DML statement dynamically, passing the manipulated parameter as an input parameter at run time. This will allow the optimizer to estimate the internal costs more accurately, resulting in more optimized execution plans.

data.name: SDR-Q4_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) instances of DML parameters being explicitly manipulated

data.name: SDR-Q4_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you re-write these procedures to execute DML statements dynamically, passing the manipulated parameters as input parameters at run time. This will allow the optimizer to estimate the internal costs more accurately, resulting in more optimized execution plans.

data.name: SDR-Q6_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q6_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9mDDyI

data.name: SDR-Q6_Description
data.value: Inconsistent procedure execution times

data.name: SDR-Q6_Finding
data.value: Inconsistent execution times for $(ObjectName?$(ObjectName):procedure)

data.name: SDR-Q6_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Execution time varied between $(MinimumDuration)ms and $(MaximumDuration)ms with reads varying from $(MinimumReads) to $(MaximumReads) for $(ObjectName?$(ObjectName):the query). This inconsistency could be caused from a cached execution plan being reused that was compiled for a set of parameters that are not optimal for each execution.

data.name: SDR-Q6_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that the $(ObjectName?WITH RECOMPLE option be added to $(ObjectName):RECOMPILE hint is added to the query). This will prevent SQL Server from caching the execution plan and cause a new plan to be compiled on each execution.
However, additional testing should be performed to verify the extra overhead of compiling an execution plan on each execution is justified and that overall performance is improved.

data.name: SDR-Q6_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) queries with inconsistent execution times

data.name: SDR-Q6_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Execution time varied for $(Count) queries. This inconsistency could be caused from a cached execution plan being reused that was compiled for a set of parameters that are not optimal for each execution.

data.name: SDR-Q6_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that the WITH RECOMPLE option be added to procedures and/or RECOMPILE hint is added to the queries. This will prevent SQL Server from caching the execution plan and cause a new plan to be compiled on each execution.
However, additional testing should be performed to verify the extra overhead of compiling an execution plan on each execution is justified and that overall performance is improved.

data.name: SDR-Q7_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q7_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9ITt1L

data.name: SDR-Q7_Description
data.value: Query plan compilations per second greater than batch requests

data.name: SDR-Q7_Finding
data.value: Query plan compilations per second are greater than batch requests

data.name: SDR-Q7_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Query plan compilations ($(CompilationsPerSec) per second) should be a fraction of the number of batch requests ($(BatchesPerSec) per second) flowing through your SQL Server system, ideally less than 10%. If compilations are running high, it likely indicates a high degree of adhoc query executions rather than stored procedures, which will result in higher CPU usage due to recurring execution plan compiles.

data.name: SDR-Q7_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you re-write adhoc queries as stored procedures to improve cached plan reuse and CPU performance by dramatically reducing the number of compilations.

data.name: SDR-Q8_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q8_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/asTIy2

data.name: SDR-Q8_Description
data.value: COALESCE used in place of ISNULL

data.name: SDR-Q8_Finding
data.value: COALESCE is used in place of ISNULL

data.name: SDR-Q8_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The COALESCE function is being used to return the first non-null expression from two arguments. This could be implemented with the more efficient ISNULL function.

data.name: SDR-Q8_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)The COALESCE function is basically translated to a CASE expression that requires more overhead than using the ISNULL function. The ISNULL function is a built-in implemented within the database engine that will generally provide better performance.

data.name: SDR-Q8_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)When more than two arguments are tested for NULL, COALESCE must be used instead of ISNULL.$(li)The performance gain from using ISNULL does not justify making the query changes.$(li)The query must stay compliant to the ANSI SQL standards (ISNULL is a proprietary built-in function).

data.name: SDR-Q8_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you modify the query to use the ISNULL function in place of COALESCE.
All query modifications must be thoroughly tested before implemented into production. A simple change to a query could have a significant impact on the results of executing that query.

data.name: SDR-Q8_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: COALESCE is used in place of ISNULL for $(Count) queries

data.name: SDR-Q8_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you modify the queries to use the ISNULL function in place of COALESCE.
All query modifications must be thoroughly tested before implemented into production. A simple change to a query could have a significant impact on the results of executing that query.

data.name: SDR-Q9_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q9_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aDWS1u

data.name: SDR-Q9_Finding
data.value: Composite expression including column used in a search predicate

data.name: SDR-Q9_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A composite expression is an expression that contains two or more sub-expressions. The value of the composite expression is calculated at run time and not at compile time, preventing the optimizer from considering the expression's value, resulting in a less optimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-Q9_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you re-write the query so that the composite expression is pre-calculated, providing the optimizer with a non-composite value that can be used to generate a more optimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-Q9_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) instances of a composite expression including column being used in a search predicate

data.name: SDR-Q9_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you re-write these queries so that the composite expression is pre-calculated, providing the optimizer with a non-composite value that can be used to generate a more optimal execution plan.

data.name: SDR-S1_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bTqf0v

data.name: SDR-S1_Description
data.value: Mixed Mode Authentication

data.name: SDR-S1_Finding
data.value: Authentication set to Mixed Mode

data.name: SDR-S1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The SQL Server instance is configured to allow both Windows Authentication and SQL Server Authentication.

data.name: SDR-S1_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Windows Authentication is more secure than SQL Server Authentication, primarily due to its integration with the Windows security system. Windows security provides more features, such as secure validation and encryption of passwords, auditing, password expiration, minimum password length, and account lockout after multiple invalid login requests.

data.name: SDR-S1_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)Even though Windows Authentication is more secure, SQL Server Authentication is required for non-Windows based clients or clients running Windows OS versions prior to Windows NT 4.0 and Windows 2000 Server. $(li)Some applications require the use of SQL Server Authentication.

data.name: SDR-S1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that whenever possible, you use Windows Authentication instead of Mixed Mode Authentication to secure your SQL Server. Note that changing this setting will prevent login using SQL Authentication accounts.

data.name: SDR-S10_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S10_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/b4bNH3

data.name: SDR-S10_Description
data.value: Guest user has database access

data.name: SDR-S10_Finding
data.value: Guest user has permission to access database $(Database)

data.name: SDR-S10_Impact_Explanation
data.value: While the guest user cannot be dropped and is necessary in system database and certain cross-database applications, in many cases it is not necessary.

data.name: SDR-S10_Recommendation
data.value: Remove access to the guest user if it is not required.

data.name: SDR-S10_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: Guest user has permission to access $(Count) databases

data.name: SDR-S2_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S2_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/arK1go

data.name: SDR-S2_Description
data.value: BUILTIN\Administrator included in sysadmin role

data.name: SDR-S2_Finding
data.value: BUILTIN\Administrator is included in sysadmin Role

data.name: SDR-S2_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The Windows BUILTIN\Administrators group is added to the SQL Server sysadmin role by default. However, this causes all local administrators to be granted full administrative rights to the SQL Server, which may not be intended.

data.name: SDR-S2_Recommendation
data.value: Research the possibility of removing the BUILTIN\Administrators group from the sysadmin SQL Server group and provide administrative access to individual users as required.

data.name: SDR-S3_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S3_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/dh7VAQ

data.name: SDR-S3_Description
data.value: Public role enabled for SQL Server Agent Proxy Account

data.name: SDR-S3_Finding
data.value: Public role is enabled for SQL Server Agent Proxy Account

data.name: SDR-S3_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The SQL Server Agent proxy account is given elevated privileges, while the Public role has fewer privileges. Someone using the Public role could therefore take advantage of a higher privilege level.

data.name: SDR-S3_Recommendation
data.value: Research the possibility of removing the Public role from the SQL Server Agent proxy account.

data.name: SDR-S4_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S4_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/a894XV

data.name: SDR-S4_Description
data.value: Deprecated SQL Agent token in use

data.name: SDR-S4_Finding
data.value: Deprecated SQL Server Agent Token in use for step "$(StepName)" of job "$(JobName)"

data.name: SDR-S4_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Beginning with SQL 2005, the token syntax used in SQL Agent jobs must use escaped notation. This will cause SQL Agent jobs to fail on SQL Server 2005 SP1 or later.

data.name: SDR-S4_Recommendation
data.value: Change any job steps which are using outdated tokens to use proper escape notation. A script to assist in transitioning job steps, sp_AddEscapeNoneToJobStepTokens, is available from Microsoft.

data.name: SDR-S4_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: Deprecated SQL Server Agent Tokens in use in $(Count) job steps

data.name: SDR-S5_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S5_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bS6yOc

data.name: SDR-S5_Finding
data.value: SQL Server instance is running on a domain controller

data.name: SDR-S5_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Microsoft recommends that SQL Server not be installed on a primary or backup domain controller. Installing a failover cluster on a domain controller is not supported.

data.name: SDR-S5_Recommendation
data.value: If possible, move the SQL Server instance to a non domain controller server.

data.name: SDR-S6_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S6_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bNV0ZV

data.name: SDR-S6_Description
data.value: Vulnerable SQL Server Password Policy

data.name: SDR-S6_Finding
data.value: SQL Server password policy is vulnerable for login $(Name)

data.name: SDR-S6_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The SQL login $(Name) is vulnerable to exploitation because it does not enforce both a password policy and password expiration.

data.name: SDR-S6_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Without a password complexity policy, there is nothing preventing the user from using a password that is easy to guess or that is not complex enough to prevent a brute force attack. $(li)Passwords with no expiration allow the user to use the same password indefinitely. This increases the likelihood that the user will never change the password and that others will learn the password and use the account without proper authorization. $(li)When a password complexity policy is in place, the user must use a password that meets the requirements of that policy. These requirements generally mean the user cannot use all or part of the account name as the password, the password is at least eight characters long, and contains a mix of upper and lower case, alphanumeric, and special characters.

data.name: SDR-S6_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)While enforcing password policies is a best practice, there may be business reasons that such a policy is undesirable, such as supporting legacy applications. $(li)When a password expiration policy is used to manage the lifespan of the password, one password cannot be used forever. If a database application requires SQL Server Authentication and there is no provision for changing the password regularly, it may be disruptive to change from the existing policy, though doing so would be in line with recommended security practices.$(li)When a vendor application has a required SQL Login password that fails to meet the complexity requirements.

data.name: SDR-S6_Recommendation
data.value: If SQL Server Authentication is not required in your environment, use Windows Authentication instead. Otherwise, enable both "Enforce password policy" and "Password expiration" for all SQL Server logins.

data.name: SDR-S6_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: SQL Server password policy is weak for $(Count) logins

data.name: SDR-S6_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A SQL login is vulnerable to exploitation when it does not enforce both a password policy and password expiration.

data.name: SDR-S6_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: If SQL Server Authentication is not required in your environment, use Windows Authentication instead. Otherwise, enable both "Enforce password policy" and "Password expiration" for all SQL Server logins.

data.name: SDR-S7_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S7_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/cyQygd

data.name: SDR-S7_Description
data.value: Trustworthy bit vulnerability

data.name: SDR-S7_Finding
data.value: Trustworthy Bit vulnerability exists for database $(Database)

data.name: SDR-S7_Impact_Explanation
data.value: If the database owner is assigned a fixed server sysadmin role and the database has its trustworthy bit set to ON, a privileged database user can elevate privileges and possibly compromise the system.

data.name: SDR-S7_Recommendation
data.value: Turn off the trustworthy bit or change the database owner to a fixed server role other than sysadmin.

data.name: SDR-S7_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: Trustworthy Bit vulnerabilities exist for $(Count) databases

data.name: SDR-S8_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S8_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/c6qhrC

data.name: SDR-S8_Description
data.value: Symmetric key in system database

data.name: SDR-S8_Finding
data.value: Symmetric key exists in system database $(Database)

data.name: SDR-S8_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Microsoft recommends that symmetric keys not be created in SQL Server system databases master, msdb, model, and tempdb

data.name: SDR-S8_Recommendation
data.value: Investigate the possibility of removing the symmetric key from $(Database)

data.name: SDR-S8_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: Symmetric keys exist in $(Count) system databases

data.name: SDR-S8_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: Investigate the possibility of removing symmetric keys from system databases

data.name: SDR-S9_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S9_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/afjhhN

data.name: SDR-S9_Description
data.value: Weak encryption algorithm for secret keys

data.name: SDR-S9_Finding
data.value: Encryption algorithm for secret keys is weak for database $(Database)

data.name: SDR-S9_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A weak symmetric key has been detected in $(Database). Microsoft recommends AES 128 bit and above for data encryption.

data.name: SDR-S9_Recommendation
data.value: Update your encryption key to AES 128 bit or above. If AES is not supported by your operating system, use 3DES.

data.name: SDR-S9_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: Encryption algorithm for secret keys is weak for $(Count) databases

data.name: SDR-S9_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A weak symmetric key has been detected in $(Count) databases. Microsoft recommends AED 128 bit and above for data encryption.

data.name: SDR-SC1_Category
data.value: Server Configuration

data.name: SDR-SC1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9WH8Id

data.name: SDR-SC1_Description
data.value: Non-default server setting

data.name: SDR-SC1_Finding
data.value: $(Configuration) is set to value $(CurrentValue)

data.name: SDR-SC1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The $(Configuration) setting has been changed from the default value of $(DefaultValue) to $(CurrentValue).

data.name: SDR-SC1_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)A non-default setting can have an adverse impact on performance.

data.name: SDR-SC1_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If the current setting has been verified to provide the greatest value.

data.name: SDR-SC1_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that the default value of $(DefaultValue) is used for the $(Configuration) server setting.
However, all changes to server configuration settings require thorough testing to verify there are no adverse effects.

data.name: SDR-SC1_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) non-default server settings

data.name: SDR-SC1_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The default server setting has been changed.

data.name: SDR-SC1_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that the default value is used for the server setting.
However, all changes to server configuration settings require thorough testing to verify there are no adverse effects.

data.name: SDR-SC2_Category
data.value: Server Configuration

data.name: SDR-SC2_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/b6wWJZ

data.name: SDR-SC2_Description
data.value: Server configuration option requires restart

data.name: SDR-SC2_Finding
data.value: SQL Server configuration option "$(Configuration)" has been changed but requires a server restart to take effect

data.name: SDR-SC2_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Certain server configuration options do not take effect until after a server restart.

data.name: SDR-SC2_Recommendation
data.value: Schedule a server restart when possible to finalize this configuration change. If a server restart is expected soon and the configuration option is non-critical, ignore this recommendation.

data.name: SDR-SC2_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) SQL Server configuration options have been changed but require a server restart to take effect

data.name: SDR-SC2_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: Schedule a server restart when possible to finalize these configuration changes. If a server restart is expected soon and the configuration options are non-critical, ignore this recommendatioon.

data.name: SDR-SC3_Category
data.value: Server Configuration

data.name: SDR-SC3_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9Oum0f

data.name: SDR-SC3_Description
data.value: Blocked process threshold too low

data.name: SDR-SC3_Finding
data.value: The Blocked Process Threshold is set too low ($(CurrentValue) sec)

data.name: SDR-SC3_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Setting the Blocked Process Threshold below 5 seconds may cause the deadlock monitor to run constantly and therefore should only be used for short term troubleshooting.

data.name: SDR-SC3_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the Blocked Process Threshold be set to at least 5 seconds.

data.name: SDR-SC4_Category
data.value: Server Configuration

data.name: SDR-SC4_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/d6botW

data.name: SDR-SC4_Description
data.value: Non-dynamic lock configuration

data.name: SDR-SC4_Finding
data.value: Lock configuration is not dynamic

data.name: SDR-SC4_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A setting other than the default of 0 for the Locks configuration option may causes code termination and "out of locks" error messages if the specified number of locks is exceeded.

data.name: SDR-SC4_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the Locks option be set to the default setting of 0, which allows the database engine to allocate and deallocate locks based on system requirements. Making this change will require a SQL Server restart.

data.name: SDR-SC5_Category
data.value: Server Configuration

data.name: SDR-SC5_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/dyRuwl

data.name: SDR-SC5_Description
data.value: Default trace log files disabled

data.name: SDR-SC5_Finding
data.value: Default trace log files are disabled

data.name: SDR-SC5_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Default tracing tracks information about configuration and DDL changes to the SQL Server. This information may be useful when troubleshooting issues with the database engine.

data.name: SDR-SC5_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the default trace be enabled.

data.name: SDR-SC6_Category
data.value: Server Configuration

data.name: SDR-SC6_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/aLrJAj

data.name: SDR-SC6_Description
data.value: Disallow Results from Triggers is OFF

data.name: SDR-SC6_Finding
data.value: Disallow results from triggers is OFF

data.name: SDR-SC6_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The server is currently configured to allow triggers to return result sets.

data.name: SDR-SC6_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)Triggers that return result sets may cause unexpected behavior in applications that are not designed to work with them. $(li)This option will be removed in a future version of Microsoft SQL Server and triggers will no longer be able to return result sets.

data.name: SDR-SC6_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If your database applications are making use of this feature, it may be undesirable to change this setting. The following error message will be given when this option is set to ON and a result set is returned from a trigger: "Msg 524, Level 16, State 1, Procedure <Procedure Name>, Line <Line#> - A trigger returned a resultset and the server option 'disallow_results_from_triggers' is true." $(li)Result sets are often returned to aid in testing and debugging triggers.

data.name: SDR-SC6_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the ‘Disallow results from triggers’ option be set to ON.

data.name: SDR-SC7_Category
data.value: Server Configuration

data.name: SDR-SC7_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/ayZ9vO

data.name: SDR-SC7_Description
data.value: CLR enabled

data.name: SDR-SC7_Finding
data.value: The Common Language Runtime (CLR) option is enabled

data.name: SDR-SC7_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The CLR Enabled option controls whether user assemblies may be run by SQL Server. CLR cannot be enabled on servers which are using Lightweight Pooling.

data.name: SDR-SC7_Recommendation
data.value: Consider disabling CLR if user assemblies are not used in your environment. Otherwise ignore this recommendation.

data.name: SDR-SC8_Category
data.value: Server Configuration

data.name: SDR-SC8_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9EoQfg

data.name: SDR-SC8_Description
data.value: McAfee buffer overflow protection detected

data.name: SDR-SC8_Finding
data.value: McAfee Buffer Overflow Protection may cause SQL Server to lock up

data.name: SDR-SC8_Impact_Explanation
data.value: McAfee Buffer Overflow Protection may inject a thread into SQL Server which may cause SQL Server to become unresponsive.

data.name: SDR-SC8_Recommendation
data.value: Ensure all updates to McAfee Virus scan are applied. You may need to disable Buffer Overflow Protection.

data.name: SDR-SC9_Category
data.value: Server Configuration

data.name: SDR-SC9_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/ba7R6T

data.name: SDR-SC9_Description
data.value: Non-standard network packet size

data.name: SDR-SC9_Finding
data.value: Network Packet Size ($(CurrentValue) B) is a non-standard value

data.name: SDR-SC9_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The default Network Packet Size is 4,096 bytes, with the maximum recommended value 8,060 bytes. SQL Server performs different memory allocation operations for values above 8,060 which can cause an increase in the process virtual address space that is not reserved for the buffer pool.

data.name: SDR-SC9_Recommendation
data.value: If there is not a specific reason that the network packet size has been set outside of the customary range, consider setting the size back to the default of 4,096.

data.name: SDR-SF1_Category
data.value: System Page Files

data.name: SDR-SF1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9D1qwj

data.name: SDR-SF1_Finding
data.value: The system page file is incorrectly sized

data.name: SDR-SF1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: When a process asks for MEM_COMMIT memory via the VirtualAlloc API, physical pages of memory are allocated and space is reserved in the page file. Errors 801 and 802 will eventually be entered in the SQL Server’s error log when the memory cannot be successfully reserved.

data.name: SDR-SF1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that even on systems that do not page, the page file size should still be 1.5 times the size of the physical memory. The total available system page file size is xxx.xGB and the server has xxx.xGB of physical memory.

data.name: SDR-UG1_Category
data.value: System Upgrade Suggestion

data.name: SDR-UG1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/9m5FCp

data.name: SDR-UG1_Finding
data.value: Upgrading certain system components may improve performance

data.name: SDR-UG1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The list below shows ranks the system components by the amount of stress they are under. Upgrading the system will improve your overall performance: 1. The I/O subsystem – (generating xx% of the waits), 2. The Network subsystem – (generating xx% of the waits), 3. The Memory subsystem – (generating xx% of the waits), 4. The CPU subsystem – (generating xx% of the waits)

data.name: SDR-UG1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the waits for the various components should be examined and, if found to be excessive, upgraded to improve system performance.

data.name: SDR-VL1_Category
data.value: Virtual Log Files

data.name: SDR-VL1_bitly
data.value: http://bit.ly/bCtPRS

data.name: SDR-VL1_Finding
data.value: The following databases have highly fragmented transaction logs: $(li) Database xxx – xxx virtual log files $(li)Database xxx – xxx virtual log files

data.name: SDR-VL1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Fragmentation occurs where the transaction log file was initially incorrectly sized far too small and has gone through many rounds of autogrowth. Fragmented transaction log files containing many virtual log files can significantly slow performance and should be corrected.

data.name: SDR-VL1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that these transaction log files be defragmented and their size increased to improve performance.

data.name: SDR-VL1_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) databases have highly fragmented transaction log files

data.name: SDR-W1_Category
data.value: Wait Stats

data.name: SDR-W1_Description
data.value: High CXPACKET and PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits

data.name: SDR-W1_Finding
data.value: High CXPACKET and PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits

data.name: SDR-W1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The CXPACKET and PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits were found among the highest waits experienced during the analysis.

data.name: SDR-W1_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)CXPACKET waits occur when a parallel query is executed and one or more threads have to wait for another thread to complete. The time spent in the waiting threads of the parallel query is the time that is measured by CXPACKET waits. When CXPACKET waits are high, this could be an indication that the query optimizer could not properly estimate equal amounts of work for each of the parallel threads.$(li)PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits occur when a data page was not found in the buffer pool and a physical I/O must be performed to read the page into the buffer pool. When PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits are high, this could be an indication that a large number of data pages are being loaded into the buffer pool from disk to satisfy various queries.$(li)When both CXPACKET and PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits are high, this could mean that there are parallelized queries performing large table scans and the query optimizer was not able to correctly parallelize the query into equal sets for each of the parallel threads. This can occur when the query optimizer cannot find a suitable non-clustered index to speed up the query, possibly because no such index exists, the index statistics are out-of-date, a function is used on a column within a query filter predicate, or an implicit conversion is occurring within a query filter predicate. Additionally, fragmentation could be a contributing factor due to the fragmentation causing an inefficient read-ahead for index range scans.

data.name: SDR-W1_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)CXPACKET waits should not be seen as a problem. They are only an indication of parallel query execution. $(li)PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits should not be seen as a problem. They are only an indication that waits occurred when data pages are being read into the buffer pool.$(li)If no performance problems have been experienced by any of the ‘Affected Batches,’ then the CXPACKET and PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits may be negligible.

data.name: SDR-W1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you review the ‘Affected Batches’ below and consider the following: $(li)Update the relevant statistics objects to improve query plan generation $(li)Rebuild highly fragmented indexes for the tables used by the ‘Affected Batches’$(li)Revise filter criteria to prevent implicit conversions which could be causing table scans$(li)Add missing indexes to prevent excessive I/O $(li)As a last resort, you may want to try reducing MAXDOP for the offending queries within the ‘Affected Batches.’ If you have a NUMA system, then try setting MAXDOP equal to the number of processor cores available in a single NUMA node.$(li)Evaluate the plan cost and execution frequency to determine if the server configuration option “cost threshold for parallelism” should be adjusted to prevent SQL Server from using parallelism in execution plans which do not benefit from it.$(li)Review the sys.dm_io_virtual_file_stats DMV output to determine whether the I/O characteristics have changed from your I/O subsystem baseline measurements.

data.name: SDR-W2_Category
data.value: Wait Stats

data.name: SDR-W2_Description
data.value: Parallelism threshold too low

data.name: SDR-W2_Finding
data.value: High CXPACKET waits with the parallelism threshold set below recommended levels

data.name: SDR-W2_Impact_Explanation
data.value: High CXPACKET waits were found and the Cost Threshold for Parallelism configuration value of $(CurrentThreshold) is set below the recommended level of $(RecommendedThreshold).

data.name: SDR-W2_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)This can cause queries to become parallelized that would not benefit from parallel execution. These extra parallel queries may be contributing to higher CXPACKET waits which occur when parallel queries are executed. $(li)Short running queries do not benefit from parallelism because the additional time required to initialize, synchronize, and terminate parallel plans can outweigh the benefits of distributing the workload across multiple processors.

data.name: SDR-W2_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If the performance benefit of parallelizing the short running queries outweighs the overhead required to initialize, synchronize, and terminate the parallel plans.

data.name: SDR-W2_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the ‘Cost Threshold for Parallelism’ configuration value should be increased to $(RecommendedThreshold) or higher.

data.name: SDR-W3_Category
data.value: Wait Stats

data.name: SDR-W3_Description
data.value: CXPACKET waits with current max degree of parallelism setting

data.name: SDR-W3_Finding
data.value: High CXPACKET waits found with the current max degree of parallelism setting

data.name: SDR-W3_Impact_Explanation
data.value: CXPACKET waits are among the highest waits found during the analysis and the current max degree of parallelism setting is $(CurrentMaxDOP).

data.name: SDR-W3_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)An incorrectly configured ‘max degree of parallelism’ can cause inefficiencies with parallel query execution by requiring more CPU cores for the parallel plan than physically available at the time of execution.$(li)A single query could monopolize all available CPU cores and prevent other queries from running.

data.name: SDR-W3_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If the current ‘max degree of parallelism’ has been tuned for the current hardware and workload requirements of the SQL Server instance.$(li)If you are not experiencing poor performance from parallelized queries or parallel queries are not monopolizing CPU usage, then the CXPACKET waits described above may be negligible in your environment.

data.name: SDR-W3_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the ‘Max Degree of Parallelism’ configuration option should be set to a value not exceeding half the number of available physical processor cores, ignoring any logical CPUs from hyper-threading. If you have a NUMA system, then try setting ‘Max Degree of Parallelism’ equal to the number of processor cores available in a single NUMA node. Also, no matter how many cores are available the parameter should not be set above eight.

data.name: SDR-W4_Category
data.value: Wait Stats

data.name: SDR-W4_Description
data.value: High CXPACKET waits

data.name: SDR-W4_Finding
data.value: The server is experiencing high CXPACKET waits

data.name: SDR-W4_Impact_Explanation
data.value: CXPACKET waits are among the highest waits found during the analysis. These waits are occur when multiple threads are used to run a query in parallel and one or more of the threads lag behind causing the other threads to wait.

data.name: SDR-W4_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)The query optimizer may not be able to properly estimate the cost of the parallel query plans. $(li)Indexes may be highly fragmented. Highly fragmented indexes can cause inefficiencies with range scans because the SQL Server read-ahead logic is unable to read large page ranges into memory with single I/O requests. Instead, a greater number of smaller IO requests may be performed which can slow down one or more of the parallel threads.$(li)Statistics may be out-of-date. Without up-to-date statistics, the query optimizer cannot properly estimate query plan costs, causing one or more threads to get a disproportionate amount of work to perform.$(li)Query filter predicates may contain functions on column values forcing a scan to be used instead of a seek.$(li)Query filter predicates may be causing an implicit conversion of a column value because of mismatched data types.

data.name: SDR-W4_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If you are not experiencing poor performance from parallelized queries, then the CXPACKET waits described above may be negligible in your environment.

data.name: SDR-W4_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you review the server activity and consider the following: $(li)Rebuild highly fragmented indexes to improve read-ahead performance for range scans$(li)Update the relevant statistics objects to improve query plan generation $(li)Revise filter criteria to prevent implicit conversions which could be causing index/table scans$(li)Revise filter criteria to prevent functions from being used on columns which could be causing index/table scans$(li)Add missing indexes to improve performance of queries$(li)Reduce MAXDOP for the offending queries. If you have a NUMA system, then try setting MAXDOP equal to the number of processor cores available in a single NUMA node.

data.name: SDR-W5_Category
data.value: Wait Stats

data.name: SDR-W5_Description
data.value: High ASYNC_NETWORK_IO waits

data.name: SDR-W5_Finding
data.value: The server is experiencing high ASYNC_NETWORK_IO waits

data.name: SDR-W5_Impact_Explanation
data.value: High ASYNC_NETWORK_IO waits normally indicate one or more applications are not pulling result sets fast enough from the SQL Server instance. This could also be an indication of network performance problems.

data.name: SDR-W5_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you review the Affected Batches and ensure the following: $(li)The applications are processing the result sets efficiently $(li)The queries are not pulling more data than needed by the calling application $(li)The SQL Server instance is not experiencing network problems $(li)The client machines hosting the calling applications are not experiencing network problems

data.name: SDR-W6_Category
data.value: Wait Stats

data.name: SDR-W6_Description
data.value: High THREADPOOL waits

data.name: SDR-W6_Finding
data.value: The server is experiencing high THREADPOOL waits due to the Max Worker Threads option being too low

data.name: SDR-W6_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The Max Worker Threads option is set too low causing high THREADPOOL waits. This is causing tasks to wait too long for worker threads to become available.

data.name: SDR-W6_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you change the Max Worker Threads option to zero. This will allow the SQL Server Database Engine to calculate the optimal number of threads.

data.name: SDR-W7_Category
data.value: Wait Stats

data.name: SDR-W7_Description
data.value: High PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits

data.name: SDR-W7_Finding
data.value: Database [$(Database)] is experiencing high PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits

data.name: SDR-W7_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The queries using database [$(Database)] may be impacted by PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits. PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits occur when a data page was not found in the buffer pool and a physical I/O must be performed to read the page into the buffer pool. When PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits are high, this could be an indication that a large number of data pages are being loaded into the buffer pool from disk to satisfy various queries.

data.name: SDR-W7_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)This may be an indication of poorly optimized queries. Queries which are defined without search predicates or cannot find an efficient index to use may require a scan of all data pages for the table. This can cause excessive I/O and contribute to the PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits.$(li)Query filter predicates may be causing an implicit conversion to occur on a column value due to mismatched data types.$(li)Query filter predicates may contain functions on column values forcing a scan to be used instead of a seek.$(li)This may be an indication of out-of-date statistics. Without up-to-date statistics, the query optimizer cannot generate an efficient execution plan due to inaccurate cost estimates. This can cause the query optimizer to choose an inefficient data access path and generate additional I/O which can contribute to the PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits.$(li)Fragmentation can contribute to longer PAGEIOLATCH_XX wait times when index range scans are performed because the SQL Server read-ahead logic may have to perform single page I/O requests instead of larger multi-page I/O requests.$(li)This may be an indication that the buffer pool is under high pressure due to large table scans or because a large number of dirty pages exist in the buffer pool that must first be written to disk before new data can be loaded. This slowdown due to flushing out existing pages from the buffer pool can contribute to the time spent in the PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits.$(li)This could indicate that the workload requirements for the server are too high based on the available amount of buffer pool memory.$(li)PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits can result when problems or bottlenecks exists within the disk subsystem.

data.name: SDR-W7_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)When the server is ‘warming up,’ there will be a significant amount of PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits due to SQL Server loading needed pages into the buffer pool. High PAGEIOLATCH_XX should normally be ignored until the SQL Server instance has had a chance to run long enough to load the most often needed data pages into the buffer pool.$(li)When executing large reports that require large table scans or index range scans.$(li)If you are not experiencing poor performance from any of the affected batches, then the waits described above may be negligible in your environment.

data.name: SDR-W7_Recommendation
data.value: You should consider the following:$(li)Review all query optimization recommendations to determine if efficiency changes can be made to the queries. $(li)Revise filter criteria to prevent implicit conversions which could be causing index/table scans$(li)Revise filter criteria to prevent functions from being used on columns which could be causing index/table scans$(li)Ensure statistics are up-to-date. Without up-to-date statistics, the query optimizer will not be able to generate an efficient execution plan and could potentially cause the query to perform an excessive amount of I/O.$(li)Ensure large indexes are not highly fragmented. Fragmented indexes reduce the efficiency of the read-ahead logic used for index range scans.$(li)Review all missing indexes to determine if new indexes can be added to improve query performance and reduce the amount of I/O required to satisfy the workload requirements.$(li)Review memory recommendations to ensure SQL Server is configured correctly for optimum memory performance.$(li)Review disk recommendations to determine if optimizations can be made to improve I/O performance on the drives hosting the database data files.$(li)Review the sys.dm_io_virtual_file_stats DMV output to determine whether the I/O characteristics have changed from your I/O subsystem baseline measurements.

data.name: SDR-W7_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) databases are experiencing high PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits

data.name: SDR-W7_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Queries may be impacted by PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits. PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits occur when a data page was not found in the buffer pool and a physical I/O must be performed to read the page into the buffer pool. When PAGEIOLATCH_XX waits are high, this could be an indication that a large number of data pages are being loaded into the buffer pool from disk to satisfy various queries.

data.name: SDR-W7_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: You should consider the following:$(li)Review all query optimization recommendations to determine if efficiency changes can be made to the queries. $(li)Revise filter criteria to prevent implicit conversions which could be causing index/table scans$(li)Revise filter criteria to prevent functions from being used on columns which could be causing index/table scans$(li)Ensure statistics are up-to-date. Without up-to-date statistics, the query optimizer will not be able to generate an efficient execution plan and could potentially cause the query to perform an excessive amount of I/O.$(li)Ensure large indexes are not highly fragmented. Fragmented indexes reduce the efficiency of the read-ahead logic used for index range scans.$(li)Review all missing indexes to determine if new indexes can be added to improve query performance and reduce the amount of I/O required to satisfy the workload requirements.$(li)Review memory recommendations to ensure SQL Server is configured correctly for optimum memory performance.$(li)Review disk recommendations to determine if optimizations can be made to improve I/O performance on the drives hosting the database data files.$(li)Review the sys.dm_io_virtual_file_stats DMV output to determine whether the I/O characteristics have changed from your I/O subsystem baseline measurements.

data.name: SDR-W8_Category
data.value: Wait Stats

data.name: SDR-W8_Description
data.value: High PAGELATCH_EX and PAGELATCH_SH waits on index

data.name: SDR-W8_Finding
data.value: $(IndexId>1?Index [$(IndexName)]:Clustered index) on table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] is experiencing high PAGELATCH_EX and/or PAGELATCH_SH waits

data.name: SDR-W8_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The performance of the $(IndexId>1?index [$(IndexName)]:clustered index) on table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] is adversely impacted by PAGELATCH_EX and/or PAGELATCH_SH waits.

data.name: SDR-W8_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)When PAGELATCH_EX or PAGELATCH_SH waits occur on an index this can be an indication of contention on the same index range by concurrent inserts or updates. If concurrent inserts/updates are made to the same page, the operations are serialized using latches.$(li)These inserts/updates can also cause page splits that keep the latch while allocating the new page which will take additional time to complete. Additionally, reads accessing these pages would conflict with the latches causing additional waits.

data.name: SDR-W8_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If you are not experiencing poor performance from operations on this index, then the waits described above may be negligible in your environment.

data.name: SDR-W8_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the index be reviewed to determine if it can be restructured in order to distribute the range being inserted across multiple partitions. If your SQL Server version does not support index partitioning, then it is recommended that the index be reviewed to determine if the columns of the index key can be changed so that the inserts are distributed across the pages of the index. If page splits are impacting the index, the fill factor of the index should be adjusted to reduce the occurrence of the page splits.

data.name: SDR-W8_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) indexes are experiencing high PAGELATCH_EX and/or PAGELATCH_SH waits

data.name: SDR-W8_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Index performance is being adversely impacted by PAGELATCH_EX and/or PAGELATCH_SH waits. This can be an indication of contention on the same index range by concurrent inserts. If concurrent inserts are being made to the same page, the inserts are serialized using latches. These inserts can also cause page splits that keeps the latch while allocating the new page which will take additional time to complete. Additionally, reads accessing these pages would conflict with the latches causing additional waits.

data.name: SDR-W8_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the index be reviewed to determine if it can be restructured in order to distribute the range being inserted across multiple partitions. If your SQL Server version does not support index partitioning, then it is recommended that the index be reviewed to determine if the columns of the index key can be changed so that the inserts are distributed across the pages of the index. If page splits are impacting the index, the fill factor of the index should be adjusted to reduce the occurrence of the page splits.

data.name: SDR-W9_Category
data.value: Wait Stats

data.name: SDR-W9_Description
data.value: High PAGELATCH_EX and PAGELATCH_SH waits on table

data.name: SDR-W9_Finding
data.value: Table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] is experiencing high PAGELATCH_EX and/or PAGELATCH_SH waits

data.name: SDR-W9_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The performance of table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] is adversely impacted by PAGELATCH_EX and/or PAGELATCH_SH waits.

data.name: SDR-W9_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)PAGELATCH_EX or PAGELATCH_SH waits that occur on a table can be an indication of contention for access to the data pages by concurrent inserts/updates. If concurrent inserts/updates are made to the same page, the operations are serialized using latches. Additionally, reads accessing these pages would conflict with the latches causing additional waits.

data.name: SDR-W9_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If you are not experiencing poor performance from operations on this table, then the waits described above may be negligible in your environment.

data.name: SDR-W9_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the table be reviewed to determine if it can be restructured in order to distribute the range being inserted across multiple partitions. If your SQL Server version does not support table partitioning, then it is recommended that the table be reviewed to determine if a clustered index can be created on the table so that the inserts are distributed across the pages of the index.

data.name: SDR-W9_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) tables are experiencing high PAGELATCH_EX and/or PAGELATCH_SH waits

data.name: SDR-W9_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Table performance is being adversely impacted by PAGELATCH_EX and/or PAGELATCH_SH waits. This can be an indication of contention for access to the data pages by concurrent inserts/updates. If concurrent inserts/updates are made to the same page, the operations are serialized using latches. Additionally, reads accessing these pages would conflict with the latches causing additional waits.

data.name: SDR-W9_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the table be reviewed to determine if it can be restructured in order to distribute the range being inserted across multiple partitions. If your SQL Server version does not support table partitioning, then it is recommended that the table be reviewed to determine if a clustered index can be created on the table so that the inserts are distributed across the pages of the index.

data.name: SDR-W10_Category
data.value: Wait Stats

data.name: SDR-W10_Description
data.value: High PAGELATCH_UP waits

data.name: SDR-W10_Finding
data.value: Database [$(Database)] is experiencing high PAGELATCH_UP waits

data.name: SDR-W10_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The performance of database [$(Database)] is adversely impacted by PAGELATCH_UP waits.

data.name: SDR-W10_Problem_Explanation
data.value: $(li)This indicates that contention is occurring due to updates made on allocation pages and is usually a sign that more files are needed for the database. Having multiple files will allow the allocations to be distributed which will reduce the demands on the allocation pages within the existing files.

data.name: SDR-W10_Additional_Considerations
data.value: $(li)If you are not experiencing poor performance from operations on this database, then the waits described above may be negligible in your environment.

data.name: SDR-W10_Recommendation
data.value:
You should consider adding more files to database [$(Database)]. This will allow for additional distribution of updates to allocation pages. SQL Server’s proportional fill algorithm will allocate based on the amount of free space in each of the files proportionately, so new files should be created with the size proportional to the amount of free space in the existing data files. Additionally, if the data files are allowed to autogrow, then the autogrowth settings should be equalized across all data files.
However, adding a new file with significantly more free space can result in a hot spot on that file and continued PAGELATCH_UP waits.

data.name: SDR-W10_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) databases are experiencing high PAGELATCH_UP waits

data.name: SDR-W10_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Database performance is being adversely impacted by PAGELATCH_UP waits. This indicates that contention is occurring due to updates being made on allocation pages and is usually a sign that more files are needed for the database. Having multiple files will allow the allocations to be distributed which will reduce the demands on the allocation pages within the existing files.

data.name: SDR-W10_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value:
You should consider adding more files to the database. This will allow for additional distribution of updates to allocation pages. SQL Server’s proportional fill algorithm will allocate based on the amount of free space in each of the files proportionately, so new files should be created with the size proportional to the amount of free space in the existing data files. Additionally, if the data files are allowed to autogrow, then the autogrowth settings should be equalized across all data files.
However, adding a new file with significantly more free space can result in a hot spot on that file and continued PAGELATCH_UP waits.

data.name: SDR-R1_Category
data.value: Disaster Recovery

data.name: SDR-R1_Description
data.value: Database has suspect pages

data.name: SDR-R1_Finding
data.value: Database [$(Database)] has suspect pages

data.name: SDR-R1_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Suspect pages have been found in database [$(Database)] based on information in the msdb..suspect_pages table. The pages for this database are suspected of being bad, but may be fine.

data.name: SDR-R1_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that DBCC CHECKDB be run against database [$(Database)] with the NO_INFOMSGS option so that only error messages are shown. These error messages should be reviewed and researched using SQL Server Books Online.

data.name: SDR-R1_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) databases have suspect pages

data.name: SDR-R1_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Suspect pages have been found based on information in the msdb..suspect_pages table. The pages for the databases are suspected of being bad, but may be fine.

data.name: SDR-R1_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that you run DBCC CHECKDB against the database with the NO_INFOMSGS option so that only error messages are shown. These error messages should be reviewed and researched using SQL Server Books Online.

data.name: SDR-R2_Category
data.value: Disaster Recovery

data.name: SDR-R2_Description
data.value: Backups should be on separate volumes

data.name: SDR-R2_Finding
data.value: Backups for database [$(Database)] are on the same volume as the data files

data.name: SDR-R2_Impact_Explanation
data.value: If the device containing the database fails, neither the data files nor backup files will be available. Additionally, using separate devices will optimize the I/O performance for the database while backups are being performed.

data.name: SDR-R2_Recommendation
data.value:
Is is recommended that the database data files and backup files be stored on separate devices, such as two different physical disks. Note that this analysis only checks logical volumes. While the analysis considers each logical volume as a unique device, mount points are not identified as unique devices. Verify that each logical volume and mount point is located on a separate physical device.
It is also recommended that you check the database backup history to ensure it correctly reflects the locations of your data files and backup files. To clean your backup history, run the sp_delete_database_backuphistory stored procedure.

data.name: SDR-R2_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) databases should be on separate volumes

data.name: SDR-R2_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: If the device containing the database fails, neither the data files nor backup files will be available. Additionally, using separate devices will optimize the IO performance for the database while backups are being performed.

data.name: SDR-R2_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: Is is recommended that the database data files and backup files be placed on separate devices.

data.name: SDR-R3_Category
data.value: Disaster Recovery

data.name: SDR-R3_Description
data.value: Database integrity should be checked

data.name: SDR-R3_Finding
data.value: The integrity of database [$(Database)] has not been checked in $(DaysSinceLastCheck) days

data.name: SDR-R3_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The physical integrity of a database [$(Database)] should be checked regularly to allow for early detection of errors so that downtime and data loss can be minimized.

data.name: SDR-R3_Recommendation
data.value: Is is recommended that you run DBCC CHECKDB against database [$(Database)] to ensure there are no data integrity problems.

data.name: SDR-R3_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: The integrity of $(Count) databases should be checked

data.name: SDR-R3_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The physical integrity of databases should be checked regularly to allow for early detection of errors so that downtime and data loss can be minimized.

data.name: SDR-R3_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: Is is recommended that you run DBCC CHECKDB against the databases to ensure there are no data integrity problems.

data.name: SDR-R4_Category
data.value: Disaster Recovery

data.name: SDR-R4_Description
data.value: Database using Simple recovery model

data.name: SDR-R4_Finding
data.value: Database [$(Database)] is using Simple Recovery Model

data.name: SDR-R4_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Using Simple Recovery Model for database [$(Database)] prevents point-in-time recovery which will increase the amount of data loss in the event of a disaster recovery.

data.name: SDR-R4_Recommendation
data.value: Is is recommended that Full Recovery Model is used on all production databases and that frequent transaction log backups are taken. This will ensure recoverability with minimal loss of data.

data.name: SDR-R4_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) databases are using Simple Recovery Model

data.name: SDR-R4_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Using Simple Recovery Model for databases prevents point-in-time recovery which will increase the amount of data loss in the event of a disaster recovery.

data.name: SDR-R4_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: Is is recommended that you use Full Recovery Model on all production databases and that frequent transaction log backups are taken. This will ensure recoverability with minimal loss of data.

data.name: SDR-R5_Category
data.value: Disaster Recovery

data.name: SDR-R5_Description
data.value: Database has outdated backups

data.name: SDR-R5_Finding
data.value: Database [$(Database)] has outdated backups

data.name: SDR-R5_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Up-to-date backups are not available for database [$(Database)]. The lack of backups will hinder the ability to recover the database in the event of a disaster recovery.

data.name: SDR-R5_Recommendation
data.value: Is is recommended that a database maintenance plan be put in place to keep the database backups up to date.

data.name: SDR-R5_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) databases have outdated backups

data.name: SDR-R5_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Up to date backups are not available for databases. The lack of backups will hinder the ability to recover the databases in the event of a disaster recovery.

data.name: SDR-R5_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: Is is recommended that a database maintenance plan be put in place to keep the database backups up-to-date.

data.name: SDR-R6_Category
data.value: Disaster Recovery

data.name: SDR-R6_Description
data.value: Recent backup file has been deleted or moved

data.name: SDR-R6_Finding
data.value: The most recent backup for database [$(Database)] has been deleted or moved to another location.

data.name: SDR-R6_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The most recent backup for database [$(Database)] had been written to [$(FileName)], but this file no longer exists. Without this file, you will not be able to fully recover your database to its most recent state.

data.name: SDR-R6_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that at least one recent backup set be maintained on disk for fast and accurate recovery. To ensure you will be able to restore this database in the event of a disaster recovery, identify the alternate location of this backup set or perform a new backup.

data.name: SDR-R6_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) databases are missing backup files

data.name: SDR-R6_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Recent backups no longer exist for $(Count) databases on this server. Without these files, you will not be able to fully recover your databases to their most recent states.

data.name: SDR-R6_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that at least one recent backup set for each database be maintained on disk for fast and accurate recovery. To ensure you will be able to restore your databases in the event of a disaster recovery, identify the alternate location of these backup sets or perform new backups.

data.name: SDR-R7_Category
data.value: Disaster Recovery

data.name: SDR-R7_Description
data.value: Database transaction log has not been backed up recently

data.name: SDR-R7_Finding
data.value: Database [$(Database)] is set to [$(RecoveryMode)] recovery mode, and the transaction log has not been backed up in [$(Age)] days.

data.name: SDR-R7_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Databases that do not use the simple recovery model maintain a log of the transactions performed on that database. If the transaction log is not backed up regularly, the log files can become very large and point-in-time recovery becomes impossible.

data.name: SDR-R7_Recommendation
data.value: For those databases that maintain transaction logs, it is recommended that your maintenance plans include periodic transaction log backups to checkpoint the log and remove inactive transactions. Full, differential, and filegroup backups do not remove inactive transactions from the log, nor can they be used for point-in-time recovery. For databases that do not require point-in-time recovery, use the simple recovery model to prevent unnecessary growth of the transaction log over time.

data.name: SDR-R7_Plural_Form_Finding
data.value: $(Count) databases maintain a transaction log which has not been backed up recently

data.name: SDR-R7_Plural_Form_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Databases that do not use the simple recovery model maintain a log of the transactions performed on that database. If the transaction log is not backed up regularly, the log files can become very large and point-in-time recovery becomes impossible.

data.name: SDR-R7_Plural_Form_Recommendation
data.value: For those databases that maintain transaction logs, it is recommended that your maintenance plans include periodic transaction log backups to checkpoint the log and remove inactive transactions. Full, differential, and filegroup backups do not remove inactive transactions from the log, nor can they be used for point-in-time recovery. For databases that do not require point-in-time recovery, use the simple recovery model to prevent unnecessary growth of the transaction log over time.
