data.name: SDR-Q37_Additional_Considerations
data.value: This may not be a problem if there are other reasons that a lower database compatibility level is being used.

data.name: SDR-Q37_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q37_Description
data.value: Trace flag 4199 is enabled globally for SQL Server 2016 and there are databases running in compatibility level 120 or lower.

data.name: SDR-Q37_Finding
data.value: Trace flag 4199 is enabled globally for SQL Server 2016 and there are databases running in compatibility level 120 or lower.

data.name: SDR-Q37_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Trace flag 4199 is enabled globally for SQL Server 2016 and there are databases running in compatibility level 120 or lower.

data.name: SDR-Q37_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>KB974006: SQL Server query optimizer hotfix trace flag 4199 servicing model: </Title><Link>https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/974006 </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-Q37_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Trace flag 4199 is a catch-all trace flag that was implemented to enable select query optimizer enhancements. Beginning with SQL Server 2016, these enhancements are enabled by default for databases in compatibility level 130 (SQL Server 2016) and only new query optimizer enhancements will be implemented via trace flag 4199. The behavior of trace flag 4199 is tied to the compatibility level of the database beginning with SQL Server 2016. Because someone may choose to upgrade the compatibility level of the database without realizing that it will affect the query optimizer behavior, we recommend upgrading the compatibility level and removing the trace flag in a controlled manner where any behavior changes can be tested thoroughly. Once the compatibility level is raised to level 130, the trace flag may invoke new, unexpected behaviors and the trace flag should be removed unless there is a specific query optimizer fix for SQL Server 2016 that is needed.

data.name: SDR-Q37_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the database compatibility level of all databases on SQL Server 2016 be raised to level 130 and trace flag 4199 be removed unless there is a specific query optimizer fix for SQL Server 2016 enabled under this trace flag that is needed.

data.name: SDR-Q38_Additional_Considerations
data.value: This may not be a problem if there have been new query optimizer enhancements created after the release of SQL Server 2016 that are verified as needed for the existing instance.

data.name: SDR-Q38_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q38_Description
data.value: Trace flag 4199 is enabled globally for SQL Server 2016 and all databases are running in compatibility level 130.

data.name: SDR-Q38_Finding
data.value: Trace flag 4199 is enabled globally for SQL Server 2016 and all databases are running in compatibility level 130.

data.name: SDR-Q38_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Trace flag 4199 is enabled globally for SQL Server 2016 and all databases are running in compatibility level 130.

data.name: SDR-Q38_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>KB974006: SQL Server query optimizer hotfix trace flag 4199 servicing model: </Title><Link>https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/974006 </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-Q38_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Trace flag 4199 is a catch-all trace flag that was implemented to enable select query optimizer enhancements. Beginning with SQL Server 2016, these enhancements are enabled by default for databases in compatibility level 130 (SQL Server 2016) and only new query optimizer enhancements will be implemented via trace flag 4199. The behavior of trace flag 4199 is tied to the compatibility level of the database beginning with SQL Server 2016. For databases running in compatibility level 130, the previous query optimizer enhancements enabled under trace flag 4199 will be enabled by default. If new query optimizer enhancements are implemented after the release of SQL Server 2016, they may be implemented via trace flag 4199. Because new query optimizer enhancements may be enabled with trace flag 4199, we recommend removing the trace flag to avoid invoking new, unexpected behaviors unless there is a specific query optimizer fix for SQL Server 2016 that is needed.

data.name: SDR-Q38_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that race flag 4199 be removed unless there is a specific query optimizer fix for SQL Server 2016 enabled under this trace flag that is needed and all databases are running at compatibility level 130.

data.name: SDR-I23_Additional_Considerations
data.value: This may not be a problem if the statistics are filtered so that they only contain rows from the active partitions.

data.name: SDR-I23_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I23_Description
data.value: Partitioned table has column statistics that are not incremental.

data.name: SDR-I23_Finding
data.value: Partitioned table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] has column statistics [$(StatsName)] that are not incremental.

data.name: SDR-I23_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Partitioned table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] has column statistics [$(StatsName)] that are not incremental.

data.name: SDR-I23_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>BOL article What’s New (Database Engine): Incremental Statistics: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb510411%28v=sql.120%29.aspx#Stats </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-I23_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Partitioned tables are often a mixture of static, historical data and new, changing data. Because changes may be occurring in only a few partitions, statistics for some partitions may not be updated frequently enough to properly represent the changes of data in those active partitions. Additionally, with non-incremental statistics, the stats have a very high overhead for maintenance due to the need to update stats for the entire table, even the non-changing partitions.

data.name: SDR-I23_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that for table-wide, non-incremental column statistics on partitioned tables, the statistics should be dropped and replaced with incremental statistics. Incremental statistics are created and maintained per partition allowing statistics on active partitions to be automatically updated based on changes to their own partition and for statistics updates to be completed much quicker as they are updated per partitions.

data.name: SDR-I25_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It is not a problem if the table is very small.

data.name: SDR-I25_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I25_Description
data.value: A memory-optimized hash index has too few buckets.

data.name: SDR-I25_Finding
data.value: A memory-optimized hash index [$(Name)] on table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] has too few buckets.

data.name: SDR-I25_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A memory-optimized hash index [$(Name)] on table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] has too few buckets.

data.name: SDR-I25_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Determining the Correct Bucket Count for Hash Indexes: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn494956.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-I25_Problem_Explanation
data.value: When there are too few buckets for a hash index, searches can be significantly slower. The hashing function only resolves which bucket a particular record is in, and all records in a selected bucket (bucket chain) must be read to find the correct rows. The more rows there are in a bucket (the longer the bucket chain), the more data that must be inspected to find the correct rows. Too many rows per bucket will hinder search performance. Additionally, long bucket chains due to too few buckets for an index can hinder recovery time and make database startup slow.

data.name: SDR-I25_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the bucket count be between 1 and 2 times the number of unique index key values with the actual value being closer to 2 times. The empty bucket count in index [$(Name)] on table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] has an empty bucket count of less than 10% indicating that it likely has too few buckets for this index. It is recommended that you recreate the table with a larger number of buckets equaling 2 times the expected number of unique index key values. Memory-optimized indexes cannot be altered and changing the bucket count requires recreating the table.

data.name: SDR-I26_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It is not a problem if the table is very small.

data.name: SDR-I26_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I26_Description
data.value: There are many duplicate key values in a memory-optimized hash index.

data.name: SDR-I26_Finding
data.value: There are many duplicate key values in a memory-optimized hash index [$(Name)] on table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-I26_Impact_Explanation
data.value: There are many duplicate key values in a memory-optimized hash index [$(Name)] on table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-I26_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Determining the Correct Bucket Count for Hash Indexes: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn494956.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-I26_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Duplicate key values in a hash index get hashed to the same bucket which can create long bucket chains (chain of records in a single bucket) that hinders search performance. All records in a selected bucket (bucket chain) must be read to find the correct rows. The more rows there are in a bucket (the longer the bucket chain), the more data that must be inspected to find the correct rows. Too many rows per bucket will hinder search performance. Additionally, long bucket chains for an index can hinder recovery time and make database startup slow.

data.name: SDR-I26_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that when the key columns of an index have a lot of duplicate values that a non-hashed memory-optimized nonclustered index be used rather than a hash index. Memory-optimized indexes cannot be altered and changing the index type requires recreating the table with the changed indexes.

data.name: SDR-I28_Additional_Considerations
data.value: This is not a problem if the high empty bucket count is due to planning for expected growth of the data of the table and the table is expected to grow into the bucket count.

data.name: SDR-I28_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I28_Description
data.value: A memory-optimized hash index has too many buckets.

data.name: SDR-I28_Finding
data.value: A memory-optimized hash index [$(Name)] on table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] has too many buckets.

data.name: SDR-I28_Impact_Explanation
data.value: A memory-optimized hash index [$(Name)] on table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] has too many buckets.

data.name: SDR-I28_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Determining the Correct Bucket Count for Hash Indexes: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn494956.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-I28_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Unlike pages in disk-based indexes, all hash buckets are maintained in memory, even empty buckets. Every bucket uses 8 bytes of space in memory. An index with a large number of empty buckets can consume a lot of memory that could be used for other purposes.

data.name: SDR-I28_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the bucket count be between 1 and 2 times the number of unique index key values with the actual value being closer to 2 times. The empty bucket count in index [$(Name)] on table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] has an empty bucket count of greater than 67% indicating that it likely has too many buckets for this index. The empty buckets in this index are consuming ($(EmptyBucketCount) * 8)/1024 KB or ($(EmptyBucketCount) * 8)/1024/1024 MB of memory. If the table is not expected to grow to use a majority of the empty buckets, it is recommended that you recreate the table with a smaller number of buckets equaling 2 times the expected number of unique index key values. Memory-optimized indexes cannot be altered and changing the bucket count requires recreating the table.

data.name: SDR-Q39_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem if the database is not critical or not being actively monitored for performance. Additionally, this feature is not allowed in master and tempdb, and it should only be used in msdb or model if there is a strong compelling performance reason driving the decision. Should not recommend enabling for msdb or model.

data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q39_Description
data.value: The Query Store feature in database [$(Database)] is currently disabled.

data.value: The Query Store feature in database [$(Database)] is currently disabled.

data.name: SDR-Q39_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The Query Store feature in database [$(Database)] is currently disabled.

data.name: SDR-Q39_Problem_Explanation
data.value: The Query Store is a valuable performance tool that provides insight on query plan choice and performance. Additionally, the Query Store provides a better process for freezing and forcing plans for queries with known plan selection issues.

data.name: SDR-Q39_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the Query Store be enabled for database [$(Database)] so query plan performance can be monitored and to ease troubleshooting queries suffering from plan selection issues.

data.name: SDR-Q40_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem if the database is not critical or not being actively monitored for performance.

data.name: SDR-Q40_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q40_Description
data.value: The Query Store in database [$(Database)] is not collecting data because it is out of space.

data.name: SDR-Q40_Finding
data.value: The Query Store in database [$(Database)] is not collecting data because it is out of space.

data.name: SDR-Q40_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The Query Store in database [$(Database)] is not collecting data because it is out of space.

data.name: SDR-Q40_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Monitoring Performance By Using the Query Store: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn817826.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-Q40_Problem_Explanation
data.value: The Query Store is a valuable performance tool that provides insight on query plan choice and performance. Additionally, the Query Store provides a better process for freezing and forcing plans for queries with known plan selection issues. The query store is still functional for some operations in read-only mode, but it is no longer able to collect new data.

data.name: SDR-Q40_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the space issue for Query Store in database [$(Database)] be addressed by cleaning up old data, reducing the amount of data that is stored, or by expanding the amount of space the Query Store is allowed to use. If you clear out data that is stored and the issue reoccurs, it is recommended that you take a permanent approach to addressing the issue by reducing the amount of data saved or by increasing the amount of space the Query Store can use.

data.name: SDR-Q41_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem if the database is not critical or not being actively monitored for performance.

data.name: SDR-Q41_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q41_Description
data.value: The Query Store feature in database [$(Database)] is almost full.

data.name: SDR-Q41_Finding
data.value: The Query Store feature in database [$(Database)] is almost full.

data.name: SDR-Q41_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The Query Store feature in database [$(Database)] is almost full.

data.name: SDR-Q41_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Monitoring Performance By Using the Query Store: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn817826.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-Q41_Problem_Explanation
data.value: The Query Store is a valuable performance tool that provides insight on query plan choice and performance. Additionally, the Query Store provides a better process for freezing and forcing plans for queries with known plan selection issues. If the Query Store runs out of space, it will be switched to read-only state until space is freed up. The query store is still functional for some operations in read-only mode, but it is no longer able to collect new data.

data.name: SDR-Q41_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the space issue for Query Store in database [$(Database)] be addressed by cleaning up old data, reducing the amount of data that is stored, or by expanding the amount of space the Query Store is allowed to use before it runs out of space and switches to a read-only state. If you clear out data that is stored and the issue reoccurs, it is recommended that you take a permanent approach to addressing the issue by reducing the amount of data saved or by increasing the amount of space the Query Store can use.

data.name: SDR-Q42_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem if the data is not expected to change and performance of the forced plan guide is not expected to change over time.

data.name: SDR-Q42_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q42_Description
data.value: Plan guides are being used instead of forcing a plan in the Query Store in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q42_Finding
data.value: Plan guides are being used instead of forcing a plan in the Query Store in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q42_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Plan guides are being used instead of forcing a plan in the Query Store in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q42_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Monitoring Performance By Using the Query Store: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn817826.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-Q42_Problem_Explanation
data.value: The Query Store is a valuable performance tool that provides insight on query plan choice and performance. Additionally, the Query Store provides a better process for freezing and forcing plans for queries with known plan selection issues. The Query Store allows for tracking of forced plan performance over time to easily identify plans that are no longer effective.

data.name: SDR-Q42_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that plan guides be removed and the Query Store in database [$(Database)] be used to evaluate if forcing a plan is still needed. If forcing a plan is still needed, the Query Store should be used to force the best plan for the query.

data.name: SDR-M31_Additional_Considerations
data.value: When the ratio of Max Server Memory setting to buffer pool extension size is no greater than 16 to 1 or when alternate configurations have been tested and performance is acceptable at current thresholds.

data.name: SDR-M31_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M31_Description
data.value: The Buffer Pool Extension size may be too large relative to the size of the in-memory buffer pool.

data.name: SDR-M31_Finding
data.value: The Buffer Pool Extension size may be too large relative to the size of the in-memory buffer pool.

data.name: SDR-M31_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The Buffer Pool Extension size may be too large relative to the size of the in-memory buffer pool.

data.name: SDR-M31_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Buffer Pool Extensions: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn133176.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-M31_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Pages in the buffer pool extension are tracked in system memory, and the overhead of managing a buffer pool extension that is too large in comparison to the buffer pool in memory.

data.name: SDR-M31_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the buffer pool extension size compared to the in-memory buffer pool not exceed a ratio of 16 to 1 with an optimal size between 4 to 1 and 8 to 1 even though the buffer pool extension may be up to 32 times the size of the in-memory buffer pool. It is recommended that the buffer pool extension be thoroughly tested with multiple sizes to determine the best size setting for your workload and server.

data.name: SDR-M32_Additional_Considerations
data.value: This may not be a problem when tests confirm that the benefit of the buffer pool extension is more than the overhead of maintaining it.

data.name: SDR-M32_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M32_Description
data.value: The Buffer Pool Extension feature my not be providing much benefit for this server.

data.name: SDR-M32_Finding
data.value: The Buffer Pool Extension feature my not be providing much benefit for this server.

data.name: SDR-M32_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The Buffer Pool Extension feature my not be providing much benefit for this server.

data.name: SDR-M32_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Buffer Pool Extensions: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn133176.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink><RecommendationLink><Title>Microsoft Data Platform blog post: Buffer Pool Extension to SSDs in SQL Server 2014: </Title><Link>http://blogs.technet.com/b/dataplatforminsider/archive/2013/07/25/buffer-pool-extension-to-ssds-in-sql-server-2014.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-M32_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Because the buffer pool extension stores only the oldest clean buffer pages that would have otherwise been evicted from cache, the overhead of maintaining a really large buffer pool extension may be more than the limited benefit of the buffer pool extension for SQL Servers with a very large in-memory buffer pool.

data.name: SDR-M32_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that for SQL Servers with more than 64 GB of memory allocated to SQL Server (Max Server Memory), the buffer pool extension feature should be thoroughly tested to ensure that the benefit it provides is greater than the overhead of maintaining such a large buffer pool extension.

data.name: SDR-I29_Additional_Considerations
data.value: When additional indexes are not needed or the index is present to support specific queries that are performance-critical but only get executed infrequently.

data.name: SDR-I29_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I29_Description
data.value: There are rarely used indexes on in-memory tables.

data.name: SDR-I29_Finding
data.value: There is a rarely used index [$(Name)] on in-memory table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-I29_Impact_Explanation
data.value: There is a rarely used index [$(Name)] on in-memory table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-I29_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Guidelines for Using Indexes on Memory-Optimized Tables: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn133166.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink><RecommendationLink><Title>Microsoft Data Platform blog post: Buffer Pool Extension to SSDs in SQL Server 2014: </Title><Link>http://blogs.technet.com/b/dataplatforminsider/archive/2013/07/25/buffer-pool-extension-to-ssds-in-sql-server-2014.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-I29_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Indexes that are scanned frequently but return very few rows have a high overhead to maintain them. Often the overhead of maintaining the indexes may hinder performance more than it helps it. Additionally in-memory tables are limited to only 8 indexes, and a different index may be better in its place.

data.name: SDR-I29_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that infrequently used indexes on in-memory tables be evaluated for removal after thorough testing to ensure no critical queries rely on it.

data.name: SDR-Q46_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem if the queries are heavily tuned already.

data.value: Query Optimization

data.value: These queries have the top 10 longest average execution time within the last hour in database [$(Database)].

data.value: These queries have the top 10 longest average execution time within the last hour in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q46_Impact_Explanation
data.value: These queries have the top 10 longest average execution time within the last hour in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q46_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Queries with a long average execution time are prime candidates to be tuned to make them run faster.

data.name: SDR-Q46_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that these queries be investigated to see if they can be tuned to make them run faster.

data.name: SDR-Q47_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem if the queries are already highly tuned.

data.value: Query Optimization

data.value: The following queries are the top 10 most I/O consuming queries in the last 24 hours in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q47_Finding
data.value: The following queries are the top 10 most I/O consuming queries in the last 24 hours in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q47_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The following queries are the top 10 most I/O consuming queries in the last 24 hours in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q47_InfoLinks

data.name: SDR-Q47_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Queries that perform a lot of I/O operations are prime candidates for tuning to see if the amount of I/O can be decreased, often by using better indexing.

data.name: SDR-Q47_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the following queries be investigated to see if they can be tuned to reduce the amount of I/O they require. I/O requirements are often reduced by implementing different indexes for all queries or by removing unused indexes for data modification queries.

data.name: SDR-Q48_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem if the plan change and increase in execution time are due to an environmental change like a sudden large increase in the amount of data.

data.name: SDR-Q48_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q48_Description
data.value: The following queries experienced an increase of at least double the execution time in the last 48 hours due to a change in the query plan in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q48_Finding
data.value: The following queries experienced an increase of at least double the execution time in the last 48 hours due to a change in the query plan in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q48_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The following queries experienced an increase of at least double the execution time in the last 48 hours due to a change in the query plan in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q48_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Monitoring Performance By Using the Query Store: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-US/library/dn817826.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink><RecommendationLink><Title>Microsoft Data Platform blog post: Buffer Pool Extension to SSDs in SQL Server 2014: </Title><Link>http://blogs.technet.com/b/dataplatforminsider/archive/2013/07/25/buffer-pool-extension-to-ssds-in-sql-server-2014.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-Q48_Problem_Explanation
data.value: A large increase in execution time due to a plan change may be an indicator that the plan has regressed to a less than optimal plan.

data.name: SDR-Q48_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the following plans be investigated to determine why the plan changed and whether or not the plan change was the best plan for the query. It is recommended that the query be tuned, if possible, to avoid the change in plan, or if necessary, force the better plan.

data.name: SDR-Q49_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem if the increase in execution duration is due to normal increases in activity or data or if the plan is still optimal for the query.

data.name: SDR-Q49_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q49_Description
data.value: The following top 10 queries have a longer run duration during the last 1 hour than did during the last day in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q49_Finding
data.value: The following top 10 queries have a longer run duration during the last 1 hour than did during the last day in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q49_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The following top 10 queries have a longer run duration during the last 1 hour than did during the last day in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q49_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Queries that are experiencing a longer run time may indicate that the current plan is no longer optimal or that some additional factor is affecting duration of the queries (such as increased blocking or waits).

data.name: SDR-Q49_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the following queries be investigated to determine the cause for the longer execution duration. The additional duration may be a sign of the plan no longer being optimal or it may be a symptom of external factors such as increased blocking or additional waits.

data.name: SDR-Q50_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem as long as execution time remains consistent across different plans.

data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q50_Description
data.value: The following queries have had more than 4 different plans in the last 48 hours in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q50_Finding
data.value: The following queries have had more than 4 different plans in the last 48 hours in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q50_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The following queries have had more than 4 different plans in the last 48 hours in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q50_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Queries that change plans often are prime candidates for plan regression resulting in inconsistent execution times.

data.name: SDR-Q50_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the following queries by investigated to determine why they change plans frequently to see if the query can be optimized to avoid generating different plans or if the most optimal plan should be stabilized by forcing a specific plan.

data.name: SDR-I31_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem if the queries do not need to return the filtered column or do not need to use the filtered column value in an expression that does not exactly match the filter definition.

data.name: SDR-I31_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I31_Description
data.value: Filtered index [$(Name)] on Table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] does not list the filtered column in the key of the index.

data.name: SDR-I31_Finding
data.value: Filtered index [$(Name)] on Table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] does not list the filtered column in the key of the index.

data.name: SDR-I31_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Filtered index [$(Name)] on Table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] does not list the filtered column in the key of the index.

data.name: SDR-I31_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Filtered indexes that do not include the filtered column in the key of the index may not be used for queries unless the filter matches exactly and does not need to use or return the filtered column value. Including the filtered column in the key of the index allows the index to be used for a wider variety of queries.

data.name: SDR-I31_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the column in the filter of the filtered index be included in the key of the index to increase the chances that it will be used by the optimizer.

data.name: SDR-I30_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If old data is not being frequently queried or if current performance is acceptable.

data.name: SDR-I30_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I30_Description
data.value: Large tables with a high number of table or clustered index scans are not taking advantage of columnstore indexes.

data.name: SDR-I30_Finding
data.value: Large table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] with a high number of table or clustered index scans is not taking advantage of columnstore indexes.

data.name: SDR-I30_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Large table [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] with a high number of table or clustered index scans is not taking advantage of columnstore indexes.

data.name: SDR-I30_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Columnstore Indexes for Operational Analytics: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn817827.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-I30_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Large tables often have a small subset of active data and large blocks of inactive data. The active portion of the data benefits from standard indexes whereas queries on the large blocks of data would benefit from columnstore indexes. SQL Server 2015 introduced the ability to add columnstore indexes to tables with standard indexes already in place. Additionally, the indexes can take advantage of filtering to ensure that the columnstore index only covers the old, unchanging data.

data.name: SDR-I30_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that large tables with a high number of table or clustered index scans be considered for applying columnstore indexes after thorough testing.

data.name: SDR-Q43_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It is not a problem if overall performance of the procedure is acceptable.

data.name: SDR-Q43_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q43_Description
data.value: Frequently executed procedure [$(ProcedureName)] with high CPU time to total elapsed time ratio was found in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q43_Finding
data.value: Frequently executed procedure [$(ProcedureName)] with high CPU time to total elapsed time ratio was found in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q43_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Frequently executed procedure [$(ProcedureName)] with high CPU time to total elapsed time ratio was found in database [$(Database)].

data.name: SDR-Q43_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online Article: Determining if a Table or Stored Procedure Should Be Ported to In-Memory OLTP: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn205133.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-Q43_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Procedures that consume a high amount of CPU time in relation to the total elapsed time could run faster in natively compiled code.

data.name: SDR-Q43_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that frequently executed procedures that have a high CPU time to total elapsed time ratio be considered for native compilation. Native compilation requires that referenced tables are in-memory tables so native compilation may not be possible for all procedures that are good candidates for native compilation.

data.name: SDR-I27_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem if the table is very small.

data.name: SDR-I27_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I27_Description
data.value: Hash indexes are being scanned.

data.name: SDR-I27_Finding
data.value: Hash index $(Name) on table $(Schema).$(Table) in database [$(Database)] is being scanned.

data.name: SDR-I27_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Hash index $(Name) on table $(Schema).$(Table) in database [$(Database)] is being scanned.

data.name: SDR-I27_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Troubleshooting Common Performance Problems with Memory-Optimized Hash Indexes: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn589805.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-I27_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Hash indexes are not ordered by the keys and scans on hash indexes hinder performance significantly. Hash index functions require that all key columns be supplied in equality expressions. If any of the key columns are not referenced by the criteria of the query, the hash index cannot be used to find buckets with matching columns. Likewise, non-equality expressions on the key columns will result in a scan because the function requires explicit values, not a range of values.

data.name: SDR-I27_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that the code causing the scan be modified to include equality statements for columns of the hash index key or that a non-hashed nonclustered index scan be used instead or in addition to the hash index. Memory-optimized indexes cannot be altered and can only be created with the CREATE TABLE statement. Changing or adding a memory=optimized index recreating the table with the changed and new indexes.

data.name: SDR-I24_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem if the queries on the table are not experiencing poor plan selection due to inaccurate statistics.

data.name: SDR-I24_Category
data.value: Index Optimization

data.name: SDR-I24_Description
data.value: There are very large tables (greater than or equal to 1 million rows) and a high number of modifications have been made since the last time statistics were updated.

data.name: SDR-I24_Finding
data.value: There is very large table (greater than or equal to 1 million rows) [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] and a high number of modifications have been made since the last time statistics were updated.

data.name: SDR-I24_Impact_Explanation
data.value: There is very large table (greater than or equal to 1 million rows) [$(Schema)].[$(Table)] in database [$(Database)] and a high number of modifications have been made since the last time statistics were updated.

data.name: SDR-I24_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>KB2754171 Controlling Autostat (AUTO_UPDATE_STATISTICS) behavior in SQL Server: </Title><Link>https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/2754171 </Link></RecommendationLink><RecommendationLink><Title>Microsoft blog post: Changes to automatic update statistics in SQL Server – traceflag 2371: </Title><Link>http://blogs.msdn.com/b/saponsqlserver/archive/2011/09/07/changes-to-automatic-update-statistics-in-sql-server-traceflag-2371.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-I24_Problem_Explanation
data.value: The default behavior for automatically updated statistics on large tables is to update when the number of changes equals 500 + 20% of the total rows. For example, statistics for a table with 10 million rows will not be updated until there have been 2,500,000 changes to the table. This may not be enough to maintain statistics accurately enough for a large table.

data.name: SDR-I24_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that statistics be kept up to date for all tables, however keeping very large tables up to date without manual intervention is difficult. Trace flag 2371 changes the calculation for when to automatically update statistics. Statistics are updated on a sliding scale, for example, statistics for a table with 10 million rows will be updated after 100,000 changes rather than 2,500,000 changes. Really small tables will not be affected by this change as the statistics update threshold will be the lessor of the new formula or the old formula (500 + 20%).

data.name: SDR-D23_Additional_Considerations
data.value: May not be a problem if less critical queries are not causing high levels of I/O operations.

data.name: SDR-D23_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D23_Description
data.value: Resource Governor is being used to limit resources of some queries, but I/O operations are not being limited and there have been occurrences of I/O stall detected.

data.name: SDR-D23_Finding
data.value: Resource Governor is being used to limit resources of some queries, but I/O operations are not being limited and there have been occurrences of I/O stall detected.

data.name: SDR-D23_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Resource Governor is being used to limit resources of some queries, but I/O operations are not being limited and there have been occurrences of I/O stall detected.

data.name: SDR-D23_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>BOL article Resource Governor Enhancements for Physical IO Control: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb510411%28v=sql.120%29.aspx#RG </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-D23_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Resource Governor allows you to cap the resources used by queries in a pre-defined pool to prevent less critical queries from using too many resources that are needed for more critical queries. SQL Server 2014 added the ability to limit the number of I/O operations per second per disk that a query can use. Because pending I/O stall is occurring, critical processes may be experiencing performance degradation if less critical queries are issuing high levels of I/O operations.

data.name: SDR-D23_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that Resource Governor pools that are intended to limit resources for less critical queries be evaluated to see if they are issuing high levels of I/O operations and consider limiting the amount of I/O for the resource pool.

data.name: SDR-Q44_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem if query performance is acceptable as is.

data.name: SDR-Q44_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q44_Description
data.value: New cardinality estimator is not being used.

data.name: SDR-Q44_Finding
data.value: New cardinality estimator is not being used.

data.name: SDR-Q44_Impact_Explanation
data.value: New cardinality estimator is not being used.

data.name: SDR-Q44_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Cardinality Estimation (SQL Server): </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn600374%28v=sql.120%29.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-Q44_Problem_Explanation
data.value: The cardinality estimator estimates the number of rows that will be affected or returned by a specific relational expression in a query (such as a join) and accurate estimations are critical for making the correct plan choice. SQL Server 2014 introduced a new, improved cardinality estimator, but it is not enabled unless the database compatibility is set to at least 120 (SQL Server 2014).

data.name: SDR-Q44_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that all databases be set to the current compatibility level unless there is a compelling reason to use a lower level setting. The new cardinality estimator introduced in SQL Server 2014 should yield more consistent good plans than the old cardinality estimator.

data.name: SDR-R8_Additional_Considerations
data.value: It may not be a problem if you would prefer the database stay offline rather than failover.

data.name: SDR-R8_Category
data.value: Disaster Recovery

data.name: SDR-R8_Description
data.value: Availability Group [$(AvailabilityGroupName)] is not enabled for failover if a database is not online.

data.name: SDR-R8_Finding
data.value: Availability Group [$(AvailabilityGroupName)] is not enabled for failover if a database is not online.

data.name: SDR-R8_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Availability Group [$(AvailabilityGroupName)] is not enabled for failover if a database is not online.

data.name: SDR-R8_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: ALTER AVAILABILITY GROUP (Transact-SQL): </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff878601.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-R8_Problem_Explanation
data.value: If the database on the active node of an Availability Group is not online but the server is still functioning normally, the Availability Group will not fail over. SQL Server 2016 introduced a new option that enables the Availability Group to fail over if this event occurs.

data.name: SDR-R8_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that DB_FAILOVER be enabled for synchronous Availability Groups to allow the Availability Group to fail over if one of the member databases is not online to avoid a prolonged outage.

data.name: SDR-M33_Additional_Considerations
data.value: When there is no possibility to increase the amount of memory allocated to SQL Server and I/O response time is faster than disk I/O response times would be.

data.name: SDR-M33_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M33_Description
data.value: The Buffer Pool Extension is experiencing high levels of I/O queuing.

data.name: SDR-M33_Finding
data.value: The Buffer Pool Extension is experiencing high levels of I/O queuing.

data.name: SDR-M33_Impact_Explanation
data.value: The Buffer Pool Extension is experiencing high levels of I/O queuing.

data.name: SDR-M33_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Buffer Pool Extensions: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn133176.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: SQL Server, Buffer Manager Object: </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms189628.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-M33_Problem_Explanation
data.value: If the buffer pool extension is experiencing high levels of I/O queuing, logical I/O response times may be slow and hinder query performance.

data.name: SDR-M33_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that only Enterprise class SSD drives be used for the buffer pool extension. If the drives are not fast enough, query performance will degrade, especially on a busy system that results in many I/O operations queuing up.

data.name: SDR-Q45_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If the query does not have any relational expressions (such as joins).

data.name: SDR-Q45_Category
data.value: Query Optimization

data.name: SDR-Q45_Description
data.value: Both new and old cardinality estimators are being forced at the same time.

data.name: SDR-Q45_Finding
data.value: Both new and old cardinality estimators are being forced at the same time.

data.name: SDR-Q45_Impact_Explanation
data.value: Both new and old cardinality estimators are being forced at the same time.

data.name: SDR-Q45_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>Books Online article: Cardinality Estimation (SQL Server): </Title><Link>https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn600374%28v=sql.120%29.aspx </Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-Q45_Problem_Explanation
data.value: A new cardinality estimator was written for SQL Server 2014. When using the new cardinality estimator on compatibility level 120, you can use the trace flag 9481 as a query hint to force a specific query to use the old cardinality estimator. You can also use trace flag 9481 as a session or global trace flag to force the behavior on a wider scope. If you are still running on the old cardinality estimator in SQL Server 2014+, you can test a specific query using the new cardinality estimator by using trace flag 2312 to force the new cardinality estimator. The trace flag may also be set as a session or global trace flag to force the behavior on a wider scope. If both of these trace flags are enabled at the same time, the behavior of the cardinality estimator may be unpredictable.

data.name: SDR-Q45_Recommendation
data.value: It is recommended that trace flags that change the default behavior of SQL Server only be implemented when absolutely required. The queries affected by the trace flag should be thoroughly tested to determine which cardinality estimator provides the desired results and ensure that only that estimator is being used though either database compatibility setting and only use the trace flag when required to change the behavior for specific queries.

data.name: SDR-DC7_Category
data.value: Database Configuration

data.name: SDR-DC7_Description
data.value: Database is at 90% of Storage Capacity

data.name: SDR-DC7_Finding
data.value: The Azure SQL Database usage exceeds 90% of the service tier maximum

data.name: SDR-DC7_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Azure SQL Databases have a set size limit based on the selected Service Tier for the database. If the maximum size is reached, the database will only operate in a limited function.

data.name: SDR-DC7_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If the database is static and will not grow, then this will not be an issue.

data.name: SDR-DC7_Recommendation
data.value:
Azure SQL Database sizes are determined by the Service Tier for the service. They cannot be altered, though the database’s service tier can be increased to support a larger database size. If a database’s maximum capacity, it will impact the operation of the database and could prevent it from functioning. If a database is using 90% of its maximum capacity, the owner should consider one of two options:
 Increase the database’s Service Tier  Scale out the database using Azure SQL Database’s Elastic Database configuration.

data.name: SDR-DC8_Category
data.value: Database Configuration

data.name: SDR-DC8_Description
data.value: Database is at 90% of DTU Capacity

data.name: SDR-DC8_Finding
data.value: Azure SQL Database Transaction Units (DTU) average usage exceeds 90% of DTUs for the Service Tier in the last hour

data.name: SDR-DC8_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Azure SQL Database performance is controlled by the amount of DTUs allocated by the service tier. Reaching this maximum means that the query performance will be throttled in order to maintain the database’s Service Tier.

data.name: SDR-DC8_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If the owner does not wish to increase the Service Tier and is all right with performance being throttled on the database.

data.name: SDR-DC8_Recommendation
data.value:
Azure SQL Database query performance is defined by Database Transaction Units (DTU), which sets a limit on how many transactions can be performed per second against the database. DTUs are calculated based on CPU, memory, I/Os. While reaching the maximum DTUs will not prevent the database from responding, owners will see increased response time for their queries.
Owners have two options to increase their available DTUs:
 Increase the database’s Service Tier  Scale out the database using Azure SQL Database’s Elastic Database configuration.

data.name: SDR-DC9_Category
data.value: Database Configuration

data.name: SDR-DC9_Description
data.value: Database is at 90% of user sessions

data.name: SDR-DC9_Finding
data.value: In the last hour, average sessions in the Azure SQL Database exceeded 90% of the maximum allowed sessions

data.name: SDR-DC9_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Azure SQL Database Service Tiers define the number of users that can be connected to a database at any time. If this maximum is reached, no further connections can be made.

data.name: SDR-DC9_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If the owner does not wish to allow more sessions and accepts the limitation.

data.name: SDR-DC9_Recommendation
data.value:
The Service Tiers for Azure SQL Database limit several items within the database. One of these is the number of concurrent user sessions. While reaching this maximum will not prevent the database from functioning, it does mean that no further connections can be made. This can limit administration or impact how the database supports a growing user base.
Owners have two options to increase their available sessions:
 Increase the database’s Service Tier  Scale out the database using Azure SQL Database’s Elastic Database configuration.

data.name: SDR-DC10_Category
data.value: Database Configuration

data.name: SDR-DC10_Description
data.value: Database is at 90% of worker threads

data.name: SDR-DC10_Finding
data.value: In the last hour, average worker threads in the Azure SQL Database exceeded 90% of the maximum allowed workers

data.name: SDR-DC10_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Azure SQL Database Service Tiers define the number of worker threads that can execute in a database at any time. If this maximum is reached, the database will still operate, but operation will be impacted and latency can increase.

data.name: SDR-DC10_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If the owner does not wish to allow more workers and accepts the limitation.

data.name: SDR-DC10_Recommendation
data.value:
The Service Tiers for Azure SQL Database limit several items within the database. One of these is the number of worker threads. While reaching this maximum will not prevent the database from functioning, it does mean that workers will be throttled. This can limit how the database supports work load.
Owners have two options to increase their available worker threads:
 Increase the database’s Service Tier  Scale out the database using Azure SQL Database’s Elastic Database configuration.

data.name: SDR-DC11_Category
data.value: Database Configuration

data.name: SDR-DC11_Description
data.value: Database Service Tier has been reduced

data.name: SDR-DC11_Finding
data.value: The Service Tier for the Azure SQL Database has been reduced since the last run of SQL Doctor

data.name: SDR-DC11_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Service Tiers determine the amount of performance resources allocated to an Azure SQL Database. Reducing the Service Tier can limit the overall performance of the database.

data.name: SDR-DC11_Additional_Considerations
data.value: Because Azure SQL Database are easily scalable, it is possible that a database can be scaled more than is necessary by the owner. If research and costs are reviewed and the owner determines a higher Service Tier is not needed, this is not an issue.

data.name: SDR-DC11_Recommendation
data.value: Service Tiers are the equivalent of hardware sizing for Azure SQL Databases. While these are flexible, they should not change frequently as this could drastically effect performance. Any changes should be reviewed by the database owner and the decision to reduce the Service Tier should be considered and deliberate.

data.name: SDR-S14_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S14_Description
data.value: Review Your Azure SQL Database for Public Network Access

data.name: SDR-S14_Finding
data.value: You are currently allowing non-Azure access to your Azure SQL Databases

data.name: SDR-S14_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Allowing too many networks and IP addresses to your Azure SQL Database exposes your data to unknown attack vectors.

data.name: SDR-S14_Additional_Considerations
data.value: There is no fixed recommendation for how many IP addresses are too many. If the specified ranges match the owner’s security policies, it should be allowed.

data.name: SDR-S14_Recommendation
data.value:
It is recommended that you only allow the specific IP address ranges necessary for your network security policy. Since Azure SQL Database is a cloud offering, it is accessible via the internet. Review any public access to make sure it matches with your network security policy.
Azure SQL Database allows the owner to create both server and database firewall rules, allowing a high level of access customization. Server rules will define IP address access for any database hosted on that Azure SQL Database server, which means general access policies can be defined. Additionally, each database can have its own set of firewall rules that control access to that database specifically. Azure SQL Database firewall rules define what is allowed, not what is denied. The assumption is that unless the owner explicitly wants to allow access, it will be blocked. Thus, firewall rules are cumulative, meaning that access to a range of IPs will be allowed if that range is contained within the server or database firewall rules.
Azure SQL Database does allow owners to create a rule that allows any service from within the Azure boundary. This restricts access to only services from within the Azure environment, but could allow access to other Azure users.

data.name: SDR-S15_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S15_Description
data.value: Access from all Azure IPs has been enabled on your Azure SQL Database

data.name: SDR-S15_Finding
data.value: There is a firewall rule that allows all Azure IPs to access to your database

data.name: SDR-S15_Problem_Explanation
data.value: While generally considered safe, enabling this rule means that any Azure service (even those owned by other customers) can connect to your Azure SQL Database.

data.name: SDR-S15_Additional_Considerations
data.value: Many Azure services, especially outside of Infrastructure-as-a-Service offerings, will not have a specific IP address. This means a firewall rule for these services cannot be created. These services are protected by Azure’s overall security settings.

data.name: SDR-S15_Recommendation
data.value: If you can restrict access to specific IP addresses, you should avoid allowing access to all Azure IPs. Only enable this if you are making use of Azure services that do not have a specific IP address to connect from, such as PowerBI or Azure Web Sites.

data.name: SDR-DC12_Category
data.value: Database Configuration

data.name: SDR-DC12_Description
data.value: Instance uses Enterprise Edition, but database uses no Enterprise Edition features

data.name: SDR-DC12_Finding
data.value: SQL Instance is Enterprise Edition, but the target database(s) do not use Enterprise Edition features

data.name: SDR-DC12_Problem_Explanation
data.value: SQL Server Enterprise edition is the most expensive version of SQL Server. While offering many useful features, if a database is not using these features then it could be more reasonably supported using a different edition of SQL Server.

data.name: SDR-DC12_Additional_Considerations
data.value: SQL Server Enterprise edition offers many instance level features that can benefit the databases it hosts. If use of these features is worthwhile, Enterprise edition can be justified.

data.name: SDR-DC12_Recommendation
data.value:
Consider carefully the impact of your SQL Server edition choice. Microsoft licenses use of SQL Server based on these editions and the cost of this can be significant. If a database does not use Enterprise level features, it could be more appropriately supported by Standard edition or lower.
Another course of action is to implement Enterprise edition features that could benefit your database. Review the available features and consider if any database specific features could improve the performance or security of your database.

data.name: SDR-S13_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S13_Description
data.value: Azure SQL Database Auditing is not enabled

data.name: SDR-S13_Finding
data.value: Azure SQL Database auditing not enabled for the target database

data.name: SDR-S13_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Enabling auditing allows the owner to track several events within the operation of the database, aiding troubleshooting and investigation of database issues.

data.name: SDR-S13_Additional_Considerations
data.value: This is not an issue if the owner does not wish to track these events.

data.name: SDR-S13_Recommendation
data.value:
Auditing within Azure SQL Database offers additional mechanisms for owners to troubleshoot database issue, therefore it is recommended that this feature is enabled. Events include:
 Plain SQL success or failure  Parameterized SQL success or failure  Stored Procedure success or failure  Login success or failure  Transaction success or failure  Threat detection and alerting
To enable auditing, the owner will need a storage account in Azure to write the events to, but can then view these events via the portal or PowerShell.

data.name: SDR-DC13_Category
data.value: Database Configuration

data.name: SDR-DC13_Description
data.value: Query Store Defaults Changed

data.name: SDR-DC13_Finding
data.value: Azure SQL Databases’s Query Store default settings have changed

data.name: SDR-DC13_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Query Store’s default values cover the bulk of operating conditions for the feature. Only owners with the knowledge of what they are changing and why should alter these settings, as changes could result in unexpected side effects. Please research the settings you are altering before making changes to the defaults.

data.name: SDR-DC13_Additional_Considerations
data.value: There are use cases where certain query store defaults can be changed. If the owner has reviewed the impact of such a change and is managing the results of such a change, then it is safe to alter these.

data.name: SDR-DC13_Recommendation
data.value:
The Query Store defaults cover most use cases. While they can be altered, this should only be done with knowledge of the why the changes are being made. Many of these values define how much data is collected, how often it is collected, and how long it will be retained. This is because the Query Store is contained within the database and its size counts against your total database size.
The most important setting is the maximum Query Store size. The Query Store will not grow beyond this, which protects the database’s operation against the Query Store growing out of control. However, if the Query Store maximum is reached, the Query Store will go into Read Only mode and cease to collect new query data. Owners should monitor Query Store usage and adjust these defaults as necessary.
Please note that on servers with extremely active workloads or expensive queries, it may be necessary to adjust these defaults. Monitoring and adjustment of the Query Store settings should be performed with care and only modified where appropriate.

data.name: SDR-R9_Category
data.value: Disaster Recovery

data.name: SDR-R9_Description
data.value: Configure Geo-Replication for HA/DR

data.name: SDR-R9_Finding
data.value: The Azure SQL Database has no geo-replication targets configured

data.name: SDR-R9_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Geo-replication is Azure SQL Database’s high-availability/disaster recovery feature. Without it, the database could suffer service interruption.

data.name: SDR-R9_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If the owner does not need HA/DR support for the database (such as a QA or development database), geo-replication is not needed.

data.name: SDR-R9_Recommendation
data.value:
Active geo-replication is a feature offered for all levels of Azure SQL Database. Databases can have up to four failover targets in other Azure regions, which can be used as readable secondaries. These failover targets will be synchronized and managed by the Azure platform, but must be initially configured by the database owner.
High availability and disaster recovery design is a very important item in any database solution. If the Azure SQL Database in question supports a production level workload, geo-replication should be enabled in order to protect the database against service interruption.

data.name: SDR-R10_Category
data.value: Disaster Recovery

data.name: SDR-R10_Description
data.value: Geo-Replicated Secondary is in SUSPENDED mode

data.name: SDR-R10_Finding
data.value: A secondary replica for the Azure SQL Database is in a SUSPENDED state

data.name: SDR-R10_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Secondary replicas in a SUSPENDED state are not synchronizing and cannot be failed over to.

data.name: SDR-R10_Additional_Considerations
data.value: You should always have your replicas synchronizing.

data.name: SDR-R10_Recommendation
data.value: Geo-replication should be setup between regions that have enough bandwidth to support replicating transactions to the secondary databases. If the secondary is in a region that does not have enough bandwidth to replicate, Azure will suspend the replication. It is recommended that the secondary replica be placed in a recommended region (which Azure will provide when geo-replication is enabled).

data.name: SDR-R11_Category
data.value: Disaster Recovery

data.name: SDR-R11_Description
data.value: Geo-Replicated Secondary is more than 300 seconds behind

data.name: SDR-R11_Finding
data.value: The replica_lag value for the database is greater than 300, meaning that the secondary replica is greater than 300 seconds behind the primary

data.name: SDR-R11_Problem_Explanation
data.value: If the replica is far enough behind the primary, it cannot be reliably failed over to.

data.name: SDR-R11_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If there is a large, ongoing task that could increase the amount of data to be replicated, then this warning can be disregarded. However, the replica lag should be checked again once the task is complete.

data.name: SDR-R11_Recommendation
data.value: If replicas become too far out of sync with the primary database, it will not be a reliable failover target. This value should be monitored to make sure that it is not consistently behind. Causes for this could be large transactions where large amounts of data are being replicated, or long running transactions that cannot be completed. Check your database for any activity that could be creating extra work for the replication process.

data.name: SDR-SC10_InfoLinks
