data.name: SDR-S11_InfoLinks
data.value: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-16"?><ArrayOfRecommendationLink xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"><RecommendationLink><Title>RDS FAQ (How do I connect to an RDS DB Instance in VPC?)</Title><Link>https://aws.amazon.com/rds/faqs/</Link></RecommendationLink></ArrayOfRecommendationLink>

data.name: SDR-P24_Category
data.value: Processor

data.name: SDR-P24_Description
data.value: RDS Instance is at 90% of CPU utilization

data.name: SDR-P24_Finding
data.value: The RDS instance exceeded 90% CPU utilization during the last hour

data.name: SDR-P24_Problem_Explanation
data.value: CPU cycles indicate the level of work running against a SQL Server. While this should see high utilization, constant high levels could mean poor query performance due to CPU pressure.

data.name: SDR-P24_Recommendation
data.value: Database performance is partly defined by the amount of CPU utilization it is seeing. CPU resources are needed to process queries, there should always be some amount of overhead to make sure that queries are not waiting on CPU resources to complete. It is important to always size your RDS instance so that it will not be 100% utilized too frequently. The advantage of using RDS means that hardware sizing is elastic and can be changed easily. If the RDS instance is repeatedly at higher than 90%, the instance size should be increased to make more CPU resources available to the instance. The owner should review workloads to identify if there is a constant pattern of use that should result in instance growth.

data.name: SDR-P24_Additional_Considerations
data.value: Abnormal workloads could spike the CPU to higher than 90%, creating a false positive. Analyze your workload to validate that the high CPU is not a regular occurrence

data.name: SDR-D24_Additional_Considerations
data.value: Abnormal workloads could spike the storage latencies to higher recommended best practices, creating a false positive. Analyze your workload to validate that high latencies are not a regular occurrence.

data.name: SDR-D24_Category
data.value: Disk

data.name: SDR-D24_Description
data.value: RDS Instance disk latencies are too high

data.name: SDR-D24_Finding
data.value: Write or Read latencies for the last hour are higher than recommended best practices

data.name: SDR-D24_Problem_Explanation
data.value: The biggest bottleneck to database performance is storage performance. When storage latencies are too high, this is an indicator that your performance is being throttled

data.name: SDR-D24_Recommendation
data.value: The most impactful performance factor for a database system is the storage. RDS offers several storage options to support different workloads in AWS. While many workloads can be tuned to have less impact on the storage, it can be necessary to upgrade the storage for the RDS instance if query tuning is not an option. The advantage of using RDS is that it is elastic. Storage types can be changed with short outages to support improved database performance. The owner should consider what additional performance is needed from the storage before selecting a storage option.

data.name: SDR-M34_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If the database is read only and/or will not grow, there is no need to grow the storage space

data.name: SDR-M34_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M34_Description
data.value: RDS Instance has less than 10% storage free

data.name: SDR-M34_Finding
data.value: There is less than 10% free space attached to the RDS instance

data.name: SDR-M34_Problem_Explanation
data.value: SQL Server needs storage space to write data to. If there is no free space available, the operation of the database could be impacted

data.name: SDR-M34_Recommendation
data.value: It is important that SQL Server databases always have storage space to grow and accommodate new data. If there is less than 10% free storage space, then additional storage space should be added to support growth. The amount of growth should be determined based on historical growth patterns. The recommendation is based on currently available free space on the volume and does not take into account any empty space within the database itself. If the database files on the RDS instance are pre-grown, then it could be ok to not grow the storage.

data.name: SDR-M35_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If the performance profile of the instance changes, it may be necessary to resize the instance

data.name: SDR-M35_Category
data.value: Memory

data.name: SDR-M35_Description
data.value: RDS Instance size has changed

data.name: SDR-M35_Finding
data.value: RDS instance size has changed from when it was last checked

data.name: SDR-M35_Problem_Explanation
data.value: RDS instance size defines how much CPU and RAM a SQL instance has to use. If this is altered, it will affect the performance of the SQL instance.

data.name: SDR-M35_Recommendation
data.value: RDS instance sizes define the available CPU and memory for a SQL Server. AWS will charge based on the size, so this should be managed in order to appropriately match the resources to the workload hosted by the instance. Any changes to this size should be measured and deliberate. Review the current workload to make sure the change is appropriate.

data.name: SDR-DC6_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If point in time recovery is not needed for the databases or the owner prefers to run manual backups, this setting is not necessary.

data.name: SDR-DC6_Category
data.value: Database Configuration

data.name: SDR-DC6_Description
data.value: RDS Instance does not have automatic backups configured

data.name: SDR-DC6_Finding
data.value: Automatic backups are not configured for your RDS instance or the backup retention period is less than seven days

data.name: SDR-DC6_Problem_Explanation
data.value: An advantage of using RDS is that database backups are managed by the service. If these are not enabled, the owner will not get any backups of their database unless manually executed.

data.name: SDR-DC6_Recommendation
data.value: RDS offers automatic backups that provides point in time recovery for any databases created in the RDS instance. This requires no additional configuration on the part of the owner other than enabling the service and setting a retention period. Recovery of these backups is also part of the service and removes some of the administration burden from the owner.

data.name: SDR-S11_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If the instance contains no sensitive data or the owner accepts the risks of exposing the RDS instance publicly, it is ok to enable this access.

data.name: SDR-S11_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S11_Description
data.value: RDS Instance has public access enabled

data.name: SDR-S11_Finding
data.value: The RDS instance is enabled for public access

data.name: SDR-S11_Problem_Explanation
data.value: When an instance is enabled for public access, it can be accessed from resources outside the AWS Virtual Private Cloud container that the instance lives in, making it more exposed.

data.name: SDR-S11_Recommendation
data.value: Since RDS is in the cloud, it can be accessed over the internet. This means that it is important to create the instance with protections against intrusion. In order to limit access and protect the RDS instance from intrusion, public access should be disabled.

data.name: SDR-SC10_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If the RDS instance is intended for development or there is some other reason high availability is not needed, Multi-Availability Zone is not needed.

data.name: SDR-SC10_Category
data.value: Server Configuration

data.name: SDR-SC10_Description
data.value: RDS Instance is not enabled for Multi-Availability Zone failover

data.name: SDR-SC10_Finding
data.value: MultiAZ is false for the RDS instance

data.name: SDR-SC10_Problem_Explanation
data.value: RDS instances are standalone instances within a single Availability Zone. This means it is a single point of failure if the server or Availability Zone becomes unavailable.

data.name: SDR-SC10_Recommendation
data.value: AWS deploys resources within Availability Zones in each region. These Availability Zones are essentially data centers housing the all the hardware to support the resources in that Zone, and multiple Availability Zones are contained within a region. While AWS strives to keep these Zones and resources up, they recommend that resources are built to have failover targets in other Availability Zones within a region to support high availability. RDS Instances use SQL Server mirroring to support high availability and AWS will create a failover target in another Availability Zone when Multi-Availability Zone deployment is declared. Some configuration will be handled automatically for the failover target (such as logins), but others will not (such as SQL Agent Jobs). Please see the official AWS documentation for the full details on this. It is recommended that if your RDS instance supports a production workload, you should enable Mult-Availability Zone failover to ensure the continued availability of your instance and databases.

data.name: SDR-S12_Additional_Considerations
data.value: If the owner accepts the risk for this level access and is unable to define specific IP addresses to connect from.

data.name: SDR-S12_Category
data.value: Security

data.name: SDR-S12_Description
data.value: RDS Instance has an access rule that allows access from any IP address

data.name: SDR-S12_Finding
data.value: One of the security groups attached to the RDS instance allows access from any IP address

data.name: SDR-S12_Problem_Explanation
data.value: Access to an RDS should be limited to known IP addresses to limit public exposure and reduce risk of attack.

data.name: SDR-S12_Recommendation
data.value: AWS security groups define how owners can access resources, including RDS instances, from outside and inside the Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) that the resource resides. Rules can be created to define what IP addresses can access the VPC and RDS instance. It is recommended that these IP ranges are explicit for what will connect to the RDS instance.
